By KEMPER DIEHL 
A $3.5 billion cut in the d e­ fense budget approved by Pre­ sident (’arter has become a de­ finite p o ssib ility , U .S. Rep., 
Henry Gonzalez revealed F r i­ day. 
Such a slash would affect the entire defense picture and "have a direct ef­ fect on areas such as Sun Antonio 
" I t ’s om inous," Gonzalez reported. 
Tile congressm an reported the deep d elen se cut is developing in the all- pow erful H ouse B udget C om m ittee, headed by Rep. Robert N. Giaimo of 
Connecticut. 
Final word 
Under new House reform rules, the budget com m ittee has the final word on spending. 
T h e H ouse A rm e d S e rv ic e s C om ­ m itte e is re c o m m e n d in g a defense budget for fiscal 1977 of $12o.9 billion. 
T his is $8oo m illion m o re than p ro ­ posed by C arter. 
Tile President had m ade some cuts 

 in the budget recom m ended by Presi­ dent Ford before he left office. 
T h e p ro po sed $3.5 billion cu t has b een d e v e lo p e d th r o u g h a b u d g e t c o m m itte e ta sk force and its staff, 
Gonzalez noted. 
He w a rn e d th e full c o m m itte e is 
"s ta c k e d with anti-defense c o n g re ss­ m en ,” and added "given the composi­ tion of the com m ittee, the chances are nine out of IU" the slash will he m a n ­ dated. 

Th*' co ng ressm an was back in San 
Antonio F riday to report on his first week back in action following a b reak he took to recover from an attack of flu and to rest 
D uring the week he presid ed over hearing s of his House S u bco m m ittee on International Development In stitu ­ tions and Finance. 
The h e a rin g s d e a lt w ith a C a r te r adm inistration request for funds for international lending agencies. 

Gonzalez said the testim ony raised his concern over h ug e loans by U S. banks to developing nations which find difficulty in m aking paym ents. 
He said the problem is U.S. banking regulators have perm itted the banking system to in c re a se its lending co m ­ m itm ents to such nations from $2o billion to $8o billion in a brief space of time. 
He warned this has diverted capital

P rim e Minister Tantn Kraivi\n>n But an arm y television station said most of th*' Thai m ilitary still supported the government.

State budget looks bleak 

Bv DICK MERKEL 
C H W . 
NIW& CAPITO* DUK*AU 
AUSTIN — The members of the House Appropriations Com­ mittee left here for home Friday tarrying with them a one-page document and a m essage from 
Hie com m ittee chairman. 
"T ak e this home with you and pray over it," Rep. Bill P resuai of Bryan told his c o m m itte e m e m b e r s as he passed out the paper. 
Both the printed word and the spo­ ken word were crystal clear. 
T he c o m m itte e m u st return he re 
Monday and start ham m ering out the 
House version of the 85th Legislature ' n general appropriations bill. 
The Senate also m ust come up with 
Us appropriations bill. 
They are starting out $888 million in the hole, th e E xp ress-N ew s learn ed exclusively late Friday. 
B etw een M onday an d m id -A p ril, when Speaker Bill Clayton has said he 

L 
E xpreH R -N ew s A n a ly s is 

 wants the bill before the House, the com m ittee is going to have to cut so­ mething — a lot of som ethings — out. 
Starting place 

T his fact m akes P rc s n u l’s s u g g e s ­ tion about p ray e r look like about us good a place to start as any. 
The B5th Legislature started out in 
Jan uary with the cheery prospects of som ething like $3 billion with which to finance the state for the 1978-79 bien ­ nium. 
The Legislative Budget B o ard’s re ­ com m endation for 1978*79 cam e out at 
$1.7 billion, leaving a surp lus for all new state spending over the next two years at approxim ately $1.3 billion 
Right now there are pending before the le g isla tu re bills calling for new state sp ending totaling exactly $1.32 billion. 

In a d d itio n , c o m m i t t e e s h e a rin g agency budget re q u e s ts have reco m ­ m ended increases totallin g $918 m il­ lion over the LHB recom m endation to the Appropriations Com m ittee, 

Together, the new spending bills and the substantive committee recom m en­ dations come to $2.2 billion. It doest! \ 

 take a m a th e m a tic a l whiz to realize that, when you only have $13 billion to spend, you’re in trouble. 
An e x a m p le of new sp e n d in g bills already so m ew h ere in the legislative m aze is H BI calling for a cut in the sales tax on utility bills and increasing the state inheritance tax exemption, 
T h is b il l, a lr e a d y p a s s e d in th e 
House and now in the Senate, will lost 
$258 million over the next two years 
P u b lic school fin an ce , now h* m g

Wild/lowers dot highways 

T hanks to the bountiful rainfall this year, bluebonnets, 
Indian paint­ brushes and yellow daisies are dotting state highways. 
Some of T exas’s 5,ooo varieties of w in n o w e r s can be seen along the 
IH41o and H arry W urzbach Highway interchange. 

B luebonnets and Indian pain tb ru sh also can be seen on UUU and HURL j 
M otorists wishing to catch a colorful view run follow 11135 south to T exas 
173; T exas 173 east to FM 1333; F M 1333 north to FM 478, FM 478 w est and north to FM 3175; FM 3175 w est to IH35 and 11135 north lo Kan Antonio.

Irish Sweepstakes top prize $68o,ooo 

R o b e r t B ennett, a 68-year-old father of five from Chesapeake City. 
Md., won the $68o,ooo “ superprize” in th e 1977 Irish Hospital S w eep ­ stakes, it was announced F riday in 
Dublin. Ireland. 
O rgan izers said Bennett's sister. 
Grace Long of Mungret in County 
L im erick, bought the ticket for her b ro th e r, a n ative of Ireland who moved to the United States in 193o. 
“ I will naturally continue to buy tickets in every sweep from now o n,” she s a id . T he draw ing was held 
T hursday and tile results announced 
Hie F riday . 
Celebrities'1 items varied but no empty 

Ronald Reagan sent a silk scarf. 
Betty Ford, an engraving of th e 
White House, George Wallace a pen from the office of the Alabama go­ vernor, Strom g Thurmond an au to ­ graphed book and two pens, 
Paul 
Newman a silver initialed ashtry. 
T he item s will be auctioned S a tu r­ day in Simpsonville, S.C., for various local charities. 
"I w as surprised we got the re­ sponse we did." said Jim Hudgins. who is collecting the celebrity item s for th e auction. The local S ertom a club had asked the celebrities for sm all m em entoes. 
They also got an autographed book from Gen William C. W estmoreland, a te n n is racket cover signed by 
Arthur Ashe and a program from the inauguration of Gov. Jam es B. E d­ wards. 
W hat they wanted but didn t get was an em p ty beer can from 
Billy 
Carter. “ We didn't hear from h im .” 
H udgins said. 

The lottery is operated by Irish hospitals as a fund-raising venture, and organizers say most tickets are sold in the United States. 
T hursday’s draw ing was the last tim e the ‘‘s u p e r p r i z e ” w ill be awarded. O rg a n iz e r plan to reduce the top prize to $425,9oo and offer more sm aller awards. 

Libel suit reversed 

Doubleday A Co., Inc., won a reversal of a jury aw ard of $125,oo2 to w riter A.E. Hotchner because of the way he was mentioned in the 1974 p u b lic a tio n of ‘‘H e m in g w a y in 
Spain " 
The U.S. Court of Appeals in New 
York found there was insufficient proof of “ knowledge of falsity or reckless disregard for tru th ” in m a­ terial that called Hotchner, a friend of 
Hem ingway, a “ to ad y ” and 
“ hyprocrite” among other things. t h e F irst A m en dm en t b a rs d a ­ m ages without this elem ent, it said 
The book in which Hotchner was mentioned was a translation from a 
Spanish work by Jose Luis Castillo- 
Puche, remiscing about travels with 
Hemingway in Spain and Cuba. 
The jury had aw arded Hotchner $1 for libel and invasion of privacy, plus 
$125,ooo in punitive dam ages. 
Hotchner. of Westport. Conn., is the author of “ Papa H em ingw ay.” 

Bing Crosby, wearing a golf hat, as usual, is placed in an am bulance for a trip to the Los A ngeles International Airport for a flight to San Francisco, where he will be treated for a ruptured disc. He injured his back in a fall from a stage while filming a TV special aired last Sunday — AP W irephoto 
Beauty contest winner never in r home’ county 

Deborah Sue M artin, who will represent New York State in the Miss 
USA pageant, has never set foot in the upstate county she represented in the state contest 

The 5 foot 9. hazel-eyed beauty from Umatilla. Fla . said sin1 had never been to Fulton County in tin' 
.southern A d iro n d a ck s before th e state contest. 

Miss Martin, an 18-year-old student at a M anhattan fashion school, was assigned to represen t the county, which did not participate in the p a ­ geant. after being a runner-up in the 
G reater New York pageant 

The Miss USA contest will be held in Charleston, S.C., in Mav.

Vance to face problem s 

WASHINGTON (AP) - Secretary of 
State Cyrus R Vance left Friday n ig h t for Moscow, where he will be g reeted by som e heat and uncertainty as he sots down new American proposals for a nuclear a rm s control agreement. 
In a b rie f d e p a rtu re s ta te m e n t a t nearby Andrews Air Force Base, Md., 
Vance said, “ I see our task as seeking to reach an agreem ent with the Soviet l ino on the framework for negotiations that would follow in Geneva for a SALT 
( s t r a t e g i c a r m s l i m i t a t i o n ) agreem ent. 
“ I hope very much, indeed I p ra y , th a t we m a y ach iev e th is p u r p o s e because I know of nothing that is m ore im portant to not only our country and the Soviet Union but to the peace of the w orld at l a r g e ” than an a r m s agreem ent, he added. 

K ey a d v is e r s a c c o m p a n y in g th e secretary’ on the eight-dav trip to the 
Sov iet Union and Western Europe said th e n e g a tiv e e le m e n ts of V a n c e ’s reception would come in the form of 

Efforts to m a k e p ro g ress on a rr a n g in g a new 
Strategic Arm s Limitation tre a ty ( S A H ) will /pc l ance’s prim e focus, although no actual negotia­ tions are e x p e c te d a n d no one is p r e d ic tin g a breakthrough 

Soviet questioning about U.S. hum an rights policy. 
Litany 

At the sam e tim e , these o fficials stressed what has becom e P resid en t 
C a rte r’s litany on the su b ject: U.S. feelings on the m atter are not aim ed only at Russia and should not be a l­ lowed to interfere with p ro g re ss on arm s control. 
Carter told a group of media execu­ tives Friday that “ a good spirit” su r­ rounds Vance's trip. C arter said the 
Soviets have p laced “ no p r e c o n d i­ tions" on the trip.

WAY TO DRESS 

Efforts to make progress on a rr a n g ­ ing a new Strategic Arms Lim itation 
Treaty (SALT) will Ik* Vance's prim e focus, although no actual negotiations are expected and no one is predicting a breakthrough. 
R a th e r, U.S. o ffic ia ls s a y . th e 
American delegation will be w orking to estab lish a fram ew o rk in w hich more serious exchanges can be m ade in the future. 
Strategy 

In his news conference T h u rsd a y , 
Carter outlined his broad strategy for 
Vance's trip. First, Vance will propose working for a /comprehensive accord in which deep cuts are made in the c u r­ ren t n u clea r a rs e n a ls held by both sides. 
If that is not acceptable at this tim e. 
Carter said the U.S. “ fallback” posi- ion will be to fo rm a liz e a 1974 a- greement reached iii principle setting ceiling of 2,4oo on the n u m b e r of m issiles or strateg ic b o m b e rs, w ith 
1,32o the m axim um num ber of m issiles that could carry multiple w arheads. 
T his will re q u ire d e f e r r in g u n til another SALT treaty the two issu es that have blocked formal agreem ent to date, the new American cruise m issile sy s te m and th e S oviet B a c k f ir e bomber. 
Maneuvering 
W hile th e o ffic ia ls w ho b r ie f e d reporters on the trip said the P resident w a n ts e it h e r th e c o m p r e h e n s i v e agree m en t or d eferral of the cru ise and Backfire issues, the officials did not rule out maneuvering between the two posi lions.

Handicapped plan sit-ins at 
HEW offices 

WASHINGTON — Thousands of handicapped Ameri­ cans may risk being wheelchaired off to jail in a militant attempt to shut down government offices in IO cities. 

To bolster Vance's mission. 57 sena­ tors sent a letter to Carter on Friday slating their support for the adm inis­ tration's stand on hum an rights. 
At tile same time. Senate Republican leader Howard ll Baker of Tennessee and House GGP leader John Rhodes of 
Arizona expressed backing for Vance's 
“ effo rts to n e g o tia te a 
SALT agreem ent.” 
Hours before Vance's d eparture, the 
Soviet news agency published an au th­ o ritative co m m e n ta ry s tre s s in g the opportunities open lo the s e c re ta ry during bis trip. 
While the co m m en tato r. Yuri K or­ nilov, repeated Moscow's com plaints alwiut the incompatibility of the A m er­ ican human rights position with good 
U .S .-Soviet re la tio n s , he in d ic a te d 
Russian leaders will not let their con­ cerns interfere with the SALT talks. 
A strategic arm s ag reem en t is the most im portant task facing the two superpow ers, the c o m m e n ta ry said. 
“ T h e re eau be no d o u b t th a t an agreement oil this question will have a very big significance,” Kornilov w rote. 
U.S. officials said th e r e a r e five elem ents to C a rte r’s co m p rehen sive approach to a treaty. F irst is a m ajor reduction in the num ber of m ajor nu­ clear weapons systems. 
At this point, the United States bus about 2,329 s t r a te g i c m is s ile s and bombers, while the Russian figure is estim ated at 2,669. The R ussian total would have to be reduced to the 2,499 level it the V ladivostok p a c t is fo r­ malized. 
No official will say for the record what Carter proposes as " a deep cu t,” but informed speculation sets the P re ­ sident's goal ut between 1,5o9 and 1,899 for each side, including the cruise and the Backfire. 
The other four points in the package contain restrictio ns on the m ultiple warheads, deployment of new types of w eapons, d e v e lo p m e n t of m o bile launchers and the cruise. 
The Soviets have rejected any move to defer the cruise issue. 

T he disabled are furious over what they see as a re tr e a t \>y P r e s id e n t 
Jim m y ('arter on his prom ises to help the nation’s 28 million handicapped. 
They are secretly planning a sit-in at the offices of Health, E ducation and 
Welfare Secretary Joseph Califano and his nine top regional assistants. 
The handicapped, in what would be their most forceful protest in history, are also considering blocking traffic with w heelchairs and vans. 
They attracted national attention in 
1973 when they ringed the Nixon White 
House with wheelchairs. 
Plans made 

S o m e tim e a f te r A p ril 4, u n le s s 
C a rte r acts on their d e m a n d s, blind m others, palsied children and medal- w e a rin g p a ra p le g ic s fro m V ie tn am plan to sw arm into the HEW' offices. 
A lre a d y , p la c a r d s a r e b e in g d e s ig n e d , c h a n ts w r it te n an d a netw ork of re c ru ite rs set up for the h a n d ic a p p e d in W a s h in g to n . New 
York, A tlanta, P hiladelphia, Boston, 
Chicago, Dallas, San Francisco. Seat­ tle and Denver. 
The anger among handicapped peo­ ple stem s in part from C a rte r's d r a ­ matic cam paign prom ise to m ake the d isabled “ active p a rtn e rs in our a t ­ tem pts to achieve ... full civil rig h ts.” 
C arter blasted the Ford a d m in istra ­ tion for r e f u s in g to e n f o r c e e q u a l r i g h ts la w s for h a n d ic a p p e d j o b ­ seekers. The disabled took C arter at his word and supported him by large majorities. 
Feel betrayed 

After Califano took over HEW. one of h is firs t a c tio n s w as to s ta ll even further by appointing a task force to stu dy th e e q u al rig h ts re g u la tio n s . 
Handicapped people felt they had been betrayed once again. 
D r. F r a n k Bowe, d i r e c t o r of th e 
A m erican Coalition of C itizen s with 
Disabilities, vented the handicapped's frustration in a private letter to Carter. 
“ Vast numbers of us endorsed your candidacy and worked vigorously for your elec tio n .” Bowe re m in d e d the president 
Bitterly describing C a rte r’s delays on equal employment opportunities for the d isa b le d , he said: “ We a re dis- 

Veterans* dividends moved up 

WASHINGTON (A F) — The Ye- terans Administration said Friday it is speeding up the issuance of insurance dividends to veterans within the next two weeks to give the national economy a $18o m il­ lion boost. 

VA Administrator Max Iceland said President Carter authorized him to accelera te the d ividend payments lo 2.1 million veterans of World War I. World War II and 
Korea. 

The dividends norm ally would have been paid on policy anniver­ sary d a tes throu gh ou t the r e ­ mainder of this year. Many veter­ ans whose anniversary dates have passed already have their checks in the normal fashion. 

Orland said the flow of annual dividends to the veterans who hold governm ent Insurance policies Is expected to be completed by April 
8. 

Sim ilar action has been taken eight tim es in the past 16 years, starting with P resident John F. 
Kennedy In 1961.

W atergate. Not because of a surrepti­ tious entry, but because of a national hysteria fomented by the media.

W atergate, Hunt said, “ was a gift to those who despised the policies of na­ tional strength.”

Maine phone bills cut 

AUGUSTA, Maine (A P) - It’s an old story: the telephone company asks for a rate increase and the Public Utilities 
Commission orders a change. But tins time, the custom ers are sm iling at the rate taking effect Saturday, the c o m ­ pany is not. 
"It blew our socks off when we got th is .” C on tinen tal T elep h o n e C o .’s 
Robert Niven said of the rate decrease 
— up to 45 per cent — ordered by the 
PUC on monthly bills for many of the company’s 24,o99 custom ers in Maine. 
But Mrs. R o bert B. Sw ain of A n ­ dover bailed the 22.2 p er cen t ra te reduction in the monthly bill for p a r­ ty-line service. 
‘‘If s the first good news I ve h e a rd .” she said in a telephone interview. “ It s just about the first thing that h asn 't gone up in price.” 
Hike sought 

Continental applied last year to the state Public Utilities Commission for a 
$51o,999 r a te in c r e a s e . I n s te a d , it wound up with an over-all 17 per cent cut in revenue, or about $929,999 less than it was expecting. 
E a r lie r th is w eek , th e 
M a in e 
Sup rem e J u d ic ia l C ourt re fu s e d to postpone the Saturday im plem entation of the lower rates, even though an ap ­ peal of the case is pending. 
Joan Goslin of the northern M aine com m unity of E ag le Lake said she couldn't believe the news, but added she knew what to do with the $1.95 a month she’ll be saving. 
"I U have to put the ex tra money toward the light bill, because th a t's gone up," the m other of four said. 

New rates 

Under the new ra le s, m o nth ly r e ­ sidential sing le-p arty bills for b asic serv ice will d e c lin e or r e m a in th e sam e for all but 19.7 per cent of the 
6,299 subscribers in that category. 

In Andover, 79 single-party residen ­ tial customers of Continental will get a 
44.7 iH*r cent reduction in their m on th ­ ly $8.59 telephone bill, which provides unlimited local calls only in the A n­ dover area. 

“ I w o u ld n ’t m in d p a y in g $8.59 a month if I eould have called (nearby) 
R um ford,” said M rs. R ic h a rd P lu n ­ d er. She said she expects to use the savings in the telephone bill to m ake more long-distance calls. 
At Fort Kent. Mrs. A rthur Pelletier said she, too. was glad about the drop in her rates from $6 to $4.35. 

"Don't worry about what I'M do with the money,” she said. “ I have to buy wood. oil and pay taxes." 

I 
Subsidiary 

T he u tility , a w holly o w n ed s u b ­ sidiary of Continental Telephone Corp , se rv e s 24,9o9 c u s t o m e r s in 48 e x ­ changes sea tier eh! throughout Maine. 

The PUC ru lin g re su lte d from an examination of the parent c o m p a n y ’s lax expenses and costs of a ttra c tin g stock and bond investm ents com pared with the level of th ose c h a r g e s a s ­ sessed to Continental Telephone Co of 
Maine 

The PUC said the tax paym ents and cost of capital were o verstated. C on­ tinental says the com m ission action was ille g a l.

Sheriff’s deputy one of 2 charged in cattle theft 

By BILL CUNNINGHAM 
EXPRESS-NEWS STATE EDITOR 

A Bexar County deputy sheriff was one of two men charged with theft of cattle Friday. 
Arrested Friday on charges filed in 
Hondo were Joe Paez, 4o. the deputy. and Gilbert Lara Ortega, 43, a packing 

 company employe. Both live in San 
Antonio. P aez was assig n ed to the sheriff’s civil section. 
They w ere placed in the B exar 
County Jail, pending bond hearings. 
Jim DeLesdernier, inspector for the 
Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers 
Assn., said the investigation leading to the arrests was spearheaded by Bexar 

County Sheriff's Lt. Kenneth Bilhartz. 
Medina County Sheriff Butch Camp- sey, DeLesdernier and Murray Potts, another TSCRA inspector, assisted in the case. 
The charges involved five head of cattle taken from the place of Marvin 
Ashley in south Bexar County and sold at the Medina Livestock Auction Co. in 

Hondo. 
The investigation started last Sun­ day, and four of the cattle were reco­ vered. 
DeLesdernier said the prompt reco­ very of the cattle came as a result of the fire branding to indicate owner­ ship. 
Edmond Talk, brand inspector for 

 the TSCRA, found the cattle through the brands. 
D eLesdernier returned to San An­ tonio this week after solving the theft of a $15,ooo race horse. The horse was recovered in Nuevo Laredo, Mex. 
Alvin Jo h n so n , a B exar County sheriff’s investigator, reported Friday that cattle rustlers and horse thieves 

 have stepped up their activities in 
Bexar County. 
He said the biggest increase is in the number of horse theft cases, pointing out 17 head had been reported stolen this year. Thefts of horses were rare in previous years, he said. 
Johnson said 18 head of cattle also had been reported stolen this year. 
Property insurance prem ium s to go up in San Antonio 

JAKE VALEN ZU ELA 
. . . Easter Seal child 
Easter Seal telethon to kick off 

The Easter Seal Telethon kicks off at 
8:3o p.m. Saturday, bringing 2o hours of entertainm ent by top television, movie and stage stars on behalf of crippled children and adults. 
National host Michael Landen will have a line-up of celebrities, including the entire casts of Laverne and Shirley, 
Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, Bust­ ing Loose, Roots and some Broadway shows. 
The local segment of the telethon, broadcast on KSAT-TV, will be han­ dled by weatherman Judd Ashmore and Jerry Franklin, KBUC radio news director. 
Entertainer and singer Vikki Carr will make a local appearance on the telethon. 
San Antonio Easter Seal supporters will be able to m ake donations at 
W indsor P a rk M all, W onderland 
Shopping City, McCreless Shopping 
City, Valley-Hi Mall Shopping Center and KSAT-TV station. 
Contributors will receive discounts and coupons from McDonald’s, Pizza 
Hut or Santikos Theaters. 
Nuclear waste briefing set 

AUSTIN. 
(A P) — F e d e ra l representatives are scheduled to brief state officials W ednesday on th e ir plans to study Texas for possible nu­ clear waste disposal sites, the Gover­ nor’s Energy Advisory Council said 
Friday. 
In December, the U.S. Energy Re­ search and Development A dm inistra­ tion (ERDA) announced that Texas was among 13 states with favorable 
.geologic conditions for the location of the first six w aste d isp o sal site s planned for the nation. 
Salt domes in East Texas and two areas of bedded salt in the Panhandle are designated by the ERDA for test drilling and detailed geologic studies. 
The ERDA plans to select two sites in the U.S. by 1978 for completion in 
1985. The sites under consideration require geologic formations capable of isolating radioactive wastes from the en v iro n m en t for se v era l th o u sa n d 

By DICK MERKEL 
CHIEF, EXPRESS-NEWS CAPITOL BUREAU 
AUSTIN — San Antonians can expect to pay slightly higher property insurance rates after 
July I, despite a state-wide rate cut ordered here Friday by the 
State Insurance Board. 

The board ordered a 2.8 per cent re­ duction in property insurance rates which will produce an e s tim a te d decrease of $18.9 million in premiums for insurance buyers on a state-wide basis. 
However, because of the higher like­ lihood of such things as hailstorm s, tornados and hurricanes, property in­ surance rates in some areas are ac­ tually going up. 
In the ca se of San Antonio, p r e ­ miums for the standard homeowners one-year policy for $25,ooo coverage on a briFk veneer home wifi increase 4.2 per cent, from $179 to $187 after July I. 
Net result 

The net result in San Antonio is a $3 in crease p er y ear for sta n d ard ho­ meowners plus fire and extended co- 
Cave-in 

 verage. 
Across the board, fire and extended coverages will drop state-wide. 
Increases in homeowners policies will result in Austin, Corpus Christi, 
Dallas, El Paso. Fort Worth, Houston and San Angelo, in addition to San 
Antonio. 
The new rates were announced at a formal moeting of the State Insurance 
Board Friday morning. 
Chairman Joe Christie said the in­ surance com panies had asked for a 
$44.5 million rate increase. 
‘Not justified’ 

“ But the evidence presented at our hearings indicates to us that, not only is a rate increase not justified, but a rate decrease is called for,” Christie said. 
, 

“ For evidence the current rates are more than equitable,” he added, “ you need look no fu rth er than a list of companies offering coverage at rates below those set by the Board of Insur­ ance. 
“ Eighty per cent of the homeowners policies written in 1975,” he concluded, 
- ‘were based on rates less than those set by the board, and this trend con­ 

 tinued in 1976.” 
However, there was almost im m e­ diate indication the insurance com ­ panies may consider taking the rate issue to court. 
An industry spokesman said after the meeting he would consult with the companies to see if a lawsuit against the board is to be pursued.

 citations outrage 
Munoz 

San Antonio labor leader Henry 
“The Fox” Munoz has fired off tele­ grams to U.S. Secretary of Labor Ray 
M arshall and Gov. Dolph Briscoe charging ditchdiggers lives are appar­ ently worth only $1,ooo a head. 

“ I’m indignant. I am so upset I can hardly speak and for me, that’s really hot,” Munoz declared Friday after finding two San Antonio contractors had been cited for unsafe job condi­ tions, an allegation the contractors may appeal. 

Munoz also fired off a Mailgram to 
Mayor Lila Cockrell accusing her of wanting “ to sweep the cave-in deaths under the rug.” 
Mayor 

The labor leader told Mrs. Cockrell as mayor she has a duty and moral obligation to see justice is done. 

Munoz’s union local has endorsed 
Dr. Jose San Martin for mayor in the 
April 2 city election. 

The citations by the federal Occupa­ tional Safety and Health Administra­ tion following the deaths of four Mexi­ can alien ditchdiggers in two separate cave-ins last month. 

“ And for this (deleted) to say in print these bureaucrats equate a hu­ man life with a traffic ticket is just unpardonable,” Munoz snapped. 

Herbert Kurtz, area director of the agency, earlier said, “ ll s just like a traffic tic k et...Y o u ’ve got so m any days to appeal it..or pay it.”

Growth sketch backed by Coft" 

T he 
G re a te r 
San 
Antonio 
Chamber of Commerce came out on the side of the city-approved resi­ dential growth sketch Friday after last-m inute changes w ere m ade 
Thursday. 

Bill O’Connell, chairm an of the cham ber’s urban affairs com­ m ittee, said removal of dots and squares from the growth sketch map helped make the sketch more workable. 

The map projects where the city should plan for residential growth for 3oo,ooo new city residents by the year 2ooo. 

It is the first step in the City 
P lanning C om m ission’s p rep a ra ­ tion of a City Master Plan. 

O’Connell also said City Council’s instructions to the commission will allow for better input from the bu­ siness community into the m aster plan. 

“ I think all sides won Thursday,” 
O’Connell said. “ The builders, the business com munity and the citi­ zens all got their way. 

“ I think the c h a m b e r w as r e ­ sponsible for everyone to be on the winning side rather than to have all losers.” 

Input from the b u sin e ss c o m ­ munity for the rest of the m aster plan work will help the City Plan­ ning Commission determ ine fiscal impact on school districts and bu ­ siness marketing, O’Connell said. 
W est wills headed for 
April l l probate date 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS 
LOS ANGELES - Beverly Hills millionaire Sandra Ilene W est’s two conflicting wills, one naming San An-' tonic attorney Fred Semaan as major beneficiary, will be presented April ll for possible probate in Superior Court. 

Mrs. West, 37, died March IO. A ruling in the death is pending. 

One of the wills, handwritten in 1972, directs major beneficiary Sol West III of Comfort, her brother-in-law, to pro­ vide for her burial in a lace nightgown 
'in her favorite car, a Ferrari, next to her husband at Alamo Masonic Ceme­ tery in San Antonio. 
Mrs. West signed the second will in 
Semaan’s office Nov. 23, 1976. 

Semann said he marked the will voi but Mrs. West refused to accept the voiding. 
Until a will is approved, the county has asked Superior Court to handle the 
$2.5 million estate. 
The will naming Semaan beneficiary was filed Tuesday by San Antonio attorney Gary Howard. Howard was named executor of that will.

Widows file suit against contractor 

Agency 

The agency said Thursday the F a r­ rell Construction Co. had been cited for a civil violation calling for a fine of 
$3,ooo for conditions which allegedly caused the deaths of three workers 
March 8. 

T eleco m m u n ic a tio n s Service Co. was cited, calling for a civil fine of 
$6oo, from an incident which killed one workman March 7. 

Munoz has called on city officials to pass a 
I safety ordinance to pre­ vent further ditch cave- ins. Some officials, how­ ever, have said the fe­ deral agency was h a n ­ dling the situation ade­ quately. 
“The lives of Mexicans com e ch e a p ,’’ Munoz said, and disclosed he had fired off the tele grams following personal telephone calls to Mar- 
I shall and Briscoe after the announcement. 
Ihis isn’t the end of this, I promise you,” he added 
Munoz is b u sin e ss agent of the A m erican 
Federation of 
S tate. 
County and M unicipal 
Employees local 1299 

Widows of two Mexican nationals killed in a drainage ditch cave in 
March 8 in Brackenridge Park filed a damage suit Friday against the project contractor. 
The suit filed in 73rd District Court is on behalf of the widows and children of Telesforo Cruz Hernandez, 56, and 
Constantino Lopez, 3o. 
Also killed in the Brackenridge Golf 
Course drainage ditch cave-m was 
Haul Gonzalez Medina, 36, of 225 
Briggs Ave., although his heirs are not 
. a party to the lawsuit. 
All three were Mexican nationals. 
Federal officials, following an investi­ gation of the job site, this week cited 
Farrell Construction Co., the contrac­ tor, for failing to erect supportive shoring on the walls of the drainage ditch before workers were sent in. 
Civil fine 
The citation could mean a civil fine of $3,ooo for Farrell, although an ap­ peal can be filed. 
The company won the city contract to handle the Pershing-Catalpa drain­ age project, including the portion through the park, with its low bid ear­ lier this year. 
The suit claims Cruz Hernandez and 

T r a ffic (H o p p e r 

Buena Vista Street wljl be cltsed from 6 a m. until evening darkness 
Saturday only between P ecos and 
Santa Rosa streets. - 

Lopez were killed because of the com­ pany’s alleged gross negligence in al­ lowing the men into the ditch without taking proper precautions. 
Suit 
The suit states Cruz H ernandez’s widow, M rs. Concepcion G onzalez 
Hernandez, has five children and Mrs. 
Elida Lara Lopez, widow of Constan­ tino Lopez, has ll children. They have each asked $1 million in damages. 
The men w ere killed w hen the w ill Is of the ditch they were excavating col­ lapsed and buried them, according to the suit. Dr. Ruben Santos, Bexar 
County medical exam iner, ruled the deaths accidental asphyxiation by suf­ focation. 

GAO wants nuclear agency involved 

WASHINGTON (AP) — Congression­ al auditors said Friday the Nuclear 
• Regulatory Commission should In* in­ cluded in any reorganization of the federal energy bureaucracy. 

The 
General 
Accounting 
Office laid President Carter’s energy reor­ ganization bill fails to come to grips with many nuclear issues by proposing to leave the NRC intact while consoli­ dating other energy agencies. 

The GAO recommended formation of a new energy health and safety regu­ latory organization which would in­ clude NRC.

BRUSSELS. Belgium (A P ) — U.S. 
Defense Secretary Harold Brown and major American allies agreed F riday to set up an airborne system to watch for a Soviet attack on Western Europe. 
But British Defense Secretary Fred 
M ulley r e s e rv e d his g o v e r n m e n t ’s right to decide whether to use its own p lane, th e N im ro d , w h ich it is developing for su rv e illa n ce b ut not battle control. 

The United States and the others are planning to use a fleet of 27 converted 
Boeing 7o7s expected to cost some $2.5 billion. The planes will be equipped with special r a d a r th a t w ould look hundreds of miles into Soviet territory for tro o p m o v e m e n ts and concentrations. 
The planes would also serve as a ir ­ 

 borne command posts, w here NATO generals would direct com bat o p e ra ­ tions. 
The announcement came at the end of a meeting of defense chiefs from 13 members of the North Alantic Treats 
Organization, who said they agreed to work out cost sharing for the Airborne 
W arn in g and C ontrol S y s te m — 
AWACS — as rapidly as possible and try to get the program in operation by 
July I. 
_ , 
Brown told reporters that the United 
States would increase its share of the costs from 28 per cent to 33 per cent 
Before the meeting, some West G er­ man officials privately threatened to balk at the costly system because of 
W ashington’s relu ctance to build a com m on U .S .-G erm an b a ttle t a n k around Bonn’s new Leopard ll tank.

Bell holds ERA ratification can’t be withdrawn 

OOMPH.ED HOM WlRt St BVIC is 
WASHINGTON - Atty. 
(ion. Griffin has Ri­ ven President Carter his official opinion that states cannot withdraw their ratification of the equal rights amendment. 

Karen Dot row. presi­ dent of the National Or­ g anization of Women, said Bell told her of his support for ERA during a m eetin g 
F rid a y . 
A spokesman for Bell said later the memo was “a legal opinion rendered at the request of the White 
House.” 

Thirty-five of the 38 states needed for ratifi­ cation by March 22, 1979 have ratified the EHA. but Idaho. Tennessee and 
N ebraska subsequently withdrew their approval. 

C ongress or the S u ­ preme Court ultimately may decide if ratification 
.by the states can be res­ cin d ed . 

NATIONAL 
DIGEST 

Cuban talks businesslike 
WASHINGTON - The 
State D e p a rtm e n t d e ­ scribes the opening of direct talks between the 
United States and Cuba as businesslike but re ­ fused to sa y w h eth er issues other than fishing rights an d m a ritim e b o u n d aries w ere co­ vered. 
The talks, held Thurs­ day at an undisclosed location in New York Ci­ ty. were the first such contact between the two countries in 18 years.

Appeals Ccmrl 
KOs FCC rule 

WASHINGTON - The 
U.S. Appeals Court has knocked down the Feder­ al Communications Com­ mission’s rules regulat­ ing w hat m o v ies and sports events cable tele­ vision m ay offer subscribers for pay by the program. 
The court said the commission may be able lo come up with accepta­ ble rules if it can state clearly the harm which its regulations seek to remedy and its reason for supposing this harm ex­ ists. The pay by the pro­ gram practice involves a ch a rg e for in d iv id u al programs in addition to monthly subscriber fees paid by customers.

San Antonio EXPRESS N E W S — Saturday March 26 I 9 77 
Page. 5-A 
U.S. to push N-fusion, drop breeder reactor 

JAM ES SCHLESINGER 
. . . nuclear energy 

WASHINGTON (AU) - P resident 
C a rte r's chief energy a d v i s e r a n ­ nounced Friday that the United States will not look to plutonium and breeder reactor plants as a source of nuclear energy. 
Jam es K Sehlesinger said the ad ­ ministration instead will rely on uran­ ium-powered plants already in use and emphasize research on nuclear fusion. a type of nuclear pow er not yet developed. 
Although hinted at previously by 
President Carter, no adm inistration figure had declared the switch away from the nuclear policy followed by 

Schlesinp e r m o d e the nu- nouncement at a round ta­ ble discussion on e n e rg y attended b v 19 ordinary ci­ tizens 

 two previous administrations 
Al a roundtable discussion with bi ordinary citizens invited to give their views on energy policy. Sehlesinger said. "For the imm ediate future we will not be using recycled plutonium." 
One reason for the change, Scil In­ s u r e r said, is to diminish "the pos­ 

 sibility of the sp re a d of n u c le a r weapons ” 
Plutonium is produced from spent nuclear fuel for use in breeder reac­ tors. the type in which J a p a n and w estern E u ro p ean c o u n trie s have heavily invested. 
Plutonium 
Critics of plutonium say the fuel can bt' used by terrorists to m ake cru d e nuclear weapons. E nvironm entalists say breeder reactor plants are likely to be unsafe. 
Cancellation of the breeder reactor program would mean killing a $3o(1 million plutonium plant-

 alien hiring 

SPECIAl to THI FXPBfSS N e w s 

WASHINGTON - U S. 
Hep. Bob K ru eg er r e ­ ported F rid ay the De­ p artm en t of L abor is planning public hearings in 
San 
Antonio th is spring on a proposed re­ gulation revision on em ­ ployment of aliens for temporary farm jobs. 
San Antonio is one of six cities selected for hearings. 

The other citie s, s e ­ lected because of the sig­ nificant number of U.S. migrant farmworkers or foreign workers, are: 
D enver, 
Colo.; 
Belle 
Glade, Fla.; Springfield, 
Mass ; Plattsburg. N Y. and Martinsburg, VV. Va. 
The Department of La­ bor. a c c o rd in g to 
Krueger, is suspending any plans to implement the proposed regulations originally published Jan. 
23 until after the h ear­ ings. In s te a d , the d e ­ p artm en t will o p erate under existing regula­ tions. 

Goal 

"T h e goal of these hearings," Krueger said, 
“ is to assist the Depart­ ment of Labor in obtain­ ing more detailed infor­ mation on the im p lica­ 

 tions of any new regula­ tions 
‘‘Anyone who is con­ nected with the issue of tem po r a r y employ rn cut of alien farm w orkers is invited to offer testimony or statements for the re­ cord” 
Hearing dates and lo­ cations have not yet been scheduled, b u t will be announced in the Federal 
Register as they become known.

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S— 
S a t u r d a y March 26 1977 
Candidates clash over tim e at work 

By J A M E S M C C R O R Y 

Councilman Glen Hart­ man and developer Jim 
Dement clashed Friday over how much time a councilman should spend working at City Hall 
Hartman insisted the job calls for long hours 

 and Dement was equally adamant that isn t so. 
The clash came at a meeting featuring candi­ dates from Districts 8, 9 and IO sponsored by the 
Bexar County Republican 
Women’s Club. 
There were so many candidates on hand the 

 club m e m b e rs sa n d ­ wiched lunch in between the presentations. 
Dement, saying he is grateful to God he isn t a politician, assured the club he will not put full tim e into city council duties on grounds it isn t necessary. 

Sit m any candidates showed up* club members sandwiched lunch in between presentations 

 people m ad e so m any p ro m ise s at so m any m e etin g s,” he told the women.

Crime control 
The fourth candidate in 
District 9 speaking was 
Roy B endele J r ., who took a leave of absence from Control Data Corp., to take the plunge into politics. 
Bendele stressed the need for stronger crim e control, saying the city has 14o police patrolling 
3,ooo miles of streets. 
He said that is below the FBI recom m ended ratio. Bendele said he has been robbed th re e times in three years and never was any of his merchandise recovered.

M onfrey didn’t include 
COPS in his schedule 

Mayoral candidate John Monfrey not only failed to appear at a Candidates 
Accountability Night sponsored by 
Communities Organized for Public 
Service, but hadn’t intended going rn the first place. 
Monfrey’s schedule of appearances for this week, prepared a week ago. didn't include the COPS meeting on the list. 
COPS held its mayoral candidates* meeting Thursday night, and the other two m ajor candidates. Mayor Lila 

Cockrell and Dr. Jose San Martin, appeared. 
Monfrey’s absence angered COPS, leading jcops p re sid e n t B eatrice 
Gallego to ask: 
“ Is this the type of man we want at 
City Hall, one who will not be there when he says he will?” 
Monfrey’s schedule listed six ap­ p ea ran ce s 
T h u rs d ay . 
He was scheduled, and did appear, before 
Voters Organized In Community Effort 
(VOICE) from 7-8 p.m. in Valley-Hi. 

 where the money is com­ ing from to fulfill all the promises made. 

Steen said the city has neglected its su rface water problem and said the city should build the 
Cibolo R eserv o ir so it will have its own water supply. 
Paul Foley, another 

District IO candidate and a retired colonel, said he can represent the district because, for many years. he was a part of the de­ cision-making process. 
He said he would be a fulltime councilman.

Gunman surrenders, frees four hostages 

NKW YO RK (A P ) — A gunman tm-rl four hostages and surrendered peaceful^ Friday night after holding them for just over five hours in a demand for $5oo,ooo to convert a Har­ lem building into a Moslem mosque. 
No ransom was paid and none of the hostages was hurt at the hands of the gunman, Luquam Abdush-Shahid, de­ scribed by police as “ very cool and calm.” 

Abdush-Shahid. HO, wa* booked on a charge of first-degree kidnaping and two counts of criminal possession of a weapon. 
Police had earlier said there would bt1 no kidnaping charge but that later proved not to be true. 
Abdush-Shahid will be arraigned on 

 the charges Saturday morning, police said. 
In an interview with radio station 
WINS after he surrendered. Abdush- 
Shahid said he did not know what would happen to him but said he wanted officials to make sure his family had a nice place to stay. 

The hostage situation developed during a meeting among city housing officials with a com m unity group planning to renovate certain Harlem tenements and a lawyer for the bank providing the financing. 

As the meeting was under way, after 
5 p.m., Abdush-Shahid, who was sit­ ting in on the meeting, drew a pistol 

 and told the others he was taking them hostage. 
One of the hostages. John Pearson, said at first nobody believed 
Abdush-Shahid. He qouted the gunman as saying, “ I'm not kidding,” and the hostage situation began It ended hours later, with the gunman voicing the hope that the real estate deal would go forward 
A fifth hostage had been freed from the ninth for office earlier in the even­ ing. 
Abdush-Shahid emerged from the room at 1o:35 p.m., the arm of Lt. 
Frank Bol/, head of a police negotiat­ ing team, around his shoulder. The hostages, in shirtsleeves, followed, seemingly calm. 

TV cam eras 

 lo m ove into 
W hite House 

N E W YORK TIMES SERVICE 

NEW YO RK — President Carter has agreed to allow the cameras of 
NBC News into the W hite House to follow his activities for a tele­ vision special to be entitled. “ A 
Day in the Life of the President.” 

John Chancellor will serve as reporter, and NRC is to have full editorial control over the content. 
The program will be taped one day during the week of April I and will be televised on April 14 at 8 p.m. as a one-hour special. 

NRC News presented a similar program with President Nixon in 
January 1972, just before Nixon's re-election campaign opened.

STA TE BUD GET 

Continued from Page I V 

 battled over in the House Public Edu­ cation Committee, is carrying a price tag of $7oo million 
Teacher retirement, sure to be a battleground in the House, is ear­ marked for $2o7 million as it stands in committee right now 
E lim in atio n of the sales tax on newspapers and magazines, whieh passed the House Thursday en route to the Senate, is a $34 million revenue loser to the state. 
And on, and on, until you reach $1.3 billion. 
State agencies, either cut their funding, held at status quo, or given small increases by the E B B , have all had their days before various com­ mittees. 
Restore cuts 

As a result, these committees have sought to restore cuts or increase bud­ gets with the resulting $916 million handed the Appropriations Committee. 
And. to compound the problem, the committee has already given tentative j approval to some of these recommen­ dations. 
For example, there’s the $4 million tentatively okayed for the state Animal 
Health Commission to fund a new pro-' gram of calfhood vaccination for bru­ cellosis. 

DEFENSE 

Continued from Page I V 

 from the U.S. economy where it is needed for capital investment. 
The administration bill involves $5 billion in funding for various multi­ national institutions like the World 
Bank, Inter-American Development 
Bank and Asian Development Bank. 
Gonzalez said he shared the concern of some com m ittee members that much of the infusion of funds might he used by the third world recipients sim ply to make loan repayments, rather than for development goals 
The fact some of th** developing na­ tions have debt burdens they cannot service is a matter for concern, said 
Gonzalez, observing the situation raises memories of the German bank­ ing crisis of the late 192os. 

Add to that $2.7 million to increase research funds for the Texas Agricul­ tural Experim ent Station, and you have a $o.7 million total in one area alone. 
The Texas Railroad Commission has already received a tentative nod on its request for $2.6 million to increase the regulation of natural gas utility pro­ grams on top fo the agency's requested amount. 
Higher education has seen its bud­ getary battering somewhat softened to the tune of $76.8 million in restored cuts. 
And on. and on again, as you run the adding tape up to $916 million in one big hurry. 
The Appropriations Committee heard a warning from Clayton that unless some of the increased budget requests were not held up until the total picture was sharper, the panel was in trouble. 
The wisdom of Clayton’s words were never clearer than on Friday when the 
House Appropriations Committee members were told to “ pray over it.” 
JU N TA 

Continued from Page LA base in Kanchanaburi province. 65 miles west of Bangkok. 
“ The army, navy and air force are still supporting the government under 
Prime Minister Tamp Kraivixien,” the television statement said, “ and the government will take proper action against the m ilitary junta for the security of the people and the country. 
The supreme commanders of the armed forces, navy and air force arc- holding un urgent meeting to cope with the- situation.” 
Last October’s coup was led by Adm. 
San gad Chalawyu. and Sangad’s 
National Reform Council picked the 
49-year-old Tanin to head the new military-backed government. 
The junta broadcast said it seized power In c ause the Tanin government could not solve economic and social problem s and because conditions in the country were “ deteriorating.” The broadcast said the coup occurred at 
5:59 a m. 
The junta’s announcement said it would continue m artial law- in 
Thailand to maintain peace and order. 
S.A. job situation 

I im p r o v e s ! 

San Antonio's 6.8 per! cent unemployment ratej is expected to fall to 6 per cent by May, Texas Em ­ ployment Commission offic ials said Friday. 
Construction jobs are expected to produce much of the im prove­ ment. 
San Antonio’s total employment was 353. HK) in 
Feb ruary, 
T E C offic ials said. 
This was virtually the same number at work during Jan u ary. How­ ever, less people were looking for work last month — 25.OUI) com ­ pared with 3o,9o(1 in Fe­ bruary 1976 
There is a great de­ mand for registered nurses, machinists, se­ cretaries. stenographers and journeyman electri­ cians. 
The commission also said there was a healthy increase of 1,1oo manu­ facturing jods over F e ­ bruary 1976. 
Wage and salary em­ ployes have shown the greatest 12-month im ­ provement, increasing to 
328,7oo. or a significant rise of 4,75o

Desui. an­ nounced the Harm's of his cabinet ministers F r i­ day. apparently resolv­ ing a leadership crisis.

ISLA M A BA D , Pakis­ tan — The government arrested chief opposition leaders Friday on the eve of a scheduled national strike demanding the re­ signation of Prime Min­ ister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. 
Opposition sources said soldiers fired into a 

 crowd of anti-govern­ ment demonstrators in 
Multan, 275 miles south of the capital, and killed nine persons. There was no immediate official confirmation or denial of tho report

EDITORIALS 

W illia m J Reddell

M a n a g in g E d ito r 

Hartman’s research saves city a fortune 

R e a listic planning p roce­ dures by City Council were rati­ fied this week as the sound way to go. 
C ity Council, under leader­ ship of Councilman (Hen Hart­ man and his subcommittee on policies and planning, refused to allow the City Water Board to ra ter into a contract with the 
Guadalupe-Bianco River Auth­ ority for tilt' purchase of water from Ci-BRA. 
The contract called for pay­ ment by ( AVB. starting when the contract becam e effective, of about $8oo,ooo a year for water, whether it was used or not. 
Hartman led the fight against the contract. CWB trustees pressed hard for the contract. 
On April 2H. the Texas Water 
Rights C om m ission will hear a r g u m e n t s to see w hether it should cancel G-BRA's right to water in Canyon Reservoir. The possibility is that G-BR.Vs right to water, apparently illegally held at the m o m e n t, will be challenged by other interests. 

Whatever litigation may evolve has to be settled before a con­ tract for sale* of the water could be negotiated, in any event. 
Thus, San Antonio has been spared the prospect of expensive arrangements for surface water that are now on shaky legal ground. 
Hartman is entitled to his large share of the credit for saving the city from that situa­ tion Council is entitled to credit for its careful examination of the4 Hartman research and re­ commendations. The planning process, properly implemented, proved its value. 

At the time, we noted the con­ tract had been negotiated with startling ease. G-BRA had ada­ mantly opposed San Antonio's proposal to take C anyon Reser­ voir water earlier. When CWB was able to make the deal with virtually no debate and with ob- viously-easy negotiations, the need to examine conditions be­ came apparent. 

Bom bing o f club 

CCA board needs safety panel to keep tax process on track 

R e s t r u c tu r in g of the City- 
County A p p raisal Board r e ­ mains a live topic for the City 
Council and County C o m m i s ­ sioners Court. 
One suggestion, by City Fin­ ance Director Carl White, d e ­ s e r v e s ser io u s consideration. 
White proposes to create a coor­ dinating board which would be the CCA board’s technical re­ view staff. 
T he CCA operation is still plagued by occasional attempts by the director, who is inexper­ ienced in tax m a tters, .to c ir ­ c u m v e n t law fu lly -defined procedures. There have been e x a m p l e s of the CCA office sending new appraisal figures to a tax office after all appraisal and review work has been done. 
There is legally-d efin ed procedure for review and appeal '•-compromise the of appraisal and a s s e s s m e n t 
‘c e s s . work There is also legally-de­ fined method for correcting er­ rors. 
Errors have to be corrected by an appropriate board of er­ rors. They shouldn’t be subject lo change, once the appraisal 

 and assessing is complete, by any inappropriate method or by any unauthorized person or board. 
The CCA staff is working toward an acceptable level of professional competence. Such competence assumes an under­ standing of legally-permissable procedures. 

The cr itica l area for p r e ­ serving progress made so far by joint tax services by the city and county is p ro fe ssio n a l a p p r ­ aisals, which are the basis for fair treatment for all taxpayers. 

County A sse sso r -C o lle c to r 
Ben Shaw is reviewing irregu­ larities and is sending them to the district attorney. A grand jury has d etailed p r a c tic e s, sin c e la rg ely co r r e c te d , that taxation pro- 

A te ch nica l coordin atin g board could be a useful s a f e ­ guard against abuse of the sys­ tem through c a r e l e s s n e s s or otherwise. There is evid en ce that such review is a minimum requirement at this point. 
Trade center has place to root 

A proposal by a private group to build a trade e e lie r on part of the old arsenal property is an encouraging development. 
If the project is completed as see m s possible, it would be a splendid e x a m p le of private enterprise taking advantage of a w ell-defined opportunity to build on an established trend. 
The Mexican Trade Fair is e s ­ tablished and successful beyond first expectations. The Mexican sponsors and the Governor of 
Texas have expressed the desire to see a permanent lair. A trade 

 center would complement those desires. 

The arsenal site is ideally lo­ cated. Private sponsors would give a trade center permanence with a minimum of uncertainty between fairs until a center is fully developed and operating. 

A center would be a source for jobs and it could be the pivot for trade with M exico and other countries in this hemisphere. 
The idea has a solid place to take root and San Antonians will welcome the development.

'Them without capital punished’ 

Sir. A prevalent m yth is that the present po st-F u rm an T ex as Capital 
Murder statute removed the historic arbitrary and discrim inatory nature of the death penalty. A review of the official Texas Judicial Council’s Capi­ tal M urder Study, covering the period from Ju n e , 1973. through F ebruary , 
1976, shows the opposite. 

During the interim of the study, 73 capital m u rder defendants w ere tried in Texas, 42 of whom w ere represented by court appointed attorneys, and 31 by retained counsel The conviction rate for those with the appointed counsel was 93 per cent (39 convictions out of 42 cases), and those convicted received the* death penalty at a rate of 79 per c ent (31 out of 39). Those able to retain counsel were convicted at a rate of 63 per cent (2o out of 31), and once convicted received the death penally at a rate of 33 per cent (ll out of 2o), 

Legal, moral, ethical and philoso­ phical considerations a sid e, capital punishment continues to translate into 
"th e m without the cap ital gets the* punishm ent." 
Tom Flower

Muzzle mi 

WASHINGTON - Maybe the best solution is just to buy ICN. 
Ambassador Andrew Young a muzzle. 
Young and Ills handpic ked gifted n e w c o m e rs at our m issio n to the 
United Nations ut first confined their unfortunate blurts and gaffes to C S foreign and dom estic, political and social, policies. 
E arlier this month, however, in the course of another of his wide ranging interviews. Young forecast, if indeed he did not incite, racial mutiny by the 
C S. A rm y should the* African policy of the governm ent not suit him. 
W hat Y oung told a g ro u p of co­ porters was this: "A n arm ed forces that is 3o per cent black isn’t going to fight on the side of South Africa " 
‘Civil war’ 
B esides p red ictin g “ civil w ar at ho m e," the above was the reason the a m b a s s a d o r g a v e why the U n ited 
S ta te s, in his view , could nut and should not provide m ilitary help to 
South Africa against som e eventual offensive by black African countries 
It was quite c le a r that Young r e ­ lishes the thought of a politically un­ 

 reliable* black minority in the arm ed forces holding som e kind of a veto over U.S. foreign policy. 
Young, to be? sure, was off-base un his num bers. The arm ed forces as a whole are 16 9 |H*r cent black, not 3o. 
Even the Army, with the highest fi­ gure am ong the four services, is only 
24 per cent black 
Constituency 
Y oung and his d o m e s tic c o n s ti­ tuency (which is also, to a large ex­ te n t, P r e s id e n t C a r te r s c o n s t i ­ tuency) would bt* outraged if a white 
( abt not-level m em b er of the ad m in ­ istration had asserted that the Army, which is 76 per c en t w hite, m ight refuse to fight side by side with black in v a d e r s or fa c tio n s s e e k in g to overthrow the governm ent of South 
Africa. 
Y et, sta n d in g (he a m b a s s a d o r ’s proposition on Us head, that is what you come up with Of course, either proposition is equally wrong. 

G en. D aniel J a m e s , the (ugliest ranking black U.S. officer, put the point squarely iii perspective recent­ ly when he said: 
" C m a g eneral and the fact that 

 be solution 

I’m black is incidental. I’m not a black general, I’m a general of the 
United States Air Force, lf our au th ­ ority, the President, dec ides that it is tune to commit our troops, and Con­ g r e s s so w ills, I go w h e re w e ’re com m itted " 
- 
A politicized regular Army incapa­ ble of or unwilling to enforce w hat­ ever policies the commander-in-chief and governm ent decide on is, besides being a disgrace to itself, a menace* to c o n stitu tio n a l lib erty and g o v e rn ­ ment. 
T he e n tire Anglo-Saxon c o n stitu ­ tional theory we inherited from Bri­ tain is thai of an utterly apolitical m ilita r y in w h ich we go to g re a t lengths to keep soldiers out of politics and politics away from soldiers. 

The least that might Im* expected of

Yet that precisely is what Young did. 
T here is another good reason why 
Young ought tu have kept his mouth shut. 
T h e a r m e d fo rc e s, w hose over- th e-bourd record on racial ju stic e stands com parison with any institu­ tion iii our society, are only now lie- ginning to pull them selves together after a historically unparalleled d e ­ c a d e of m u tin y , s a b o ta g e aud sedition, much of it racial in origin. 
Indiscretion 
It is in no way to condom* Young’s indiscretion to suggest th a t, insofar as some U S. blacks in uniform are concerned, his reading of their pus- sible behavior might just In* right 
During the seven years 1968-1975, the four services had at least 33 m u ­ tinies. To put this figure bi context, during nearly two centuries between 

1773 and 1968, the A rm y and Navy logged only 14 m utinies of record 

In all probability, th e total ut 33 recent mutinies m entioned abov* is far below the actual n u m b er since all se rv ic e s went to g r e a t le n g th s to minimize, m isre p re se n t and w here 
(Risible withhold inform ation on this d elicate and d eeply e m b a r r a s s in g subject. 

E ig h te e n of th e 
33 m u t in i e s involved explosive racial violence on the part uf black m u tin eers aboard warships, and on A rm y, Marine and 
Air Force liases at hom e and abroad 
Background 
It is against tins unhappy back­ ground that people, mostly ordinary people, have been calling in to the 
Pentagon to express their anxiety over Andrew Young s o ffh an d , in ­ flamm atory dictum. 
That — based on past misbehavior 
<*f some blacks in the a rm e d forces — 
Young might well know what in* is ta lk in g about is the b e st p o ssib le reason why anyone calling him self an am bassador should understand when to keep quiet. 

Carter using press forum 

WASHINGTON — President 
Carter has held four news con­ ferences since his inauguration, each of them making less news than the one before. 
The novelty is w e a rin g off and he k n o w s it, but he will continue to hold one every fortnight, for he has other purposes. 
H»* is not a lw a y s tr y in g to m a k e news. Som etim es he is using the news conference to send a m essage to other governm ents or to Congress. 
Sometimes he is teaching or preach­ ing about th)* problem s before him, hut always he is try in g to restore confi­ dence at home and abroad in the inte­ grity and authority of his new ad m in­ istration 
Illustration 
His latest m eeting with th)* reporters il l u s t r a t e s b o th th e s t r e n g t h s an d w eaknesses of Ins technique, particu ­ larly th)* strengths. He was not talking p rim arily to his q u estio n ers, h u t to 
Moscow on th e eve of S e c re ta ry of 
State Vance’s mission to that capital 
He didn’t say anything new about the arm s control proposals Vance will take to the Soviets, but he wanted Brezhnev and other Soviet officials to know not only th at V an ce w as going th e re to negotiate seriou sly on the control of n u c le a r an d c o n v e n tio n a l m i li ta r y weapons, but w as going with the su p ­ port of C o n g ress and the A m erican people for h u m a n rig h ts as well as arm s control. 
C a rte r is well a w a re that Lyndon 
Johnson gave up the White House and 
Richard Nixon was driven out of it be­ cause they had lost the confidence of tin* American people: Therefore, he is risking the im precisions of the new s conference dialogue to keep the A m er­ ican people with him. 
Support 
Th)* new President also knows that his policies abroad w ill be precisely as effective as his support at home: 
T h e re fo re , he e m p h a s iz e d b efo re 
V ance’s m ission to Moscow that his public proclam ations on human rights and a rm s control had the support of the federal legislature and the people. 
"I believe that it is very im p ortan t," he said in his fourth news conference, 
‘for the A m erican people to know the fram ew ork w ithin w hich d iscussions might take place. . . . And that when I do speak. I d on’t speak with a hollow voice, hot that the rest of the w orld knows th a t on m y sta n d on h u m a n rights. . . 
I’m strongly supported by the C o n g ress and th e people of th e country." 
Weakness 
The main w eakness qf his news con­ ference technique is that while he is precise on ins principal m essage — in this case to Moscow — lie is then con­ fronted by secondary issues in which he is often m y s te rio u sly v ag ue and imprecise. 
For exam ple, he didn t really clarify his decision to intervene in the African country of Z aire . We have " n o o u t­ s ta n d in g c o m m i t m e n t s ’’ t h e r e , he said. anil no evidence that Cuban or 
A ngolan tr o o p s h a v e c r o s s e d th e border of Zaire. 
But. he added, " P re s id e n t M obutu has been a friend of ours, w e’ve e n ­ joyed good relatio nsh ips with Z aire, and we have substantial co m m ercial investments in that country." 
Civil wars 
Does this m ean that his policy is to intervene in the civil wars of Africa if we have a friend in power or c o m m e r­ cial in te re s ts th e re ? He did not e x ­ plain. 
\ 
This is the risky and devilish prob­ lem of the quick give anil take of news conferences. ll is h a rd to e x p la in , ha rd to r e ­ concile the defense of hum an rights in 
Moscow and ignore them "for national security reasons" in South Korea and tin* Philippines 
There is another problem. It is very difficult to keep the larger, long-range questions of either domestic or foreign policy at the forefront when news con­ f e r e n c e s c o n c e n t r a te oil th e s h o rt- range questions of tom orrow ’s news. 
Visitors 
For exam ple, tin* prim e m in isters of 
Britain. Jap an and Israel have recent­ ly been iii Washington. 

The political and economic instabili­ ty of these countries, anil of most of the rest of the F re e World, including In­ dia, F rance, Greece, Turkey and even 
G erm an y m a y in* Hu* most om in ou s questions in the world today, but they were not even mentioned by the P re s i­ dent or his questioners. 

E ven so, C a r te r se e m s to h av e a clear set of priorities in m ind anil is taking his chances. He is concentrating on public* support at home to sustain his policies abroad. 

If he can g et the atte n tio n of the evening netw ork news, lie will get the attention of the A merican people, lf he can r e s t o r e th e c o n fid e n c e of th e 
A merican people, he will probably get tin* support of Congress — and, with this sort of h ac k in g , V ance will be h eard wi t h re s p e c t in Moscow and elsewhere. 
/ 

That, at least, seem s to be C a rte r’s a p p ro a c h to th e u se s of th e Whi t e 
H ouse n ew s c o n fe re n c e . It m a y be running down a bit, aud the m ore he talks, the m ore he provokes the oppo­ sition of Bill Buckley, Jack Kilpatrick and the other observers on the right, but he is aim ing at larger objectives.

Mailer voices support of assassinations com m ittee 

 w a s h in g t o n star SCHV ICI 

WASHINGTON - N orm an Mailer has leaped with his usual syntatieal gusto to the defense of the em battled House A ssas­ sinations C om m ittee, and has enlisted 28 fellow waiters to join his plea for contin­ uation of the co m m ittee ’s investigations 
In a letter sent T hursday to the House and to P resid ent C arter, Mailer said in effect that while the com m ittee’s gam e is being badly played — and getting bad play 
— it’s the only g a m e in town and the stakes are high. 
“ The s e le c t c o m m it te e ," he w rote, 
“ may be im p erfe c t, im practical and a demon for poor publicity. For all we know, it may be riddled with undercover men. 
"But it is the only investigating body we have in the House of Representatives with the obligation to subpoena recalcitrant witnesses on these m a tters and the duty to listen to w itnesses who have studied the flaws in the W arren Commission report for years. 
Existence 

“ By its existence, therefore, the c o m ­ mittee represents a threat to anybody who would ho pe to m a in ta in public a p a th y about the assassin atio n s.” 
Though conceding that practical results, such as p ro secu tio n s, are unlikely from the c o m m ittee’s work. Mailer stressed the psychic value of the investigations. 
“ A c le a r idea of the character of the events of the recent past is essential to a d em o c ra c y ,” he w rote. “ Without k no w ­ ledge of what happened in an event, how can one deb ate its m eaning? 
“ lf we do not know whether Jack K en­ nedy was killed by the demented act of an isolated m an , or w hether by the concerted acts of a gro up of conspirators who e m ­ ployed Oswald as the set up; if we do not know w h e th er the m u rd e r of Oswald bv 
Jack Ruby was an attem pt to spare the 
First Lady all the discomfort ot appearing at a trial, or an order that came to Ja c k 
Ruby out of the chain of com m unication that ran between the CIA and the Mafia. then we do not know which history we can act upon.” 
Belief 

Mailer told a news conference here that he personally does not believe t uban P r e ­ mier F idel C astro had Kennedy shot b e ­ cause C astro would have realized that it 

 e v e n tu a lly would have le ak e d out and m eant the end of C astro's Cuba. 
But he noted the belief in some quarters that "th e reason the W arren Commission went into the tank" and pinned the assas­ sination on Lee Harvey Oswald alone was the commission s fear that Castro was in­ volved. and that if this were brought out it 

M a iler said iii e ffe c t th a t while the committee's paine is being b adly p la y e d 
— anti g ettin g bad p la y — it's the truly g a m e in tow n anti the stakes are high 

 would lead to war with Cuba and possibly with the Soviet Union 
He would. Mailer said. like to know the truth. 
Mailer said he takes it for granted that th e a s s a s s i n a tio n s c o m m it te e sta ff is loaded with undercover agents 
Though he declined to specify exactly w hat g o v ern m en tal body — or what go­ vernm ent. for that m a tte r — the agents are working for. his repeated references to the CIA strongly suggested where his su­ spicions lie 
Purpose 

A sked w hat u sefu l p u rp o s e it would serve to determ ine that the FBI and or CIA were involved in the Kennedy or Martin

As things stand now, he said, there are some who think the FBI can do no wrong, and others who think “ they couldn't oper­ ate cleanly if it was handed to them on a tow el."

After world role Evans is now home 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 26 1977 
Page T3-A 

After years of hobnobbing with world leaders, Luther 
Evans has come home to Texas 
— to San Antonio. 
To re tire . To w r it e h is a u to b io ­ graphs. The book will be about his long career which included running the Li­ brary of Congress and the United Na­ tions Educational, Scientific and Cul­ tural Organization (UNESCO). 
H is “ W ho’s W h o ” c a r e e r also threaded through Princeton and Dart­ mouth university classroom s where he once taught Nelson Rockefeller. 
Wholesome 

H e's sitting in the living room of his 
North Side home. His arm s are crossed on the high a rm of the couch. He rests his chin on his a rm s and gazes out the window. A thoughtful pose. 
E vans is a native of Bastrop County, 
T exas. B u t. he d o e sn ’t look or talk 
Texan. 
H is is th e p in k -w h ite sk in of a 
Yankee w ho’s never known the harsh 
Texas wind and sun 
T h e re ’s no trace of a drawl. And his constant reference to this fellow or that as “ old c h a p ” has a foreign ring to it. 
He laughs at the suggestion that h e ’s lost his Texan qualities. “ We feel like we’re real T exan s.”

Elderly 
M exican star still has fans 

By BEN KING Jr. 
M exican singer and movie star Tito Guizar found out Frid ay that just because a woman is over 6o doesn’t mean she doesn’t have her matinee idols. . 
A crowd of about 5oo 
San Antonians, largely composed of elderly wo­ men. filled Hemisfair’s 
Plaza Mexico to honor 
Guizar, who is known as 
M exico’s m usical am ­ bassador. 
A few of the older wo­ men were apparently so excited about seeing the 
68-year-old entertainer they had to go on stage to give him a kiss, just what their grand daughters would do to a rock star. 
5o-year span 
But to 65-year-old Mar­ ia Sanchez it certainly didn’t seem like 5o years since she first saw a 
Guizar movie in a down­ town San Antonio movie house. 
‘‘I remember when I was teen-ager my friends and I would go sec all of 
Tito’s movies. We even saw some of them several times.” she explained in 
Spanish. 
G uizar first came to prominence in the United 
States in 1936 after his song "A lia Kn E l Rancho 
Grande” became a na­ tionwide hit. 
He also distinguished himself by becoming the first Mexican musician to perform in the W hite 
House and Carnegie Hall. 
Following his success with ‘‘Alia En E l Rancho 
Grande.” Guizar made more than IOO movies in the United Stales and l^atin America. 
Star 
Guizar was already an established star when he made a movie with 

 comedian 
Bob 
Hope, who, as" a young upstart at the tim e, sang 
“ Thanks F o r The M e­ mory” in the movie. 
Obviously the tall-dark guitarist made a strong impression on the women who saw his movies dur­ ing the 193os and 194os. 
Pointing to her well-bundled mother, 
Alicia Rodriguez, said. 
‘‘My mother said she would be a ‘good girl’ if I brought her down here to see hor idol Tito Guizar. 
When the blare of mariachi trumpets final­ ly brought Guizar on stage, his enthusiasm matched the wom en’s expectations. 
Old h i t s 
The bcaming-Guadala- jare native sang most of his old hits for the au­ dience, which greeted al­ most every tune with a standing ovation. 
One woman summed up the occasion by say­ ing, “ Just because peo­ ple get old. doesn’t mean they lose their loves and fantasies.” 

TITO GUIZAR takes a bow during his Friday night performance

Foundation gets $8oo,ooo 

Southwest Foundation for Research and Education has received an $89o,oo(1 bequest from the estate of 
Mrs. Ellen Kerns. 
Mrs. Kerns, who died Feb. I, directed her will executor to give a portion of her estate to research and treatment in cardiovascular disease, cancer and tuberculosis. 
Alamo National Bank, the will s executor, selected the Southwest Foundation for the bequest. . r

New A-Texas flu hits 
Lackland AFB trainees 

Bv DAV It) MCLEMORE 

EXPRESS NEW S MEDICAL WRITE* 

About 85o cases of a new flu virus broke out among Lackland A F B trainees during 
F e ­ bruary, a base spokes­ man said Friday. 
The federal Center for 
Disease Control in Atlan­ ta said the new strain — 
A-Texas 177 — may be the predominant flu virus in the U.S. next year. 
Lackland officials said 

 the new virus occurred during late .January and early February, but has subsided to a point w here it is no longer a major concern. 
About HO cases of the 
A-Texas strain identified at Lowry A FB, Colo., have beep* attributed to 
Lackland due to assign­ ment of trainees. 
“ We had about HSI) cases during the height of the outbreak in Fe­ bruary.” the spokesman 

 said. “ That averages to about 28.7 cases per I ,OOO population per week.” 
The spokesman added 
IOO cases per 1,ooo popu- laton is considered an epidemic. 
Normal range of flu cases at the base during the time period of the outbreak is about eight cases per 1,ooo, he said. 
The base has an average trainee population of about 1o,ooo. 
Lackland officials and 

 doctors at Wilford Hall 
USAF Medical Center last month initially iden­ tified the flu as a flu-like virus 

San Antonio Metropoli­ tan Health District Dir. 
Courand Rothe said state health officials identified the \irus as a new strain at the state health lab last Friday and notified 
CDF. 

(D C said the new

 strain was described as an offspring of the A- 
Hong Kong flu virus, varieties of which have been present in epidemic proportions in the U.S. since 19o8. 

Wilford Hall officials said the A-Texas out­ break ended in Fcbraury and there have been no significant occurneees of any flu strain since. 

Dr Rothe said CDF of­ ficials have taken blood samples of trainees who had the new flu virus and are now attempting to determine whether it is transmittable among hu­ mans outside a closed environment, such as the trainee population. 

CDF said A-Texas is the fourth identified var­ iation of A-Hong Kong and it could become the predominant flu strain in the U.S. next year

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday M arch 2 6 I 9 7 7 
Page 
DB 
Where history has the pungent tang of moonshine 
Piney Woods spring 

Woodlands 
Of course the dogwood blooms and the tall pines grow for mile after mile across East Texas. T here art* more than ll million acres of commercial timberland alone in the 4o East Texas counties from Texarkana to Beaumont. 
And this is only a fra ctio n of the woodlands. 
But Woodville is a symbol. Since 1o4o it has staged the “ Dogwood Festival" under the slogan — 
“ It’s Dogwood Time in Tyler Coun­ ty.’’ 
This weekend is “ Western Week­ end” at the Dogwood Festival with more than I.HOO riders, a rodeo and a 
Western dance. Next weekend is the 
“ Dogwood Queen’s Weekend" with a 
Dogwood Parade, a historical pageant, dances and other e\ents. 
Woodville, county seat of Tyler 
County / is about IOO miles northeast of 
Houston and 5o m iles southeast of 
Lufkin. 
To savor the b eau ty of Dogwood 
T im e, drive down any road — as 
Bonnie and I did last Saturday. 

Weekend 
Visit 

B y 
George Car m ark 

IMi o I om fey 
Bencite farm ark 

Deep East Texas in sprin g­ time is something special. 
It may be Nature’s “Show of the Year” in Texas. 
There are challengers for that beau­ 

 ty crown for no state matches Texas in variety. 
But few Texans would find much fault with choosing as N ature’s peak — 
“ When spring com es to the Piney 
Woods.’’ 
And the symbol of that beauty is the dogwood. 
Bonnie and I went to Woodville last weekend. 

The rough hands of the years have dealt harshly with this wonderful old log cabin. It is known it was built more than I 32 years ago — for it was standing in 
I 8 4 5 . The man who lived in it then — W . B. Charlton — introduced in the lower house of Texas first state legislature the bill that created Tyler County. This home is made more unusual by the fact that it is not a museum piece — a family still lives in it. 

Nature’s splendor 

Who could ev er fo rg e t the tall, slender pines — straight as the main mast on an old-time sailing ship and three times as tall? 
And then as th e s u n lig h t filters through the green of the pines high overhead, the dogwood shines and glimmers in its white purity. 
But the dogwood is only part of the show. 
The wisteria is unbelievable — li­ lac purple blossoms cascading down from the top of a thousand trees 
The magnolias — symbols of tile Old 
South and of East Texas — have not yet flowered. But even without their great cream y blossom s, is th ere a more beautiful tree? 

And Woodville is the country of the yellow-flowered jasm ine vines — par­ ticularly pretty against the light green of young pines on a broad, low hillside. 
Occasionally there is the bright stab 

Dogwood and a Princess — symbols o f East Texas in the springtime. Kathy Barnes, a high school senior at Chester, Texas, is one of the princesses in the queen's court at the Tyler County 
Dogwood Festival 

The d o g w o o d shining in its white purity in the deep P iney W oods is the symbol o f sprin g in East Texas 

- 
— 
„ 
Berry Coffman is tin* leading Tyler of a red bud — or the softer red of the- 
- “there were the dogwoods, the purple 
County historian. David Lefkovits, who pink dogwood — or a big white* haw in wisteria and azaleas. Both the red and rec en tly re tire d and moved to th e full bloom. pink azaleas were so pretty. 
Woodville area from Baytown, is in- 
And the beauty was not limited to the 
In the inner courtyard of our motel, tereste d in the outdoors. His w ife, woodlands. the white of the dogwoods was drama- 
, 
In town — iii yards large and small tized by the c o n tra st of a big. red 

 flowering peach in full bloom. 
We were told the dogwood reached its peak the weekend we were there 
Mrs. Faye Ward of the* Tyler County 
Chamber of Commerce made fine a r ­ rangements for our visit. The guides she got for us were exceptional.

W ards best 1ox7-foot barn-style lawn building
