Sm oked food is tops at 
Casey’s 

C asey's on the River opened this week featur­ ing o ak-sm oked rib s , brisk et, sau sag e, ham and chicken in an old 
Texas 
The r e s ta u ra n t is located in the lower level of the Chandler Building 

Rio R am blin gs 

 on th e c o rn e r of S. 
Broadway and Crockett 
Street. 
John Casey, who oper­ ates the restaurant, says all of his b arbecue is smoked 16 to 18 hours in the restaurant. 
Casey says the idea is ti* serve auth en tic old- 
Texas food which can on­ ly be c re a te d by th e long-smoking process. 
The restau ran t’s early 
Texas decor is fu rth er accented by live country m usic on Friday and Sa­ turday nights. 
Casey’s on the River is open for lunch from 11:3o a rn. until 2:3o p.m . Din­ ner is served from 5 p.m. to IO p.m . and the bar rem ains open until m id­ night. 
■A ★ -A- 
La Mansion Muter Ho­ tel has joined the ranks of riverside food service e s ta b lis h m e n ts w hich cater boat dinners on the 
San Antonio River. 
Zoe W right, director of sales and catering, for the hotel said th" new se rv ic e w as added b e­ cause of requests by con­ vention planners. 
A popular featu re of 
Paseo del Rio, the group boat luncheons, cocktail parties and dinners are available through m ost 
Riverwalk restaurants. 
Menus and prices vary according to specialties of the restaurant. 
China is changing m usically 

A O fN C f M ANCI T O S S ! 
PEKING - China will 
“ re h a b ilita te ” Ludw ig* van Beethoven Saturday » on the occasion of the 
15oth anniversary of the 
G e rm a n c o m p o se r’s death. 
No official announce­ m ent has been m ade of this event, but news of it spread by word of mouth in Peking and was con­ firm ed by Peking Radio officials contacted by telephone. 
It is C hina th a t is changing and it wants to let the world know that a page has been turned and is prepared to open more to the outside now that 
Mao T se-tu n g ’s widow 
Chiang Ching and other too radicals accused of being her accom plices have been toppled. 
Several Chinese film s and p lay s w hich w ere previously banned have already reappeared since the fall of Chiang Ching, but the rehabilitation of 
B eethoven w ill m ean more to the outside world and that is evidently just what the authorities here want. 
Saturday night’s event will be unique. After the political news program , the official rad io and television netw ork will broadcast a concert by the Peking Central Phil­ h a rm o n ic 
O rc h e stra . 

S on A n tonio EX PR ESS-N EW S— S a tu rd a y M arch 2 6 I 9 7 7

3-B 
Vikki Carr makes 
S.A. showing tonight 

Vikki Carr, the popular singer and ac­ tress, will give her sixth benefit for Holy 
Cross High School at 8:3o p.m. Saturday at the Convention Center Arena. 
Miss C arr’s first appearance here during Hemis- fair 68 included a visit to the West Side high school, which was threatened at the tim e with being closed. 
The visit and Miss C arr’s belief that education is the answ er to 75 per cent of the problem s facing 
M exican-Americans prom pted the creation of the 
Holy Cross Endowment Fund. 
Born Florencia Bisenta de Casillas M artinez Car­ dona. Miss Carr includes in her other public efforts work with the American Lung Association, M uscular 
Dystrophy and the John Tracy Children Clinic. 
The 36-year-old El Paso native is a past recipient of the “ For God and Youth Award” presented in 1975 by the Catholic Youth Organization 
All proceeds from the Saturday concert will go to 

 the perm anent Holy Cross Endowment Fund 
Ticket prices are $3.5o. $5.5o, $7.5o and SIO They are available at all San Antonio Joskes stores. Sears and the Holy Cross box office, 433-86oo 

 tY o rk s h o p Net 

Registration is being held for a workshop in caligraphy, the art of elegant handwriting, at the Southwest Craft Center. 

Kitty M aguire will teach the 1-4 p.m . Satur­ day sessio n s at the creative art school’s Old 
I rsuline Academy, 3oft Augusta St. 

For registration or m ore inform ation te le ­ phone 224-1848. 

SINGER Vikki Carr will give a Sa­ turday benefit performance for 
Holy Cross High School in the Con­ vention Center Arena.

C A N T R E L L 
Frances M iller Cantrell of Lover- ma, Texas, passed aw ay T h u rs­ day M arch 24, 1977 at the age of 71 years She w as born in W axaha chic, Texas, July 21, 19o5. She was a retired school teacher, having taught 39' ? years, with 15' r years in East Central School Dist. She w a s a m e m b e r of L a v e r n ia

By DAVID HENDRICKS 
City Public Service an­ ticipated the current na­ tural gas shortage by p lan n in g two coal-fire electricity plants in 1973. 
This was the m essage to St. M ary’s University e n g in e e r in g s t u d e n ts 
Friday from Tom Berg, 
CPS Board chairm an. 
Berg was the third in a series of guest lecturers s c h e d u le d for p u b lic talks by the university’s 
D epartm ent of E ngineer­ ing. 
The first coal plant will he o p e r a t in g in M ay, 
Berg said, with the se­ cond plant to begin so­ m etim e in the fall. 
5o per cent 

The two plants, located at C ala v eras Lake, will supply 5(1 per cent of the city’s electricity needs. 

T h e C PS d e c is io n to build the plants cam e in 
1973 a fte r a serio us n a ­ tu ra l g a s c u r t a i l m e n t was imposed on the city in November. 1972, by its n a tu r a l g a s s u p p l ie r , 
Lo-Vaca (la th e rin g Co., 
Berg said. 

A fter th e coal p ric e s arc reflected, utility hills should stabilize, perhaps as long as seven y ears, 
Berg said. 

Coal will cost $1 3o per million btu (heating un­ its) co m p ared to $2 for gas and fuel oil, he said. 

CPS has a 2o-year coal su p p ly c o n tr a c t w ith a 
Wyoming firm. Wyoming coal is needed. Berg said, because it is low in sul­ phur content 
Sulphur coal 
Texas lignite is high in sulphur content and pol­ lu tio n c o n tro l d e v ic e s would cost $1oo million, the chairm an said. 
Berg presented a slide 
D octor’s trial is delayed 

.Jury selection in the trial of a San Antonio physician charged with fraud in connection with go vernm ent health p ro ­ g r a m s h a s b een p o s t­ poned until April IL 
The trial of Dr. Haul E. 
G ao n a had been scheduled to begin Mon­ day, but U.S. Bist. Judge 
Jo h n ll. Wood J r . o r ­ dered the delay. 
Judge Wood will hold a pretrial conference in the ease Monday morning. 
Dr. (iuona’s attorney, 
A nthony N icholas, has filed a motion to dism iss the 36-c*ount indictment, winch alleges the doctor falsified application for 
Medicare and Medicaid payments. 
N ich o la s a rg u e d th e indictment is too vague to allow him to prepare a defense in the ease. 
Asst. U.S. Atty. T ho­ m as E. Kiekhoff filed a response listing specific in s ta n c e s w hen G aona allegedly did not perform s e r v ic e s he liste d on app licatio n for g o v e rn ­ ment payments, 
Each of the 36 counts carries a m axim um pen­ a lty of five y e a r s in prison and a $1o,ooo fine. 
Dr Gaona is free on a 
$25,ooo personal recogni­ zance bond 

 show w hich d e p ic te d o p e ra tio n of th e coal plants and the construc­ tion of the South Texas 
Nuclear Project near Bay 
C ity, fro m w h e re San 
A ntonio w ill re c e iv e electricity in the 198os. 
B erg said th e s e a rc h for oil m ust go on. even if it comes from places like 
A laska, w here its costs 
$2o per barrel, compared to $13 per barrel from the 
Middle East.

B attle brews again over Alamo statue 

Gas hearing bill is filed 

AUSTIN, 
(AP) - 
Sen. Kent Hance has in­ troduced a bill requiring the railroad commission to hold public hearings before the rates for n a ­ tu ra l g as used in a- grieulture may be raised. 

“ N o w .” sa id H an ce, 
D-Lubbock, “ a fa rm er's only ch o ice w hen c o n ­ fronted w ith a n a tu r a l gas price increase is to either pay the ir 'Teased price or to turn off his ir rig a tio n w e lls .” 

By VICKIE DAVIDSON 
T here’s another battle b rew in g on w h e th er a b ro n z e s t a tu e of fou r 
A lam o h e ro e s ean be lodged inside the Alamo chapel. 
Rep. Ja m e s Knowlin of 
San Antonio has in tro ­ duced a bill that would allow the bronze statue to be placed in the Alamo. 
A s p o k e s m a n for 
Knowlin said Friday the representative is taking the action for the sole p u rp o s e of g iv in g th e 
Daughters of the Repub­ lic of Texas the right to have the statue if they want it. 

D R P le a d e r s h i p o p ­ poses the bill. They don’t want the statue and the group’s state convention voted against it.. 
Only last su m m e r the 
B RT leadership sighed with relief when Atty. 
Gen. John Hill ruled the proposed bronze statue 

DHT I v a d v r xiii ft opposes the bill 

 could not be placed in­ side the Alamo. 
Hill 

Hill based his ruling on 
19o5 leg isla tio n f o r b id ­ ding chan ges or a l t e r a ­ tio n s in th e 
A la m o c h u r c h p r o p e r u n le s s needed for preservation. 
The proposed statue of 
D avy 
C r o c k e tt, 
J i m 
Bowie, J a m e s B o n h a m an d 
W illia m 
T r a v i s would require digging a 

 four-foot hole in the A la­ mo floor. 
S ince th e D a u g h te r s are th e cu sto d ian s a n d tr u s te e s of the A la m o , the bill gives th em th e final choice on whether to place th e statue in th e chapel, said John Roth of 
K n o w lin ’s San A nton io office. 
Roth said Know I i n 's bill would amend the 19o5 le g islatio n which A tty . 
Gen. Hill referred to. 

BRT F’resident G e n e r­ al M argaret Lowery sent letters to the media this w eek s t a ti n g th e B R T opposed Knowlin’s bill. 

T h e b a ttle o v e r th e statue started some tim e ago when a form er p r e ­ sident of the state B R T took steps to contract the statue. 

T h e T e x a s H is t o r ic 
Commission was notified there was a donation to build the statue — if it was located in the center of the chapel.

 is an o u ts ta n d in g n a tu r e 

Princesses 

414— Funeral Directors 

A N G E L U S F U N E R A L H O M E 
H E N R Y G U E R R A 
6o2 W Houlton 
227 1461 

Mrs. Ward also arranged for pretty 
Dogwood Festival princesses from four 
T y ler C ounty tow ns to be B o n n ie’s models for her dogwood pictures. 
They were Kathy Barnes of Chester, 
Him Collier of Woodville, Cindy Hry- horchuk of W arren and Gina Pickens of Colmesneil. 
We first went east of Woodville for pictures at the home of Mr. and Mrs. 
Robert M. Birdwell — on the shore of a pretty little lake. 
The drive symbolized East Texas. 
As we crossed the railroad at Wood­ ville, th e r e w ere th e long ra ilro a d flatcars stacked with pulpwood Just beyond was a saw m ill, the big pine logs piled h ig h e r th a n a tw o-story house 
As we drove to the Birdwell home, we began to realize how much histor­ ian Coffman was going to add to our day. 
Now 
82. 
Coffman cam e to 
Woodville 52 years ago. When he cam e there was not a paved road — nor even a gravel road — in all Tyler County. 
In th e 192os. the county p a sse d a bond issue for roads. The bond money was put in the bank and soon the bank went broke. Som e bridg es had been built first and for several years they sat alone out in the fields or woods w ith no road approaching on either side. 
Following his re tire m e n t as a Dr. 
P ep per bottler, Coffman — who had been interested in local history all his life — spent six years m apping every p iece of p r o p e r ty in th e 
275-square-mile school district. Study­ ing courthouse and other docum ents made him an authority on Tyler Coun­ ty history. F or example, we asked him where the road we were on led. 
“ It leads to the old co m m un ity of 
Town B luff on th e N ech es R iv e r ,” 
Coffman said. “ In the 183os a man who had som e difficulties east of here cam e to th is c o u n try and put in a fe rry across the Neches. 
“ He decided to found a town and sell lots in it. 
“ Natchez. Miss., had un outstanding rep u tatio n — so he called th e town 
’Natchez-on-the-Neches,’ He sold many lots in c lu d in g so m e to th e A llen brothers who founded Houston. 
“ In tim e the purchasers found a lit­ tle flaw — the developer d id n t own'the. land he was selling." 
The Birdwell grounds m ade such a b e a u tifu l s e ttin g for p ic t u r e s and 
Birdwell was so helpful. After making p ic tu re s th e r e , B onnie m a d e o th er p ic tu r e s of th e fo ur p r i n c e s s e s in w(Midland scenes. 
T hen C offm an and L efkuvits took 
Bonnie and me to a historic spot. Iii a ta n g led th ic k e t on the o u ts k irts of 
Woodville stood a cabin. It is badly battered by time hut a family still lives in it. 
Log cabin 

“ This log cabin was built some tim e before 1845,” Coffman said. "It was the home of W B Charlton, who in­ troduced in the lower house of the new state of Texas the resolution creating 
Tyler County. This was in 1846 
"Woodville does not get its name, as so many people think, for the m agnifi­ cent woods in this area. Woodville was named for George T. Wood who intro­ duced the T yler County resolution in the Senate.” 
In an era of rugged Texans, Wood s ru g g e d n e ss stood out. He fo rm ed a company and fought in the Creek In­ dian War when he was 19 
He resigned from the Texas Senate to com m an d a m ounted regim en t in the Mexican War. The Texas Handbook says his daring m ade him a hero to the 
East Texans he com m anded and this resulted in his election as T exas go­ vernor. 
Charlton was not forgotten. A Wood­ ville street bears his name. 

2 g r e a t f e s t i v a l s 

There are two m ajor dogwood festivals in East Texas this weekend and next. 

Woodville has its Tyler County 
Dogwood Festival and Palestine has its Dogwood Trails. Both have nu­ merous special events. 

Then the Texas State Railroad train will run between P alestin e and Rusk on April 2 and 3. 

Another East Texas town. Tyler, has its Azalea Trail Saturday and 
Sunday.

J SC A C E 5 M asonic Section, M u ­ tton Oui tai Park. South 113 *787 

TV aerial 

Though the spell was broken a little by a big television aerial on the log cabin — we were moved at seeing a log c a b in m o r e th a n a c e n tu r y and a qu arter old not as a m useum piece but simply lived in as a nome. 
Of course no one could visit Wood­ ville without seeing J e th ro Holmes, 
Jethro is a fixture at the Texas Folklife 
Festival with his log wagon pulled by his oxen, Tom and Jerry 
Jethro — now in ills 8os — is proud that durin g P rohibition days he was the biggest moonshiner in East Texas. 
"I started out keeping the fire going at my d a d d y 's still wheir I was 8," 
Jethro says. 
"At one time I m ade and sold whisky 

 all across East Texas. I had as many as three big stills oui in the woods at one tim e — I could turn out m ore than 3oo gallons a day." 
Got caught 
The revenuers finally picked Jethro up. He pleaded guilty and the judge who had long known Jethro reluctantly sentenced him. Jethro reports: 
“ The judge said. T would rather go to prison m yself than see J e th ro go there.’ “ 
Jeth ro has another unusual distinc­ tion. He voluntarily stayed in federal prison a month beyond his release date to finish up a project he was on. 
“ The federal prison had a big hog raising project that they were having trouble with until I was put in charge I was erecting some buildings for ii and 
I just couldn’t leave without seeing it finished." 
Then cam e Je th ro ’s always present punch-line: 
“ Besides by that tim e I was riding a big blaze-faced horse and bossing a lot of men. I liked that." 
B u t t h e r e a r e a h u n d re d J e t h r o stories. 
Festival 

Back at the cham ber of com m erce, 
Mrs Ward told us some of the story of the c o m m u n ity co o p eratio n for th e 
Dogwood Festival 
“ Just consider making the artificial flowers for the a m p h ith e a te r," Mrs. 
Ward said “ To save tile w in no w ers, 
Woodville m akes artificial dogwood, azalea and wisteria blossoms. 
“ This year 2oo,ooo are being made. 
Mrs. Sue B racken is in charge. The blossom s a re cut out of crepe paper witii a bandsaw 
“ But then every blossom has to be formed by hand. Nursing homes, g a r­ den d u b s , Women s clubs, home d e ­ monstration clubs and other organiza­ tions join i i i . 
“ Even in the beauty shops, as wo­ men sit u n d er the d rie rs they m ake artificial flowers." 
The T exas F orestry Assn. sponsors 
14 w a lk in g tr a ils in T ex a s forests. 
International P a p e r has one just off 
U.S. 19o three miles west of Woodville. 
There is un auto road into the forest for 
I‘4 miles with four hiking trails stem ­ ming from it. 
Heritage village 
B o n n ie an d I sa v e d for tile lust 
W o o d v ille ^ o u tsta n d in g p e rm a n e n t attraction 
Clyde Gray, a salesman now turned c e ra m ic a rtist, and his wife. Bill, a new spaperwoman, retired and moved from Beaumont to Woodville. 
They cam e up with the idea of Heri­ tage G arden Village, which they d e ­ scribe as " t h e larg est collection of 
East Texas artifacts in tile s ta te .” It has this slogan. 
"Come be your own grandpa for un afternoon." 
There are about 3o m ajor exhibits — such as an old-time East Texas b arb er shop, a g e n e ra l s to r e , an 
1888 newspaper shop and a shingle mill. 
Centerpiece 
But the centerpiece is 
“ Pickett 
House," a one-time schoolhouse now a dining room It is run as an earlier day 
East Texas boarding house. Chicken and dumplings are served every day. 
In sum m er, more than 7oo people are served dinner every week. 
“ In 197o. three people ran Heritage 
Garden Village," Gray told us. "Now we have 32 full-time people." 
From Heritage Garden. Bonnie and I h e ad ed n o rth on U .S. 69 — a g a in through those wonderful pines laced with d< gwood 
We cam ped Saturday night on Luke 
S am Rayburn, But th a t s a n o th e r story.

Spurs, 113-11o. Friday night ut-the 
Spectrum,

/ones.

Lloyd Free with 5:58 left. Philadelphia ran off a 1o-3 streak over the next 3:35. and then held on.

Moe, who usually re­ frains from critizing the performance of officials, was so angered by the work of 
Lee Jones and John Vanuk, he could not stop pacing while talking with re­ porters.

Leu Antonopolis learned an important lesson in being gutsy Friday afternoon. 

"The only way to win is being gutsy.“ said tile 
18-year old Glendora. Calif., high school senior, following her 5-7. ti-2, ti-7 loss to Mary Hamm in the sem ifinals of the Lm nel-MeFurlin Cup. 
“ Being gutsy is what I learned playing Mary. She was more gutsy than I was i i i the final set, and she won the match. I should have been more gutsy like Billie (Jean King) toid me earlier ” 
However, p a rlicip u tm g i i i tins tournament and other pre- v ious meets on the Virginia 
Slims' circuit. lias all been a learning process for the youngster, 
“ I ve had a good record i ii 
Virginia Slim s." Autonopolis said " ll I had gone to Little Rock next week, I would have probably been seeded first <»r second. I ve got to get buck l»i school, however.

Bruins, K L in Los Nngeles the day the rankings were announced.

California switched places. They are third and fourth,

Young.

OT THE EXPRESS N EW S STATT 

When Billie Jean King won h ct first Wimbledon singles title. Mary Hamm was 12 years 1 old. That was in IHM. 

But Saturday at I p.m. the two will meet for the first time on Court No. 22 at McFarlm Tennis Center in the finals of the $2o,ooo Lionel-McFarlm Cup 
Tennis Tournament. 
King, a six-time 
Wimbledon singles champ and top seed here, took just 55 minutes to bump off 
Marne Louie, ti-2, ti-2r in one sem ifin al match Friday. 
Sixth-seeded M ary 
Hamm, a standout during her T rin ity 
U niversity tennis career, took a trifle longer — two hours aud 5o minutes — to defeat Leu Autonopolis. 7-5. 2-ti, 7-ti 
(5-3). iii tile other semifinal till 
“ I feel privileged lo be fating Billie 
Je a n ." Hamm, the 22-.vear-old San 
Automan, said "It is a great oppor­ tunity for lite. Gut I would be lying if I said I am not a little awed by it 
"How ever, I am going out there thinking I eau win.” It is the first time llamm has reached the finals of a tournament in her pro career. She graduated from Trinity last spring 
King. who is competing in her first tournament since having knee surgery last October, was complimentary of her next opponent. 
“ She (Hamm) is tough,” King said 
“ She has a great attitude. I just love seeing a young player like Mary bust­ ing a gut out there. I am very im ­ pressed with her. She never quits." 
Reminded 

King, 33, reminded most of the more than 1,2oo fans present of flu* old Billie 
Jean Frid ay. She moved well and mixed up her shots against a befuddled 
Louie It was clearly King s best per­ formance of the tournament. 
“ I am not tired aud my knee feels great." King beamed afterwards "She tried to run me. hut 
I was able to move wide I felt like I was shot out of a cannon " . 
King broke Louie s serve iii the fourth game of the first set to take a 3-1 lead. She did the same in the sixth game to take a 5-1 advantage. 
Louie, a '23-year-old from San Fran­ cisco who was the tourney’s number three seed, bruke back in tile seventh

Daw kine went over his back for a fol­ low stuff

“ Thank God,” said the 6-8 Olberd- liig, “ he didn t decide to put me through tin' lump with the hall.” 
"This is the worst home job I ve ever seen,” said Mot*. "They shouldn't have given Dawkins the Most Valuable

" Ile couldn't coach a high school game, not even a grammar school game.

I ve ever seen It was a disgrace. 
“ I'v e never been so angry. We played our hearts out. outplayed them the whole game. It s a disgrace. The 
NBA bleeps 
But the Sixers were stronger down the stretch, hitting 5o per cent of their shots in the final quarter while out­ scoring the spurs. ,*2-34 San Antonio shot 37 |>er cent in the fourth. 
And Philadelphia’s All-Star guard. 
Doug Collins, did an all-pro defensive 
•job on the Spurs' leading scorer. 
’George Gerv in. 
"tie rvm s a great player.” said Col­ lins. " I must admit in the back of my 
.mind I was trying to break Ins streak of games in double figures. I guess tilt* 
. challenge was just too great." 
Ice finished with 15, but was four-nf-12 from the field Ile bas been in double figures in all of the Spurs’ 74 games Only Boston’s Jo Jo White and the Lakers’ Hareem Abdul-Jubbar have done the same. 
“ I tried..to use my quickness on 
.him .” said Collins, who bad but IO 
•points, nine Indow bis average, "lie s 
"basically a forward-orientated player. so I tried to keep bim outside." 
W hile Gerv in was tepid from the 
'field . Mike Gale was superb in all phases of the game Gale, a Philadel­ phia native, was IO of 12 from the field for 2o points and handed out eight as­ sists. 
And the Spurs' "Ph illy Dog” stole everything but the Liberty Bell, adding eight thefts to his single season club record

245-pound Dawkins, led the Sixers with 
2o points and 15 rebounds, while Free s 
25 points, including 13 in the final quarter, paced Plully's run to the wire.

Dawkins, whose entrance was wildly applauded by the crowd of 14.753.

Dawkins. "B u t I haven't played so much ut one stretch before. I thought 
I d need un oxygen mask."

Ayala chalks up TRO 

Continued from Page IC 

 improvement. Ile should have finished him (Anaya) iii the second round. 
• He still has to learn to finish his opponent off.” 
You would have trouble convincing 
Anova of that 
Ayala started out stinging Anaya with two good left hooks iii the first round Of course, the cunning veteran countered with a lunik and combo of Ills own, but Ayala never lost Ins poise. 

In the second round. Anaya hit Ayala with stiff jabs several times, but late in 
Hie round Ayala landed a crisp left- right combo that hurt Anaya and brought cheers from the crowd. 

Anaya seemed dazed upon coming out for the third round and a tiny cut was visible over Ills left eye. Then experience took over. Av ala lost a little momentum and the former champ ap­ 

 peared to have won the round slightly. 
But then, midway the fourth round, 
Ayala retreated lo the ropes and un­ fortunately Anaya followed him. Using the rope-a-dope exactly as All did against George Foreman in Zaire. 
Av ala staggered Anaya with two hard lefts. 
Anaya backed to the opposite corner where Av ala floored him with another left hook bringing a deafening roar from the crowd. 
Ayala did the same iii the fifth, and suddenly, blood gushed from Anaya’s left eye. Bul the seasoned Anaya would not stop. 
In the sixth round. Ayala nailed hts opponent with a straight right, putting lulu on the canvas once again. Referee 
Tony Zuniga halted the action at I 49 of the round. 
“ He never hurt me,’’ Ayala said, though he took several licks from a man that would have knocked out 39 of 

 his foes " I feel I ’m improving. I ’m hitting harder." Ayala added as he signed autographs at ringside. 
Avalu's manager, his father Tony. said, " I think we ll get a world title shot by June and we're going to try and bring it here We’re going to have to sit down with the Federation and ne- goiate.’’ 
The elder Ayala also said he heard rumors that Canada’s Art Hafey, the top contender for Mike’s title, had re­ tired. But he named possibles such as 
Rafael Herrera. Ruben Olivares and 
Rudolfo Martinez for future matches 
In the preliminary action, San An­ num ’s Robert Vusquez, who was rid­ ing a 19-knockout string, scored a fifth-rou Castillo, Gilbert Galvan was surprised by a first-round THO at the hands of Juarez, Mexico’s Augustin 
Estrada and Johnny Moreno in a local comeback debut was T K O ’d in the third round by Mexico’s Haul Ramirez 
Braves get new owner 

B U F F A L O 
(A P ) 
- 
P a u l 
Snyder, owner of the Buffalo 
B raves for the last seven years, said Friday night he had sold his 
5o per cent interest to Kentucky bu sin essm an John Y. B row n, who now becom es the sole owner of the National B asketball A sso­ ciation club. 

Brown, a former owner of the Ken­ tucky Colonels in the now-defunct 

Amcriun Basketball Association, immediately promised to keep the 
Braves in Buffalo for the time being 
"lf it doesn't work out here, then I'll have to look at alternatives—Louisville br Miami,” Brown said. adding. “ I’d like to have a team in Louisville." 

But. he predicted: “ W e’re going to build a winner here. I think we have the nucleus to build a winner in Buf­ falo.” 
Brown introduced Norman Sonju, a 
Chicago businessman, who Brown said would be the Braves’ president and 

 would have complete control of the team’s operations. 
Snyder, who bought the Braves from a New York investment firm several weeks after the NBA franchise was awarded to Buffalo, reportedly paid $4 million. Ile was believed lo have gotten between $7-7 5 million from Brown, but both declined to mention the figure 
Brown, who bought 59 per cent of the 
Braves last summer, told a news con­ ference: 
“ I think Buffalo is a good market for basketball. 

Bullets hit 

BOSTON (A P) - The Washington 
Bullets erupted for 19 straight points in the first half and went on to crush the 
Boston (’cities 122-98 in a National 
Basketball Association game Friday night. 
W ashington's 
Tom 
Henderson scored the last basket of the first period to give the visitors a 28-23 lead, then reserves Larry Wright and Milch 
Kupchak levi tho Bullets to 17 straight points and a 45-23 lead.

Bullets led 61-41

Johnny recalls bad day at Indy 

' It’s been said that concentration is the secret of strength in the m anagem ent of all hum an affairs. This then, more than anything else, explains how big-tim e auto racers can flirt with death, look it squarely in the eyeballs and then return to their thoughts of 

 racing. 
But don’t think that when the black angel of death visits a friend or colleague on the racetrack drivers forever erase those tragic m em ories from their m inds. The human brain barrel just doesn t work in such a convenient manner. 

Johnny Rutherford, the handsome 
Texan, is at the top of the pack now He got his second Indy w in last year so he spends a lot of time doing TV com­ mercials and visiting his bank. 
Johnny’s first victory at Indy came in 1974, exactly 19 years after his clo­ sest brush with death, the darkest day in the history of the ancient shrine of speed Rutherford remembers that day so well. He recalls every, detail of the crush that took two lives and missed claiming number three— lohnny—by tilt* narrowest margin. 

Those who saw it and many who 

 viewed the films will never forget that horrible holocaust on Memorial Day in 
St when 
Eddie Sachs sat in his 

 wrecked car and burned to death. 
Flames from the SO gallons of gasoline that surrounded the seat of Sachs’ car leaped KO feet into the air and black smoke spiraled skyward for hundreds of yards. Some of those flames licked the back of Rutherford's neck but 2(1 minutes later he was trying to repair his wrecked car in time for a re-start. 

But let Johnny tell the story as only he knows it and remembers it so vi­ vidly. After all. he was the third man in the mishap and the other two are dead. 
It’s not a painful story for a race- driver to tell at this point, 13 years alter it happened. It s just one of those bad. occupational hazards that made sad history at Indy. 
The crash 

Rutherford. 39 with a lot of racing still ahead of him, unbuttoned his eoat and leaned back in his chair. 

“ We were just moving onto the se­ cond lap and, as is always the case on early laps in a big race, the traffic was heavy. It really was hard to see and I ducked In behind Sachs, figuring that he was a good veteran and if there was an opening to be found he would find it. 
You may recall that was only my se­ cond time to race at Indy and the year before my car developed problems after just 43 laps.” 

The Fort Worth native began to frown a bit us he moved toward the details of the wreck. The whole thing happened in three or four seconds but it must have been a slow-motioned nightmare, an eternity, for those in­ volved. Come to think of it. it was an eternity for two. Rutherford continued. 

"The first danger signal I saw was a 

 puff of dust ahead. That's usually the telltale. When you see dust gathering you’d better keep both eyes In that area. In an Instant the puff of dust became I cloud and I tried to look beyond Saeh’s car. dropping back just a little. And then it all happened. That first cloud was Dave McDonald hitting the wall and when he came off there was no place for Sachs to go. Ile smashed right into the crippled car and the rear of his car went straight up. I remember looking at those twin 
Ford tailpipes rising in front of me and then I saw the smallest opening at right, near the wail where Dave had hit. 

 was burning and the fire—by then be­ hind me—was obviously growing in intensity. You’ve got to keep in mind that this happened quickly and I was still moving well over 199 miles-un hour." Rutherford said. 

McDonald and Sachs died within se­ conds on the track. And it wasn’t until the next day. after studying newspaper and TV pictures and re-visittng the track, that Rutherford discovered that he hadn t missed the wall. He left two tire tracks on the side of the wall be­ fore flipping back down and continuing on to safety. The neck burns proved minor. C ertainly minor by com pa­ rison. 

The race was stopped and when 

Rutherford and the other survivors reached their pits they prepared for the re-start. “ My crew worked fever­ ishly to make needed repairs and I was getting ready to go agaio but my car was too badly damaged.” Johnny said. 
And what was he thinking of as the track wa> being cleaned and the bodies removed? “ I was thinking of the same thing the other drivers were thinking about—being prepared for the race s re-start and fighting to push all other thoughts from my mind.” 

Now that, friends, takes a heavy stack of concentration. 
Texas rate 

Rutherford, a class guy who once attended TCI! before deciding that the university d id n’t have the right courses to help him make cars go fas­ ter. is in San Antonio to promote his next race, at Bryan. 

The Texas Grand Prix, a 2oo-mile 

 chase for Indy cars on the super speedway near Aggieland. is set for 
April 2, next Saturday. It s a tune-up for the Indv 5oo and many of the top name drivers who will compete at Indy will be in that Bryan race. 

But more than anything else, it fi­ gures to Im * a battle between Texas’ two great drivers. Rutherford and A .J r a f t 
And by the way. no matter what you might have read or heard elsewhere, 
A .J. and Johnny are close friends 
They don't offer each tither any cour­ tesies when they go wheel-to-wheel hut then, that’s got something to do with concentration. 

" I went toward the walla s near as I dared but I caught the tailcnd of 
Eddie s car just as it burst into flames. 
One of his back wheels came down on my hood and for the next few seconds I had my hands full trying to wobble on through and keep off the wall. My neck i— 34th for Texas— i 

AUSTIN (A P ) — Texas capitalized on the first inning wildness of Rice 

 pitchers Tim Holder and Ralph Cooley for five runs and the Longhorns went on to an 8-2 Southwest Conference baseball victory over the Rice. 

The victory was Texas' 34th in a row this season, believed to be two more than 

 the national collegiate baseball record. The Longhorns arr IO U in SWC play. 

Holder walked the first four batters in the first inning and was relieved bv 

Cooley, who walked two more, allowed a run-scoring single to Charles Proske and then threw a wild pitch. 

Rice countered with two second-inning runs off winning pitcher Kern Wright 

 and Cooley beld Texas to one more run until the eighth inning, when Texas tallied twice. 

The Owls are now 11-17 for the season and 4-S in SWC play. 

Bulls kick 
CHICAGO (A P ) — Artis Gilmore scored 21 points and grabbed 23 re­ bounds Friday night to lead the Chica­ go Bulls to a 1o5-87 National Basketball 
Association win over the New York 
Knicks. 
The win was Chicago’s seventh in a row and 14th in their last 15 outings 
Going into F rid a y night's N BA schedule, the Bulls were a I 1* games behind Kansas City in a fight for the final Western Conference playoff spot.

King denies match rumor 

B illie Jean King and 
Renee Richards denied 
Friday they are playing a challenge match in the near future. 
Rum ors floating a r­ ound the Lionel-McFar- lin Cup tournament said that King and Richards had signed up for a big money winner-take-all challenge match at Cea- sar’s Palace in Las Ve­ gas. The rumors also said that, if both had one semifinal matches in the tournament, one or the other would have de­ faulted so as not to hurt the proposed challenge match. 
Came to play 
‘‘Never heard of such a thing.” said Richards when questioned about the challenge match. “ I didn't come down here to monkey around with television. I came to play tennis. 
“ I ’m going to the F a ­ m ily C ircle meet and 
Billie’s going to Little 
Rock next week We both may play in New York together. But, we haven’t signed up for any chal­ lenge match.” 

“ No way.” King said. 
“ You guys would be the first to know aboiit such a match if there indeed was one.” 

“ I wish someone would come up with the money for such a match, we would be there tom or­ row .” said David Buf- fum. Richards’ manager. 
“ This rumor is all new to me. There’s no validity to it whatsoever” 

“ Marcie's Monument-, the huge .scaffold over­ looking the courts F r i­ day. caused CBS a bun­ dle. The scaffold was set up for the never mater­ ialized King-Richards semifinal match. Marcie 
Louie stunned Richards in the q uarterfin als 
Thursday. 
$11,ooo 
CHS “ blew” sn .(Min in equipmenl and personnel in anticipation of the match. 
Announcers 
Brent Mussberger and 
Ju lie 
Heldman were flown in from New York to broadcast (he match. 
They returned F rid a y 
1‘iiipty handed 

“ That's a funny thing about television.” Buf- fiim said. “ We asked for coverage four or five weeks ago. lint th<*y said they didn’t have time. 
Now. they come in. put­ ting up scaffolds, at the last minute. They didn’t get anyone prepared for 
It,..who knows, the girls may have wanted to wear a different dress or hair style. You ciin’t do any­ thing well on a short notice. 

“ There's a couple of things for sure. Renee and Billie Jean haven’t signed for a challenge m atch, and both g irls came down hen* to play tennis. It's funnv how rumors are started.” By

“ She is a good player.” said an exhausted Hamm of .Anlonopolis after the lengthy two-hour. 5o-minute match “ She is very mature for her age. Lea has a g<»od future ahead of her. She has been playing a limg time, and she has the right attitude.”

.iediiisl Mary. She played like I wantwl her too. hut I didn’t play like I wanted to. I really would have won if I’d come lo the net more

Confidence 
“I don’t have confidence in my fori hand I knew I couldn’t hit with her...that was the faults of (Karen) 
Krantzcke and Linda (Rupert Thomas). I really didn’t hit with her but I made the mistakes.”

Rupert. “ It’s obvious you can’t play her backhand” 
“ My legs started cramping up in the last three games and I couldn’t push off my serve." Antono- polis said. “ It’s the first time. I ’ve ever double­ faulted (seven tim»*s) so much. I made up some of them with five aces but I hate to nullify aces.

I wduld be a lot fast(*r. 
(’dlifornia’s rules allow Antonopolis to participate in these tournaments, and still compete at the high schiMil level. Texas doesn’t have such a rule. 
“ Sure, I can play in these tournaments,” said the 
Southern California bound lM*auty, who is not getting any prize money for her showing. “ We can even get gifts, like racquets, and can carry a little expense mom*y. .And we can still participate in the state meet. 
Forbid 
“ I heard that Texas had rules that forbid high school players to play with the pros That’s why one of my friends is going to a private schrad in the state 
Ifs really g(M»d playing with the pros. You learn a lot. get g(K)d advice, and it improves your game.” 
Rupert, who watched the match, praised both 
.\iitomi|>oIis and Hamm. 
“ U*a IS a g(M»d young player.” Rupert said. “ She’s going lo Ik* tough. I played Mary over 23 times in college, and she only won three limes. However, she has really improved her forehand and is more ag­ gressive now. Both lA'a and Mary need to work on their concentration. All of M ary’s matches are long because she seems to relax in the second set and lose then plays strong in the third set” 
Crowd good 
“ The crowd was really good 
.. I was worried about people cheering for me.” Antonopolis said 
“ Now my goals have moved up, I want to move up to the majors with Chris (Kvert) and people like that 
“ I really like Texas. I advanced to the semifinals in the Av'dn Futures tournament in Austin last year. 
I’ve learned a lot in this and previous tournaments. 
The main things I ’ve got to work on is bt>ing more aggressive and being gutsy — those are the keys to winning.”

Bahamas (A P ) — New 
York Jets quarterback 
Jo e Namath stands a good chance of playing for Los Angeles next Rea­ son if his savaged knees can pass the club’s phy­ sical. Rams owner Car­ roll Rosenbloom said 
Friday. 
“ Of course we’re in­ terested in Namath if he can help us," said Ro­ senbloom. on vacation here. “ But if s all im ­ portant to know if he’ll pass our physical and our doctor’s physical” 
No decision 
Rosenbloom told the 
Nassau Tribune in an in­ terview that no decision would be made until he returns to Los Angeles, probably next week. 
Jim m y W alsh. 
Na- m ath’s agent, said 
Thursday in Los Angeles that Namath. who quar­ terbacked the .lets for 12 years has been given permisi^on to be traded to the Rams Namath has said he would like to be n(*ar Ibdlywood and the movie industry. 
HosenblcKun said talks about Namath had been going on for a long time and that “ obviously Na­ math wants to join a g(M>d club where he gets good protection, can (ilay ef­ fectively and go out in a blaze of glory,”

SnCIAl IO TH* EKMIf SS NEWS 

 usually spotty forehand for help. 
“ I just rushed a lot of my backhands at the net.” Hamm said. “ But my for­ ehand stayed togtdher. To tell you the truth, I really did not rea'izc I had missed that many backhands." 
Hamm broke serve in the lith game of the first set to take the lca(l. She won the set by holding serve in the 12tli game. The opening set, like all three sets. ft'atured long baseline rallies 
.Antonopolis, an 18-year-old from 
Glendora, Calif., jumped in front in the second set 2-o, breaking Hamm in the’ second game. 
Hamm came back with a break of her own, but Antonopolis broke again in the fourth game and 

 took command. In all. there were six service breaks in the second set. 

“ My leg cramped up late and I could not push off on my serve very well.” 
Antonopolis said, trying to explain all the service breaks. 

Hamm opened the third set with a service break, but Antonopolis broke in the fourth game lo even the set. 
Hamm, who does not have a powerful serve, was also beset with break woes 

Leading 4-3. Antonopolis broke 
Hamm in just five points to even the match again. 
Hamm was servinj:: for the match at 

H-5. but misfired on thr«’e consecutive backhands and Antonopolis converted a good volley to force ‘Up iiEdireaker. 

Hamm got the first two points in the tiebreaker with an overhead and a backhand shot which dribbled over the net. 

“ I felt victimized by that shot.” An- tonopolis said, still shaking her head.

A stro ace has surgery 

HOUSTON (A P ) 
— 
Houston 
Astros eenterfielder Cesar Ce- dono underwent surgery 
Friday to correct liga­ ment damage on a finger and will miss the Astros’ season opener April 8. 

The Astros placed Ce- deno on the 21-day disa­ bled list Thursday. 

Houston wins, 5-4 

COCOA, Flu. (A P )—Ken Boswell’s sacri­ fice fly in the eighth inning drove in the winning run as the Houston Astros defeated the Montreal Expos 5-4 Friday in an exhi­ bition baseball game. 

Boswell’s fly to C en terfield scored Rob Andrews. who led off the eighth with a single. Andrews moved to second base on Mike Cosgrove’s sacrifice bunt and reached third on Julio Gonzalez’ single. 

The Expos had tied the game game in the top of the eighth when Tony Perez homered off Cosgrove. 
It was Perez’ fourth spring home run 

Gonzalez, who is making a strong bid for Hous­ ton’s starting second base job as a rookie, had four hits and now is ll for 19 in his last five games for a 
.57(1 Average. 

Joe Ferguson drove in two other Houston runs. 
While Al Javier and Enos Cabell each added RBIs for the Astros. Andre Dawson drove in three Expos runs and Wayne Garrett had two hits.

WATSON watches drive 
AP WIREPHOTO 
NCAA foes battle today 

ATLANTA (AF) - College basketball’s showcase event narrows its field to the finalists Saturday with nationally televised semifinal battles in the NCAA Champion­ ships. 

Watson in lead 

HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C. (AP) — 
Tom Watson shrugged off the nagging memory of last week’s collapse, put to­ gether a solid, four-under-par 67 and es­ tablished a one-stroke lead Friday in the second round of the $225,ooo Sea Pines 
Heritage Golf Classic. 

The freckle-faced, red-haired Watson put together a 36-hole total of 134, eight under par for two trips over the 6,655 yards of the Harbour Town Golf Links that winds its way along the marshy coasts of this resort island off the South Carolina coast. 
“ I just didn’t play very well—started hitting it sideways,” Watson replied when asked about the JI strokes he took over the last nine holes last week, a blowup that cost him his third victory of the season in the Tournament Flayers Championship. 
This week is a different story. He got around without a bogey, missed only one green and could have had a much better score on this course lined with moss-dripping old c y p re ss trees. He missed twice on putts of less than six feet and failed on four others in the 12-15 foot range. 
“ I feel I really have the club on the path I want right now,” said Watson. The 27-year-old former 
British Open champion already has collected two titles and $1o9,535 this season. 
G olf standings 

W ASH IN G TO N (A P ) 
— The new collective bargaining agreement in the National Football 
League went into effect 
Friday after the union’s rank-and-file m em ber­ ship voted ratification. 
The owners had already approved the contract. 
Ed Garvey, association executive director, said a majority of the members had given their approval by Friday's voting dead­ line with ballots still ar- riv mg. lie told a news conder- dice that 416 of the 812 members had approved the new agreement, signed March I, with 2o others easting negative ballots.

I Michigan out of title contention a week ago 
The nightcap of the doubleheader matches 
A tlantic Coast Confer­ ence champion North 
Carolina, ranked No. 5, against No. 4 Nevada-Las 
Vegas, an explosive club averaging a whopping 
1o7.9 points per game. 
Winners 
Tile winners, who will have survived a 32-team field which began this annual spring madness two weeks ago, will de­ cide the championship 
Monday night following a consolation game between 
Satu rd ay’s losers. 
Oddsmakers have es­ tablished 
Marquette, 
23-7, and North Carolina, 
27-4. as 2V2-point favor­ ites against teams with better records. UN CC is 
28-3 and U N LV is 28-2. with victories in 25 of its last 26 games. 
The two Carolina clubs currently carry the lon­ gest winning streaks among m ajor college teams. North Carolina has won 
14 straight, 
CNCT 13, Las Vegas ll and Barquette 8. 
McGuire, one of college basketball's most out­ spoken coaches, an­ nounced during the sea­ son he was retiring to devote fulltime to busi­ ness at the end of this season, his 13th at Mar­ quette. 
Lost 
Despite averaging 25 victories during the last nine seasons, M cGuire has never cdpluieii the 
NCAA title. His 1974 team lost to 
North 
Carolina State iii the fin­ als, m arking the only other time the Warriors have reached the final four in eight previous 
NCAA appearances. 
“ I know this sounds phony, hut it doesn't mean that much to me,” 
McGuire says of the title. 
“ We just p lay,” he says. “ Ifs not where you start. Ifs where we fin­ ish 

Porkers prevail 

F A Y E T T E V IL L E , 
Ark. 
(A P ) 
— 
Ferg 
M cNiel singled home 
Marc Brum le with the only run of the game in the fifth inning as Ar­ kansas trimmed South­ ern Methodist University 
1—6 in a Southwest Con­ ference baseball game 
Friday. 
Fat Anderson was the winning pitcher, taking his fourth victory in five decisions 
The victory left Arkan­ sas with a 5—5 SWC re­ cord and 21—8 record overall. The Mustangs slipped to 6—13 in the conference and 6—19 for the season.

Evert triumphs 

NEW VOUK (A P) - 
Top-seeded Chris Evert fought oil two set pointe 

 iii beating Virginia Wade ti*2, 7-5 Friday night for her second round-rohin victory in the $ 15o,ooo w o m e n ’s p r o fessio n a l tournament at Madison 
Square Garden 
T h ir d -s e e d e d 
Sue 
Harker, the rising British sta r , a lso raised her round-room record to 2-o, winning a tiebreaker for a 6-1, 7-H triumph over 
Kristien Shaw . 
M iss E v ert, playing lier impeccable baseline gam e, broke Ms Wade’s service twice in the first 

 set. But Ms. Wade, the 
No. 4 seed in the four-day to u r n a m e n t, offered more resistance rn the second set. 
She held a 5-4 lead and had the advantage twice, only to have Miss Evert even the game. The first time Ms. Wade hit a wide shot and the second time 
Miss Evert’s shot tipped the net and fell over for a winner 

Night g a rn et not included 
AH T im e t EST

W ASH IN G TO N (AIM 
— Two airline executives opposed legislation F r i­ day that would gi\(' air­ lines greater freedom for setting fares and make it easier for new companies to enter the business. 
And a banker said the uncertain^ about how the carriers would fare in a new competitive em 11- onment would make it difficult for them to ob­ tain needl'd financing for purchasing new aircraft 
Among those testifying before the Senate Avia­ tion subcomm ittee, whit'll is considering hills to revise airline regula­ tory procedures, were 
\rthur F 
Kelly, chair­ man and chief executive officer id' Western A ir­ lines; Harvey .I Wexler, senior vice president of 
Continental Air lanes, and Frederick VV Brad­ ley Jr., vice president of 
( itibank of New York. 
Kelly said proponents of deregulation envision lower fares and in ­ creased competition 

E X P R E S S A N ALY SIS 

MONDAY 
— The market eased lower at each hourly reading, with the 
Dow Jones Industrial Average posting a final loss of 7.48. Of the JU stocks making up the Dow average, one ad­ vanced — American Can, up a tiny '* 
Of the 29 losers, 2H fell back fraction­ ally. Chrysler made a new 1977 low 
Putting a damper on the market was a government report that new factory orders for durable goods rose less than 
It. I per cent in February. Cold stocks had their own private bull market, with Dome Mines and Campbell Bed 
Lake lint ll up a point 

T U E S D A Y — Hourly readings were 
4 to 5 points in the minus column but in late trading the D JIA bounced back and shaved the loss to 2.58 on the day 
Blue chips were well represented in the "15 most active list” (Coif Oil, off 
I 
Kodak, up I. Texaco, off 
Tele­ phone. off •'**, and Exxon, up th) illus­ trated continued "window dressing” by institutions for first quarter re­ ports 
Federal Reserve chairm an 
Burns stated that with business ex­ pected to expand, interest rates will rise. 

W E D N E S D A Y

8 64 In the market as a whole, declines led advances by almost two to one. On the most active list, 4o per cent of them were oil stinks — all down Sen. S. Korea debt rises 

SEOUL (AP) - South 
Korea's outstanding for­ eign debts totaled $5 8 billion at the end of 1976, up from $4.7 billion a year earlier, the govern­ ment economic planning board reported Friday. 

It said that Korea ob­ tained $7.8 billion in for­ eign loans from 1959 through 1976 and paid back $2 billion in princi­ pal, leaving the balance of $5 8 billion dollars

J A W T T e B a MAR I APR J 
Fuss 

N EW YO UK (A P ) - 
The stock market, brac­ ing for the end of the first quarter of 
1977 and weather-depressed profits, tumbled again 
Friday for the seventh straight session. 
The Dow Jones average of 3o industrials stocks, off 32.33 points in the last six sessions, fell another 
Ii SI to 928.86 Friday. 
Declines outpaced ad­ vances 9-5 i i i the overall tally on the New York 
Stock Exchange. 
Big 
Board volume reached inst 16.55 million shares, the smallest total since a 16.22 million- share day 
Feb. 
2H. 
Thursday’s volume was 
19.65 million 
In the afternoon Beth­ lehem Steel projected an unprofitable first quar­ ter. and the market, erratic most of the dav. gave way lo renewed selling. 
Blame 
Bethlehem blamed the first quarter decline on 
"... losses sustained its a result of operations (lur­ ing January and F e ­ bruary." 
After the an noun- mars 

 cement, trading in the stock was halted, with the last sale at 367x. down 
•Sc 
W all Street also is faced with the gov ern- menPs promised anti-in­ flation plan. C arter’s 
April 2o energy message and the threat of higher interest rates. 
‘‘The market par­ ticipants seem gripped in the perception of perdi­ tion,’" observed Robert 
Stovall of Reynold Secur­ ities. ‘‘They fear it might slow growth." 
Stovall, noting that on­ ly four trading sessions remained in the quarter, said money managers probably were moving toward greater liquidity and lower investment posture in stocks 
Shuffling 

‘‘There is some port­ folio shuffling." Stovall said. “ They want to show a more conservative profile and have more cash on hand on March 31 than thee did on Dec. 
31." 
As of the 4 p.m. close, 
Sony Corp. topped the 
N Y SE’s most active list. unchanged at IIM 4 fete 

Sperry Rand, one of the highest percentage 

 l o s e r s , dropped 31* to 
331, 
A HH),ooo-share block was traded at 37:V$. 
The company said the decline in its stock ap­ parently was an "em o­ tional reaction" to IBM s introduction of a new computer. ‘‘Our stock price has been hit this way every time IBM makes a major introduc­ tion," a company spo­ 

 kesman said. 
IBM was off 21k to 278. 

Burroughs also de­ clined. off 2*8 to HTV 
Polaroid went down :<j to 33. The company said in its annual report that engineers have developed a laboratory system ol instant motion pictures.

 arid 
S & P ’s 
5oo-stock composite index dropped 
.64 to 99.o6. 

The N Y SE’s composite index of all its listed common stocks was off 
.33 to 53.92. 
On the American Stock 
Exchange, the market value index dropped .15 

I I I 111 98 The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market closed at 95.28. tiff .26. 
Business and Finance 
H og, pig inventories could hold prices 

 the downtrend Sears profits rose 3o per cent, a record, in its latest quarter 

I H U R S D A Y — The market was in a nervous mood and continued its sixth straight day of decline for a total of over 32 points. The portions of Presi­ dent Carter’s press conference that affected the market (inflation and taxes) were not favorably received 
Half of tht* loss on the day came alter his conference. Loss on the day was 
Ii 65 

FRID AY — The mood of tin* day was a slow volume sell off, closing down 
6.81. bringing seven successive days of losses Volume of trading on the day at 
16.559,(Hit) was the slowest of the week, indicating lack of buying interest rather than selling pressure. Bethle­ hem Steel projected an unprofitable first quarter, which did not help bul­ lish sentiment 

SU M M ARY — The Dow Jones In­ dustrial Average broke through its 
February low and pulled back to its 
Nov 12 level on the chart pattern. The loss on the week was severe — 32.12 point* — the largest since the week ending Dec. 5. 1975. when the loss was 
41 87

The dispute over representation for the smaller countries — Hol­ land. Belgium. Luxem­ bourg, Denmark and 
Ireland 
— dampened celebrations on Rome's 
Capitoline Hill. where the accord that created the 
Common Market w a s signtd iii 1957, and later al the Quirinal presiden­ tial palace 

President 
V alery 
Giseard d’Estaing of 
France insisted the <’(mi­ nion Market need not he represented as such. while a Dutch govern­ ment spokesman said if the community as a whole is left out ol the 
London parity, it would deal a serious blow to 
“ the credibility of the 
European 
Economic 
Coinmunitv " 

Color issues 

The Dutch asked th.it the issue be settled "at un early stage.” A s p o ­ kesman said the outcome oi the dispute would color oilier issues before the leaders, including an economic slump w it lim the communis arid rela­ tions with tlii* Carter ad­ ministration and Japan 

Italian 
President 
Giovanni Leone, host at a gala birthday lunch, cau­ tioned the Western E u ­ ropean leaders "Ex per­ ience has shown that either we all move together or we do riot move at all 
We must, I repeat, all pull together." 

The UNDA had some good news for the consumer this week. 
It reported the. hog and pig inventory on March I was up 8 per cent over a year ago, with both hogs kept for marketing and those kept for breeding registering increases. 
Hog and porkbelly (ba­ con) futures prices were under considerable pres­ sure follow mg the release of the report. This pres­ sure spilled over to the cattle market which fell in sympathy. 
Based on the numbers for m arketing and breeding, ample supplies can be expected through next fall which should keep price competition at 

Bp 

COMMODITY 
REPORT 

 furnished bv Herald S. 
Cohn, vice president. sales division, 'van \n- tonio office, Bache Ilal- sev Stuart Inc. 

 the meat counter keen. 
The A griculture De­ partment also released revised supply-demand outlook estimates which 
Bus fares hike b lock ed 

 indicate ample to ade­ quate wheat and corn supplies but a tightening soybean situation. 
They reduced the fore­ casted carryover of beans to 65 million bushels, about 2 weeks usage and very close to the recent low of 59 million bushels in 1973. 
The report pushed soy­ bean prices to new life of contract highs, but subsequent liquidation in record trading volume eliminated the advance. 
The U SD A reduced estimates of the soybean meal carryout and in­ creased that of soybean oil. The latter provided much of the impetus to the failure of soybeans to hold those life of contract highs. 

W ASH IN G TO N (A P ) 
— In tercity bus fare raises that would have gone into effect Friday were blocked by the In­ terstate Commerce Com­ mission 
But the ICC said under certain conditions, it would approve tempor­ arily the same 6 per cent hike effective as early as 
Monday, 
The commission told the bus industry it can refile for the increase and receive it on a one- day notice, provided the boose expires May 3o In the meantime, the IFF said it would ask the in­ dustry to justify a full 13 per cent increase that it seeks. 
The industry said if the 
It F approved the interim 
6 per cent hike it had planned to request an additional 7 per cent raise May 13 
Ari IFF spokesman said the industry indicated it might refile as early as 
Merger nixed 

MONROE, ( onn. (A P ) 
— A proposed merger of the financially troubled 
Monroe Bank and Trust 
Co with the Bridgeport- based Lafayette Bank and Trust Co. has been rejected bv stockholders. 

Friday night for the 6 per cent .also lf so, it would go into effect Monday 
An IFF panel on Tues­ day approved the 6 per cent fare hike1. But the 
Justice Department filed an immediate appeal, asking the full commis­ sion to suspend the in­ crease for ut least two months. 
The commission said 
Thursday it opposed the two-step fare boost pro­ posed by the industry, and asked that by May I the industry justify the full package, 
"accom­ panied bv appropriate tariff schedules not to ex­ ceed 13 per cent." 

The b u s industry argues the extra money is needed to maintain terminals, to replace old buses and pay higher fuel costs. The Justice De­ partment maintains the bus owners have shown no evidence that an emergency exists, as the industry contends.

Louisiana eyes plan to tie oil, gas prices 

ATTRACT 

BOAT 

BUYERS. 
225-1666 

BATON B O E G E . La 
(A P) — Guv. Edwin Ed­ wards says hi' s con­ sidering a new approach that would tie natural gas prices to the price of oil and result in a significant windfall for louisiana 
Edwards sketched his unique approach to rais­ ing a considerable amount of money at a 
Mineral Law Institute at the 
LSI law school 
Thursday. 
His idea involves mea­ suring natural gas and oil in B IT ’*, the standard measure of heat, rather than iii barrels or cubic feet, then charging a set amount per 
BTU 
A thousand cubic feet of natural gas produces 

 about one-sixth the BT I s 
(British Thermal Units) of a barrel of oil. the governor said 
Edwards said he will ask the legislature to ap­ prove his plan, if there a re no legal problems associated with it. 
Ills plan would concern only the natural gas produced from state leases, and hi* said it might have to he limited to new gas. The state could enforce the pricing regulation by controlling drilling permits, wcll- w orkover permits and tire like. lie said. 
Oil a related topic, the governor said lie believes tile production incentive program of the Depart­ 

 ment ut Conservation is a failure and will probably be cancelled by the legislature

Jonah finally did God s bidding and went to preach to the people at Nineveh, and they repented from their evil ways, hoping that God would bo m erciful unto them And God showed mercy to the people of Nineveh. Jonah, however, was angered, and sat outside the city to see what would becom e of the city 
“And the Lord God prepared a gourd, and m ade it to com e up over Jonah, that it might be a shadow over his head, to deliver him from his grief So Jonah was exceeding glad of the gourd. But God prepared a worm when the morning rose the next day, and it sm ote the gourd that it withered ” (Jonah 4 6-7) 
Then said the Lord, Thou hast had pity on the gourd, for the which thou hast not laboured, neither m adest it grow, which cam e up in a night and perished in a night: And should not I spare 
Nineveh, that great city, wherein are m ore than sixscore thousand persons that cannot discern between their right hand, and their left hand: and also much cattle?" (Jonah 4:1o-11)

_ 

The legislature is in its perennial hassle in Aus tin over whether to legal­ ize gambling in Texas. 
This effort by the pro­ gambling forces centers note in a statewide vote and a constitutional amendment but in a local option approach. 
HB1499 which is in the 
Mouse Intergovernmen­ tal Affairs Committee and sponsored by Repre­ sentative B illy Hall of 
Laredo is known as the 
Texas Horse Racing Act. 
It asks for legalization of pari-mutuel gambling on a county local option vote. 
The lull is misnamed. 
It has nothing to do with legalizing horse racing in 
Texas. 
Horse racing has never been illegal in Texas. It continues to he legal. The 

 bill is a gambling bill. It has to do with legalizing pari-mutuel gambling iii 
Texas. 
Pari-mutuel gambling has been illegal ever since the business people rose up to defeat it back in the 193os. 
County lines 
The bill also Is built around a misconception that the effects of lega­ lizing gambling can be lim ited to the county lines within which that activity Is legal. Even a cursory glance at the practices of legalized gam bling and illeg al gambling in our nation makes this position untenable. 
One of the basic argu­ ments that the wealthy sportsmen who support this lull have been using 

SAN ANTONIO 

»> 
| 
I*". I 
‘ 
Jimmy R. 

Pastor. 
Fir si Baptist Church 

 is that 
Texas money from gambling devotees is moving to the tracks in New Mexico, Arkan­ sas. and Louisiana, lf the racetrack gambling ef­ fect is generated across state lines, how much more is it generated across county lines? 
The local option con­ cept was utilized to try to deal with the social and 

 legal controls over the dissemination of alcohol in our country. It has proved porous even in that setting. 
However, it would be impossible to lim it the damaging social effects of legalized gambling to a local option level of impact. 
Revenues 
The gamblers, sports­ men. and many of the poor who want to place their hope on some magic moment of deliverance from their plight by risking what little they have in wagering have been working assiduous­ ly to convince the citizens of Texas and their law­ makers that racetrack gam bling is simply, a beautiful sport of run­ ning horses. 
Their point is that peo* 

Dr. Allen lo visit tem ple 

Dr. Jim m y R. Allen, pastor of First Baptist 

 church, will speak at the “ First Friday" series at 8 p.m. Friday at Temple Beth-EI. 

Dr. Allen will speak on “ Evangelical ( hris- 

 tianity Confronts Judaism ", during the Sabbath 
Eve service. 

Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl will offer a pulpit 

 introduction to the subject from his rabbinical perspective. 

The “ First Friday’" series is sponsored • by 

 the Continuing Education Committee of Temple 
Beth-EI. 

 pie will gamble anyway and therefore legalizing gam bling at the track will somehow decrease the illegal gambling that the bookies have. They claim easy revenues for public projects can he skimmed off of the gam­ 

 bling money. 
The actual experience of states with the gam­ bling phenomenon, how­ ever. indicates that ille­ gal gam bling also in­ creases rather than de­ creases w herever gam ­ bling is legally and so­ 

 cially approved. It means that the promotion of the gam bling events in ­ crease the appetite of the poor and therefore victi­ mizes the weakest ele­ ment of society. 
It is a regressive tax concept that takes the position of skim m ing money from the people who can least afford to pay it through taxing gambling activities for public works. 

April 12 
The gambling bill will be heard in a hearing on the afternoon of Tuesday, 
April 
12. before the 
House Intergovernmen­ tal Affairs Committee 
Opponents of the le­ galizing of gambling are hopeful that the com ­ mittee will decide not to further complicate the 

 session with a highly emotional issue such as the legalizing of gam ­ bling while so many other more pressing public issues are being debated. 
Supporters are peren­ nially hopeful that the day will come that they will be able to wear out the reaistance of those who oppose the idea. 
Gravely concerned vo­ ters need to inform themselves about what the real impact has bei n 
•in the social conse­ quences of legalizing gambling. 
An oft quoted state­ ment by British govern­ mental philosopher E d ­ mund Burke is true — 
“ The only thing that's necessary for evil to pre­ vail is for good men to do nothing." “

This map shows the path San Antonio’s 4oth annual 
Home and G arden Pilgrim age takes this year. Five beautiful homes will be visited. Proceeds will benefit the 
Bridge, Jersig School of Communication Disorders, Re­ gional Children’s Heart Center and the San Antonio 

Council of Churches Film Library. The tours, sponsored by Christ Episcopal Church, will be held from noon to 6 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. Tickets are $2.5o and are available at each home on the tour.

Banquet will honor nun 

A banquet honoring 
Mother Mary Margaret 
Quevedo. M.C-M will be conducted following a 
Muss celebrated at ll a m. Sunday at ( ordi* 
Marian villa (off FM 471) west of Culebra Road, 
A donation of 55 will be collected at the event. 
Mother Quevedo is the formal superior of the 

Cordi-M arian Sisters, 
U S delegation. 
She lias done social work among the Mext- can-Americun people in 
San Antonio, beginning an educational program for the children of the barrios and opening 
Christ the King School. where she served as principal and instructor.

Ray Ellison 
Homes 

‘Last call’ for Royal Ridge patio homes 

This weekend will be the last in which Windcrest Develop­ ment Corp. can offer its excit­ ing, innovative Royal Ridge pa­ tio homes at their extended 1978 prices. 

Next month the prices of the patio homes in the northeastern Bexar 
County neighborhood must be higher; so, now is the time to act for those who want a contemporary residence and carefree lifestyle. 

Even models sold 

So popular have been these patio homes that even some of the models have been sold as more and more fa­ milies find the answer to owning a new home while maintaining nothing but the carefree lifestyles they enjoyed while renting an apartment. 

This particular Royal Ridge project is something that has to be exper­ ienced to be fully realized, and now, before the price increase becomes inevitable, is the time to view the models, professionally decorated by 
Mrs Hal wfentress 

The concept behind the patio homes in Royal Ridge, an established neigh­ borhood still growing and still on its way up. is that all tin* advantages of owning a home are featured along with the easy lifestyles usually associated only with apartment dwellers. 
W indcrest 
Developm ent Corp., co-owned by Bal and Tom Fentress, offers this concept in its twit-, three- and four-bedroom patio homes of one or two stories. 
There is a total of seven different floor plans offered among Royal Ridge patio homes. Some are modeled this weekend, decorated, color-coordinated and furnished. 
The models, each distinctively dif­ ferent, represent a price range from 
$44.(1o(1 to only $49,5oo. That s unusual for an array of homes ranging in size from two to three bedrooms But it can’t last beyond this month 
The term “ patio” applies to the name of these homes well 
A good portion of the backyard of each is a large patio with privacy fencing. Each patio is perfectly planned for the backyard, reasonably small to serve as 

R O Y A L RIDGE p a tio hom es announce that this w e e k e n d w ill be their last a t e x te n d e d 1976 p rice s starting as low as $ 4 4 ,o o o 

 the area separating tin* home from the completely finished, two-car garage. 
The frontyard for each patio home also is small, again reflecting on the m inim al m aintenance these patio homes need to allow residents more carefree leisure. Each yard, visitors will see at the model park, is carefully sodded and planted. 
The handsome exteriors of the patio homes are done in an off-white stucco with red tile trim, yielding a Contem­ porary Spanish flair to their designs. 
Cedar-shake shingles on their roofs enhance both the design and the con­ cept of the patio homes. 
The splendidly spacious interiors of 
Royal Ridge patio homes are well de­ picted by these models. All situated along Royal Ridge Drive, the models include the Aspen, with three be­ drooms, two baths in one story; Birch, three bedrooms, 217 baths, two stories; 
Laurel, two bedrooms, 2*a baths, two stories; and he Elm, two bedrooms, two baths, one story. The other model, the Cypress, is the largest, with four bedrooms, three baths and two stories 

 encompassing 2,o3o sq. ft of living area. 
Two other plans, the Mimosa and the 
Linden, also are offered as variations of others. 
The Mimosa resembles the Cypress plan, but is designed for three be­ drooms, one downstairs and two up­ stairs. The Linden is kin to the Laurel, but has three bedrooms upstairs 
Inside each model can be seen pre­ possessing, decoration, along with the ample extras each patio home fea­ tures. 
Extras include luxury appointments such as tiled entryways with guest closets, carpeting throughout, paneling, elegant light fixtures, simu­ lated marblctop vanities in decorator baths or dressing areas, dual access baths by complete compartmentaliza­ tion, pocket doors creating more useful floor space, huge double walk-in closets with guide-slide doors of hand­ some panel styles and abundant ca­ binetry in kitchens. 
Im m ediately im pressive is the 
"Great Room” featured in the Elm. 

This is an extra large living area which, as visitors will see, could be put to a number of different uses. The special plus of this room, though, is its wet bar to assure the variety of a r­ rangements 
Woodburning fireplaces are in each plan, and hidden utility areas are placed strategically for each. All gar­ ages have electronically-operated doors and storage areas. 
Certainly not to be overlooked is that each R o yal Ridge patio home is 
“ Energy-Crafted.” This means even more carefree living for residents, along with substantial savings in operating utilities. 
Energy-saving features include the cedar shake shingles, a plywood deck­ ing, thermostatically-controlled power vent fans in attics, rock wool and batt-insulatinn in walls and ceilings, styrofoam sheathing, extremely effi­ cient Fodders rotary-powered air con­ ditioning and meticulous sealing of all possible openings to keep any kind of drafts out. 
All this is offered by the Windcrest 

Development Corp Mal and Tom Fen­ tress together represent 5o years of experience in building. They take great pride in what they build, and their success can be seen in projects like the Crown Ridge Townhomes in 
Royal Ridge and and a number of su­ perior quality custom homes in Wind­ crest. Everything they built has in­ creased in value! 
Royal Ridge patio homes, of course, will be no exception. The arrangement for modern living here minimizes ex­ penditure. creates leisure and, at the same time, provides high-standard maintenance by membership in an owners association. 
Across the street from the models is a recreation center to which residents belong only if they want to. A large swimming pool, clubhouse with equipped kitchen, tennis courts and courts for other sports are among the amenities featured. 
Royal Ridge is ideally located in northeastern San Antonio, equi distant from Fort Sam Houston and Randolph 
A FB. Its quick access to N E. Ill 35 

 makes many other tnaior destination points short trips trom the residential arca. 
Although always quite and peaceful. 
Royal 
Ridge is surrounded by shopping facilities. Besides a good number of large shopping centers along Walzem Road, the new Windsor 
Park Mall is in its immediate vicinity. 
North East District school bus ser­ vice is prov ided for Windcrest E le ­ mentary, White Middle and Roosevelt 
High Schools. 
All utilities are underground, pre­ venting any eyesores that would ruin any resident’s view of the surrounding area. 
To view these patio homes before their prices increase, drive north on 
N E. Ill 35, exit right onto O’Connor 
Road and stay on O’Connor until you reach Royal Ridge Drive. Then follow 
Royal Ridge Drive past the Crown 
Ridge Townhomes to the model area just beyond the community recreation center. Signs lead the way, but a loca­ tor map is included in the Royal Ridgt advertisement inside this section.

Saturday M arch 26 197 7 
Fortuna opening new firm 
Marie C. Fortuna has announced the opening of 
F o rtu n a Associates, a new real es tate counseling firm located at 374o Colony Dr. 
The com pany is in­ volved primarily in real estate c«» t ult inc hut will specialize in residential and c o m m e rc i a l p ro ­ perties. 
Background 

Mrs Fortuna, serving as broker-d I rector for the now firm, obtained her broker's license in 1965 and, in I OHO, opened an office in t lit' Colonies 
North Mall, where she worked primarily with builders in sales of new homes. 
Iii I OHO, Mrs. Fortuna joined Fptmore & Asso­ c ia te s , and, in 1o72. she 

Oak Creek gives buyers their choices 

CLASUFM D O U TLA Y 

M A R IE C. FO R TU N A was named director of 
General Real E sta te, then an Up!more & As­ sociates division. 
Mrs. Fortuna holds a 
B A iii business from the 
University of Maryland. 
She also attended Tem­ ple University and the 
University of the IMnlli- pines. 
She is a member of the 
G re a t e r San 
Antonio 
Chamber of Commerce. 
San Antonio Board of 
Realtors and Greater San 
\ntonio Builders Asso­ ciation. She serves on the 
B u ild e r /R e a l to r Com ­ mittee of SABOR and the 
B u ild e r /B ro k e r Com* ll I ittee of (I SA BA 

 c l a s s i f i i d o i m 
» r 

A genuine Bill Country development of preferred homes and full city ser­ vices will be featured this weekend as Oak (reek in northw este rn 
Bexar 
County. 
Oak Creek is a c o m ­ munity from Homecraft 
Corp., now a majo r di­ vision of U.S. Home 
Corp. Its homes well befit the native oak trees and m ountain laurels that ca p tu re the whole romance of nature. 
Oak Creek stands out as a prim e example of professionally planned conimunitL.es which yield the best in modern living and definitely last­ ing, even incre asing home values. 
Conveniences 
In choosing the serene setting for Oak Creek, 
Homecraft was sure to preserve Mother Nature s own creations in a way which allows all city conveniences. Result- ingly. Oak Creek boasts 
CLASSIFIC DISPLAY 

 fully paved, curbed streets, all city utilities and even sidewalks. 
Homecraft always has displayed four fully fur­ nished, professio nally decorated model homes in the at • home - with nature neighborhood.

Wilderness by 
Wildwood 

, 
San Antonians who remember 
J/ ‘the good old days” recall when 
Bandera Road offered a semi­ wilderness trip to dude ranches, 
4 lit as tv pit barbecue and Saturday flig h t dancing to heel-kicking 
Country music. 
Today. Bandera Road still leads to 
11 of those things, in abundance, but. u ilderness has given wav. to some 
•xtent, as modern shopping centers. 
'Restaurants and specially stores have 
•^sprung up on the way, to Wildwood. 
—Mine of the most popular developments 
"Tnt the northwestern quadrant of Bexar 

County and by Texas largest home­ builder. Ray Ellison Hornes. 
Although Wildwood is readily acces­ sible to the growing commercial facil­ ities in the northwestern area, such as 
UTS A, I SAA and the South Texas 
Medical Center, its homes are outside the city lim its, providing lower monthly payments on new home in- vestinents ranging from the low $;ihs to the mid $4<ls. 
Wildwood homes retain the wilder­ ness touch, surrounded by tree-cov­ ered slopes and wooden horizon. 
Fireplaces in most Wildwood homes recall the rustic touch of country liv­ 

 ing. bringing warmth and cheer to the brisk evening air. 
Children and teenagers of Wildwood families attend the excellent schools of tin* Northside District with educational programs that not only in still the 
“ three ll s." but also offer rich and diverse ex tracurricu lar programs which emphasize leadership and ini­ tial i n c . 
Wildwood kitchens are designed for beauty and functional convenience. All are fully equipped with dishwashers, disposers, ranges with self-cleaning ovens and range vents plus fine quality wood cabinets which typify the fine

Bv FRA N K M A M P E L L I 
PRESIDENT. GBE ATEF S A Bl HIDERS ASSO CIATION 
A re-you delaying until to m o r­ row buying the new home you need tod ay? It could be the c o s t l i e s t d e c i s i o n you e v e r made! 
If you’re hesitating in the hope that interest rates w ill return to the level of the good old days. forget it. Buy now. 
The continuing pressures of land, materials and labor costs tend to force prices up. Home sale prices have in­ creased from a median of $18.mill in 
1965 to about $42,ooo today. Land costs continue to rise — at about 25 per cent a year. W hat is the ra tio n a le fo r waiting? 
P u ttin g your money into the p u r­ 

 chase of a new home would probably result in a gain for you through in ­ creased valuation in both house and land. 
Suppose, fo r exam ple, th a t you should buy a $56,ooo home Based on a 
2o per cent down payment and a IO per cent mortgage loan for 25 years, you would be making monthly payments of 
$262 Taxes, insurance and upkeep m ight add $9o to $1oo per month to your m onthly housing expenditure. 
But, in the first year of ownership, the income tax savings on interest and real estate taxes, as well as equity gained in the home, could amount to about $85 per month — dropping the net monthly cost to about $275 
Your home, meanwhile, is increas­ ing in value, making your monthly in­ vestment even better.

Bowling joins 
Summit 
Al Parker , president of 
S u m m i t M o r t g a g e Co., has announced that Mike 
Bowling has joined th** c o m p a n y as a te r rit o ry m anage r fur the residen­ tial loan division 
His arrival at Summit e n la rg e s the c o m p a n y ’s production staff and in ­ c r e a s e s its t e r r i t o r y m anagers lo three 
‘Excellent choice’

Bowling i \ an expansion move in keeping with our gro w th and i n c r e a s i n g v o l u m e . " said P a r k e r

Mortgage ('n in Lexing­ ton and. for the past six years, has been involved with v a r i o u s p h a s e s of mortgage han king." 
Summit began o p e ra t­ ing in J u n e , 1B7B w it Ii four empl oyes. Bowling brings that n u m b e r to KL

S u m m i t th e y o u n g e s t , f a s t e s t - g r o w i n g m o r t ­ g a g e loan c o m p a n y in 
San Autumn.

B o w lin g a n d h a v e p r o ­ vided competent, profes­ sional s e r v i c e , " P a r k e r added.

Kentucky and received a 
B A. in political science and R u s s i a n f r o m E a s ­ tern Ken tu ck y U niv ers i­ ty. His wife Linda is an a r t te a c h e r for San A n ­ tonin School District. The couple has one son. They are m e m b e r s of Trinity 
Baptist C hu rch and a r r active in Cub Scouting
