"on't he surprised if someone tells you how great your Great America nome looks. Because at 
Great America, we believe you can see the difference quality makes. 
In our garden kitchens, with handfimshed cabinets and top quality appliances. In our roomy living areas, with vaulted cathedral ceilings, built-in bookcases and woodburn- ing fireplaces. In our lavish ceramic tile baths, with marble vanities and decorator appointments. 
Even in our generous mas­ ter suites, with private baths and walk-in closets. 
Everywhere you look, there is careful attention to design, styling, practi­ cality and energy-effi- ciency. 
But that's only the in­ side story. Outside, Great 
America homes arc strik­ ingly individualistic. Each home is designed for its particular homesite. Some are traditional, others reflect the informality of 
California styling. Some have soaring rooflines, 

 cedar trim and second- story balconies. Others are simple, yet elegant. 
But all are equally suited to entertaining and day- to-day family living. 
You'll find these really great homes in San 
Antonio's finest com­ munities. In Northwest 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Park f orest, 
Hidden Creek, forest Oak 
Estates, and now, 
Elm Creek. In North 
San Antonio, we have new homes in Thousand 
Oaks, The Oaks in 
San Pedro Hills, and 
Hidden Forest. Each community is minutes excellent schools, 
**iaior shopping and employment centers. 
Prices range from the upner-4o's to $1oo,ooo. 
Visit these fine com­ munities today and look for our new red, white and blue signs. For additional information on a particu­ lar community, call 
69o-o3oo. The really great homes in San Antonio are 
Great America homes, lust ask any of our home­ owners. a GREAT AMERIO A 
The really great homes in San Antonio. 

42o4 Gardendale, Suite .1o2, 69o-o3oo, Headquarters tor Great America Construction Co.

Apartments built for most privacy 

Ray Keuthan joins Fortuna 

RAY KEUTHAN 

Hay 
Keuthan has joined the new real estate consulting firm of Fo r­ tuna /Associates, 374o Co­ lony Dr., as a real estate agent specializing in re­ sidential properties and government 
- owned homes. 
Keuthan obtained his real estate license in 19H9 and has a total of eight years of experience with several real estate com­ panies in San Antonio. In 
1o75. he joined Marie C. 
Fortuna at General Heal bistate, then a division of 
Bpt more & Associates. 
Keuthan holds a B S degree in Science and 
Mathematics from Flori­ da Southern College in 
Lakeland. Fla. lie also has taken business courses at St. M ary's t'mversity in San Antonio. 

 c u t i s * lf D DISM AY 
C U m W I O DISM AY 

A quiet, mature envir­ onment emphasizing pri­ vacy uncommon to apartment living can be found at Maison de Ville. 
The little touches or 
“ extras" that shift the emphasis from simple functionality to pamper­ ing luxury are provided here for people who enjoy apartment living. 
Premises 
Planned for privacy, the specially landscaped grounds include private courtyards with secluded walkways, special spaces for relaxation and an abundance of trees, shrubs and green belts which lend a garden-like setting to the grounds. 
Large play areas with playground equipment for children are set apart, maintaining fami­ ly as well as adult pri­ vacy, Entertainment fa­ cilities include a two- story private clubhouse, complete with game room and an O lym pic­ sized swimming pool ex­ clusively for residents and their guests 
All apartm ents have either private balconies or patios for outdoor re­ laxation or for those who enjoy wonderful “ green space" planting areas. 
Designed and built with im agination, the apartments themselves offer n in n y spec i m I “ ex­ tras" such as Woodburn* mg fireplaces built-in bookcases and wood- paneled living areas. In­ teriors also feature an­ electric kitchens, pass­ through bars and separ­ ate bath and dressing ar­ eas in master suites. 
Spaciousness is appar­ ent in every residence, from efficiency to one-, two- aud three-bedroom apartments. In addition, several luxurious town* 

 are large outdoor storage spaces and covered parking fur each apart­ ment: guest parking is abundant: and daily trash pickup is provided 
Maison de Ville offers a professionally managed em ironment of well con­ structed. beautifully de­ 

 signed apartment resi­ dences. 
Located at 1ooo Jack- son-Keller Rd in the choice North East School 
District. Maison de Ville provides luxury, conven­ ience. economy and prestige as well as an at­ mosphere of priv acy

CLA SS IC O DISM AY 
CLASSICO DISMAY 
CLASSIFIED D IS M A Y 

Loan market surveyed 

The Departm ent of 
Housing and Urban De­ velopment has an ­ nounced the results of the 
March I opionion survey on conditions in the mortgage market. 
Nationally, the average secondary market price for immediate delivery of 
IU'D/FHA-insured 8 per cent, new-home m ort­ gages with 3o-year terms and minimal down pay­ ments decreased seven- tenths of a point to $9H I per $1oo of outstanding loan amount. 
This increased the equivalent gross yield to investors to 8'd per cent. a gain of IO basis points from a month earlier and a total gain of 25 basis points in the past two 

 months. 
For the fifth consecu­ tive survey, the percen­ tage of HUD field offices reporting funds which were generally adequate for financing Section 
2o3(b) loans remained at 
o7 per cent. In March. 
197K, the percentage also was reported at the same lev el 
Following two conse­ cutive months in which national average interest rates contracted to be paid by the borrowers on conventional first mort­ gage loans had declined, the rates, as of March I. were unchanged from 
Feb. I at 8.8 and 8.85 per cent for new- and exist- mg-home sales respecti­ vely.

Located practically at the front door of UTSA, USAA and the medical complex, University Oaks is a neighborhood covered with trees you would be proud to call home. Designed for activity families, this community features a swim club for residents. Owens Co.’s North 
Central office moves 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 26 I 9 7 7 

Robert F. Owens Sr . president of 
Dean ie 
Owens Co., Realtors, has announced the opening of a new location of the 
North Central Office at in n NAV. Loop 41o. 
The office is owned by 
Phil Grubbs and Je rry 
Holloway and managed by Grubbs. The opening was m arked by recent 
Open House festivities. 
According to Grubbs. 

 the move was prompted by growth in both sales and staff. 
“ We have had such tremendous sales and have increased our staff steadily for the past two y e a rs ," 
Grubbs de­ clared. “ We simply out­ grew our previous facili­ ty. We wanted an office that would not only give use room for expansion but also would represent 

 us well. 
“ Our new location is ideal. It has high visibi­ lity and easy accessibili­ ty, and the building is both attractive and func­ tional." 
In addition to a sales a r ‘a and executive of­ fices, the building has a reception area, private closing areas, a kitchen and a second floor with space for meetings and 

 classes. 
"And. it has a warm, h o rn e -1 i k e appe a ra nc e and stmosphere which will make our customers feel at hom e," said 
Grubbs. 
Owens added, “ E v e r­ yone is pleased with the new office. Not only does it appeal to customers, but the sales staff is de­ lighted to be working in such surroundings.”

Allen Janson residence just behind Basket Nur­ sery. If you still don t know how to get there. call my office at 22o-2774. 

Every once in a while, something really special comes along. 
Tucked away in the ci­ ty of Windcrest are the only apartments that will ever be there. 
Exclusive 
Windcrest Apartments’ residents have exclusive enjoyment of a commun­ ity room for gatherings or just relaxing by the large swimming pool. 
Luxurious apartments also play key roles in making W indcrest un­ ique. 
Attractively decorated, these splendidly spacious apartments are available either furnished or un­ furnished. Four floor j plans include one-be- 

CLAtSIFIfD DrtALAT 

 droom and two-bedroom flats and two-bedroom townhouse styles with or without a den 
Fedders central heat and air conditioning un­ its keep the apartments comfortable throughout the seasons. Windcrest residents also enjoy the conveniences of electric appliances in the apart­ ment kitchens. U tility bills’ costs are included in the monthly rates. 
Especially pleasing to the eye, in a number of ways. is the arrangement of 
W indcrest 
A p art­ ments.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday March 26 1977 
How to inlay graft pecans 

C L M H H I P DISPLAY 
J^ U ^ yF IE O m P lA Y , 
C LASSIFIED Of S P I A Y 

Bv T E R R Y Wll BOI RN 
C O U N T Y EX TEN SIO N HORTICULTURIST 
Now is Hie time of the year to think about going out and graft­ ing that seedling pecan tree in your back yard that will be worthless, or perhaps you just want to change varieties. 
The follow alg informal ion on inlay grafting is taken from an Extension 
Service publication written by Blan­ ford G. Hancock, horticulturist at 
Texas A&M I niversity: 
Original method 

"Inlay grafting is one of the best and most popular systems of propagating pecans now in use. Grafting was tile original method emploxed bv Antoine, the gardener, in Louisiana in lK4"i He is credited as the first to successfully propagate pecans. 
"The inlay bark graft is simpl> a refined procedure that has proved to have definite advantages over the old standard bark graft. 
"The Texas method of inlay graft­ ing. initiated iii the bialis, follows most basic fundamentals of the standard inlay graft procedure blit employs an entirely new system of covering the graft and stock Aluminum foil pro­ vides the base cover, reflecting sun­ light and reducing temperatures ar­ ound the inlay. Plyethylene plastic film, the filial cover, assures constant high relative humidity around the in­ lay 
"This system not only results i i i a higher percentage of growing grafts but is easy to use All equipment ne­ cessary to do the job can be carried in an apron since the need for a burdensome was melter is eliminated. 
"Anyone tan do inlay grafting by following instructions and practicing to develop skill rn basic techniques 
"Here is a description of the steps to follow: 
•Esc pecan trunks or side limbs iv. to 3 * 2 inches in diameter. Leave one or two side branches below cut to keep tm* v igorous, to protect from sunscald and to keep graft from overgrowing. 
( ut straight across trunk or limb with sharp saw at a intuit above a section 

 where tin' trunk or limb is straight. 
Make cut seven or eight feet above ground if cattle or horses are grazing in pecan grove. 
•Select a section of stock with a flat surface sn the flat cut surface of graft stick will fit securely. Choose a spot on the south or southwestern side so pre­ vailing wind will blow grail into the iris- instead of away. Cut a clean shield by removing a thin layer of the rough outer bark Leave the bark as thick as possible so as to hold the graft secure­ ly. 
•Collect graftwood of desired variety in late February or early March while tree is dormant Secure one-year wood 
Lj- to U-inch in diameter. Select smooth, straight wood with two or three plump buds at each node Keep graftwood in cold storage until the day it is used Cut graftstiek with two or three strong buds and at least six niches long for easy handling. 
•Esc a knife with a sharp grafting blade. Hold knife firm ly aud with a level trajectory make a smooth, straight cut I! 1 2 to ‘t1 2 inches long. 
Skirt the cut about three inches from the bottom of the graft on the opposite side and a little below the lowest bud. rills 'insurance bud’ is iii a reserve position A slanting shoulder o f1, to of an inch long will allow graft to be set iii an upright position. The shoulder or slanting cut extends about half the distance through the graft stick: the remaining level cut is the same thick­ ness from the edge of the shoulder to the end of the graft stick. Make the entire surface of cut smooth and level 
Avoid a wavy surface. Turn the graft stick over and make a chisel-shaped cut about *2 to 1 1 of an inch long on the. hack side of the lower end. This makes it easier to insert graft and provides more uniting surface. 
•Place cut surface of graft against shaved shield on stock. Allow > ,- to 
•■2-inch cut surface shoulder to extend above stock. Hold graft firmly upright with left thumb Begin out at top of stock on the right side of graft. Cut through hark down to the wood. Draw knife blade straight down the right side to within •**- to a4-mch of the bot­ tom portion of the graft 
•Hold graft firmly in position with thumb of right hand Do not allow graft 

 rn, 

TERRY WILBOURN to move after first side cut is made. 
•Make the cut on tin’ left side of the graft identical to the cut on the right side. 
•Two parallel cuts through hark form an inlay pattern This inlay pat­ tern should be exactly the same size as the lower section of the graft. 
•Peel hack the inlay flap of hark >2 to an inch between two parallel cuts. 
Start chiseled end of graft into slot with the level cut flat against wood of tile stock. 
•Press the flap of hark against the graft with the thumb of the right -hand to hold graft firmly in the inlay slot 
Apply firm pressure on top of graft to force it into inlay slot 
•Push graft into inlay slot until the 

• 4 - to t^-inch cut surface of the shoulder is above the top of the stock 
This cambium around the hark of cut surface will form a callus roll that will cover the top of the stock and anchor the graft securely to the stock. 
•Remove about half of the flap ol hark with the grafting knife. 
• Secure the graft by use of two 
18-gauge wire nails. >2 to :<j of an inch long. Drive the nails carefully with a tack or small hammer. Place one nail through the flap of hark and into graft just above chiseled surface. Place one nail through graft near the top of the stock. 
•Take an eight*. IO- or 12-inch square of aluminum foil; tear or cut a line down to the center of the square. 
Fold the aluminum foil square around stock so that the bottom of the tear fits right under the insurance bud.’ 
•Fold each side of the divided end of the square of aluminum foil Cover all cut surfaces with the foil, including the overlap shoulder of the graft. Crimp the foil to form a loose mold around tin1 stock. 
•Cut off one corner of a pint- or qiiart-size polyethylene hag to make a hole at that point. Slip the hag over the graft and work tin* graft through the hole. Pull tin* hag down gently until the cut corner rests just below the insur­ ance bud.’ 
•Tie the polyethylene hag at the cut corner around the graft and just below the ‘insurance bud’ and above the cut surface of the overlap shoulder. Tie with a rubber hand. small rubber budding strip or polyethylene tape so that the graft will not suffer girdling damage.

Poge 13-D 
Tables turned on writer 

HOLLYWOOD Columnist Marilyn Beck, shown with Wil­ liam Holden, will be hostess of “ Hollywood Out-Takes,“ an Oscar-oriented special at 9 p.m. Sunday on KMOL-TV 

Hollywood columnist 
Marilyn Beck bad the ta­ bles turned on her re­ cently. 
Instead of seeking answers to questions she would ordinarily be ask­ ing in an interview for her column. Marilyn was doing the answering. 
This all came about because of an idea for a television show the co­ lumnist had. 
I have sat in hundreds of interviews with Mari­ lyn when our targets have been actors, ac­ tresses. producers, directors, etc. I knew this would be fun talking to 
M arilyn about 
H ER show. 
And it was. “ Hollywood 
Out-Takes’’ will be show n Sunday evening at 
9 on KMOL-TV. The hour-long special, which was M arilyn ’s brain­ child, will feature never-before-seen out­ takes from Academy 
Award nominated filrps. 

O n the A ir 
Bv LEONA PAPPAS 
TV' Editor 

The Academy Awards presentation will be 
Monday evening and will be broadcast * over 
KSAT-TV, beginning at 
9. 

Hostess 

Marilyn will serve as hostess in a program that w ill feature bits and pieces of film which had to be cut from movies for one reason or another — mostly comical blunders. 
Her guests include W il­ liam Holden, nominated for 
Best 
Actor for 
“ Network” ; Sylvester 
Stallone, nominated for 
Best Actor for “ Rocky ”; 
Randy 
Quaid, from 
“ Bound For Glory” ; Burt 
TV LISTINGS

FLIGHT ’77 - "The Mil­ lionaire: The Story of

West and Gordon take on a band of counterfeiters who have robbed the mint of plates used to print money.

“ The

Young from “ Rocky,” 
•and Jon Peters. 
Out-takes will come from such movies as 
“ Network 
Rocky.” 
“ All the President’s

For

“ A 
Star is 
Born.’’ “ Taxi D river,” 
“ Marathon Man,” “ Lo­ gan’s Run," “ The Pink 
Panther Strikes Again” and “ The Omen.” 

Education 

“ Not only was it a lot of fun," said M arilyn, in answer to a question about putting this show together, “ but a marve­ lous education. Even sit­ ting in the cutting room. 
It taught me to empath­ ize with people involved in the business. 
“ We have just com­ pleted the taping." the columnist continued. 
“ We did three tapings. 
And it looks like it will be a good show. It seems like such a natural. It’s 
Hollywood with its ma­ keup off. 
“ There is certainly in­ terest in what the stars are really like. People want to know.” 
Marilyn said she was 
“ kibitzing with Jack 
Lemmon when the idea came. I got home and thought about it. The more I thought, the more 
I felt that it would make a tremendous show. So I started to work on it.” 

Not easy 

It wasn’t the easiest job to get what she wanted for her show, M arilyn admitted “ The out-takes was just a tremendous challenge to collect,’’ she said “ I naively thought they would just be sitting there. This was not so. I had to go through roll after roll of film. 
“ Then it took a lot of persuasion, a lot of talk­ ing to be able to use what 
I had. When the coopera­ tion started, it snow­ balled." 
All the movie clips and guests you will be seeing on this special show to­ morrow night are from 
.Oscar-nominated movies w ith the exception of one. 
That person is Bob Hope, 
America’s beloved come­ dian. and the world’s most famous Oscar non- nominee. 
Though 
Hope was never nominated for an 
Academy 
Award, he received an honorary Os­ car in 1952 for his service to the motion picture in­ dustry. Hope was also presented the Jean Her- sholt 
Humanitarian 
Award in 1959 

Columnist 

It was in 1967 that 
Marilyn Beck wrote her first syndicated column as Bell McClure’s Hol­ lywood columnist and 
West Coast Bureau Chief 
Three years later she was named Sheila Graham’s successor. 
In 1972, the writer joined The New York 
Times Syndicate. The 
M arilyn 
Beck’s 
Hol­ lywood column is carried in papers around the country. 

Following in her mother’s footsteps is daughter Andrea. An­ drea now has her own syndicated column. 
When asked how it worked with mother and daughter, Marilyn re­ plied. “ It is great. We have been working to­ gether a year and a half now. A lot of people warned us against it be­ cause our relationship with each other had been so good. But the associa­ tion has proven to be great. I couldn’t be more pleased." 

Umberto Giordano’s opera, “ Andrea Chen­ ier,” will be broadcast today at I p.m. on radio station KMAC. 
Singing principal roles will be soprano Martina 
Arroyo as Maddalena. mezzo-soprano Lib Choo- kasian as Madelon, tenor 
Placido 
Domingo as 
Andrea Chenier and bar­ itone Cornell MacNeil as 
Gerard Jam es Levine will conduct. 
* * * 
ABC 
Sportscaster 
Chris Schenkcl has been named honorary national chairman of the fund raising campaign for the 

National Bowling Hall of 
Fame and Museum. 
Sehenkel has been the announcer on “ Profes­ sional Bowlers Tour’’ since the series began in 
1962. 
He will head a group of 
Jfour national co-chair­ men and a 16-member honorary campaign ca­ binet in the drive to raise money for the new facili­ ty, a project being co­ sponsored by the Amer­ ican Bowling Congress and the Women’s Inter­ national Bowling Con­ gress. The site for the museum is yet to be de­ cided. 

Come Tuesday even­ ing. viewers will be able to see another of those fast-paced, musical spe­ cials with the glamorous 
Mitzi Gay nor. 
“ Mitzi 
Zings into 
Spring,’’ can be seen on 
KENS-TV at 9. 
On my most recent visit to Los Angeles, Mit­ zi and her husband. Jack 
Bean, were hosts at a party at Chasen’s for the press. She hopped from table to table, posing for pictures and making everyone feel it was a 

 or special evening just ? them. 

 k k k 

The James Anderson family is about to be reunited. 
This is the Anderson family of 195o-Bfts tele­ vision fame. 
Robert Young and Jane 
Wyatt were cast as par­ ents of Betty (Elin o r 
Donahue), Bud (B illy 
Gray) and Kathy (Lauren 
Chapin) in the series which ran several sea­ sons, then went into syn­ dication and continued in reruns. 
NBG has ordered a 
9o-minute television movie starring the ori­ ginal cast members It will be the first time they have worked together since tho series went out of production. 
Young, winner of two 
Emmy Awards for his work in “ Father Knows 
Best," has continued to be active in television and most recently starred in the long-run­ ning “ Marcus Welby, 
M D " on ABC. 
The basis of the 
9o-minute movies is a 
35th wedding anniver­ sary party for the Ander- sons.

Your 
Health 
By George C. 
Thosteson, M.D. 

Achalasia cause is not known 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: What kind of disease is called “ achalasia” ? Can you describe tin* cause and treatment for it? I never heard of it before — H G.A. 

Pronounced ‘‘A-ka-LAY-zha.’’ the word means 
“ failure to relax.” In medicine, it describes the inability of tile lower two-thirds of the gullet to propel food downward in response to the act of swallowing. 
The cause is not known. It is a distur­ bance in the nerve con­ trolling the gullet mus­ cles. The problem can occur at any age, but is most common between 
3o and 5o. 
It usually develops slowly. Victim s may have more difficulty swallowing cold foods than hot foods and, strangely, solid foods are usually swallowed more easily than liquids. 
Because it interferes with the orderly passage* of food into the stomach there is great discomfm t and often regurgitation into the upper gullet, especially at night while lying down. Achalasia is diagnosed bv X rays 
Treatm ent 

Conservative treatment consists of small bland, low-bulk meals eaten slowly The patient should not lie down for two hours after eating. Dilation of the lower gullet is often effective, widening the outlet of the esophagus into the stomach. A relatively new technique called “ hydrodilation” has been effective. 
In cases not responding to dilation surgery is necessary, and it has a high degree of success 
As with many of smooth muscle disorders, anxiety and emotions can trigger an attack. 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: Out of curiosity I'd like to know how aspirin helps relieve arthritis pain. Do you have material on arthritis? — .I II. 
Since the cause of arthritis is not really understood, how various drugs affect it exactly is not quite clear. Aspirin has an anti-inflammatory effect similar to cortisone, l oo, it d u lls pain centers iii the brain. 
I dill find an interesting note iii an issue of the bulletin of the I tall Arthritis Foundation, which crossed my desk recently. It involves research at the 
I diversity of I tall Medical Center's Arthritis Di­ vision that b e a rs on your question. 
Researchers report that inflammation from arth­ ritis produces what is called a “ superoxide" (a damaging oxygen product) and that aspirin and other substitutes break down this substance into compounds that are less harmful, thus reducing fever aud pain. The booklet. “ How to Control Arth­ ritis.” will suggest sensible ways to deal with the problem For a copy, semi 'IS cents and a stamped, self-add cessed envelope to me care of this newspaper, 
Constipation 

Dear Dr. Thosteson What is your view of epsom salts for relief of constipation? — Mrs CFD. 
It is too harsh oil the system. The effect is to force the colon to extra activity by irritating its lining. 
( out inned use can cause colitis, far worse than the original problem 
Ifs better to get sufficient liquids along with some fruits and vegetables for bulk These allow one to make headway with most constipation problems 
And what do you mean by “ constipation '? Doctors are often confronted by patients complaining about constipation after having missed a movement for a couple of days. The fact is that movements every single day are not necessary to good health. Vet so many get on the laxative bandwagon because of a couple of days without one. lf tins shoe fits, wear it 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: Why do you hear so much about the danger of children being overdosed with iron supplements? Are they more apt to retain it. or what? — D.S. 
Ifs strictly a matter of weight 
Iron overload can occur i ii adults a s well as in children. Your answer lie s iii the fact that children are smaller, and some people don’t take this into consideration iii giving supplements. A dosage in­ tended for a IM-pound body will amount to a double dose for a 75-pound youngster. 
This applies to other medicines and supplements. 
That s the rea so n manuiacturers list adult aud chil­ dren's dosages on labels 
W h a ! about co n stip atio n ? M an y can be relieved a t it, bath mentally and physically, by reading Dr Thosteson s booklet, 
The 
W a y to Stop Constipation for a copy write to him in care a l thu newspaper, enclosing a long, sell addressed, stamped envelope

I t ’s hard to keep so 

 mrthing like the Tower of the Xmerieas secret and almost as hard to keep its financial situation secret. 
There has been no at­ tem pt to hide the fact that the tower has been operating in the red for several years. 
The revenues from 

 rental of the restaurant area and concession fees and other income more than pay for the opera­ tional costs of the big tourist attra ctio n , hut ihov are not sufficient to pax the payments on the debt incurred for its con­ struction — w hich is what was promised when the tower was built. 
The am ount of the 

 shortfall changes from ye ar to year. In this year’s budget, there will 

 he a $?9§,OOO surplus of revenue after the c ity pays the tower s operat­ ing expenses. Bu t the debt s e rvice this y e a r will he $423,962 for pay­ ments on the principal and interest for the con­ struction. 

'(h at m eans about 

$127,ooo to pay off the lower this vear will have to come from city pro­ perly taxes.

 secret about it at alt. A call to City Hall turned up that information and the status of the tower’s op erations has been

S.A. native is producing apples, plays 

BY EVE LYNN SAWYER 

Eloise McAllister, youngest of the four children of the W . W . 
McAllisters Jr., is visiting for a couple of weeks from her fruit farm in New Mexico near Taos. 
It s really busin ess th at b r i n e s 
Eloise to San Antonio. She is the pro­ ducer for the Magic Mirror Players of 
Taos. Her com pany will perform a spoof of “ Jack and the Beanstalk” in the River City T heater at 9:3o p.m. 
Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. 
Producing plays is a new sideline for 
E loise in the past 18 m onths. Her friend, Cynthia McFarland, was asked to direct melodrama theater in 1975. 
She asked Eloise to produce the plays. 

Says Eloise, “ Growing up in my fa­ mily, I learned about public relations. 
It was an intuitive understanding that I developed and I had it to call upon when I needed it. I'm blessed with my mother s organizational talents." 

Organic 

Eloise has her three-acre organic fruit ranch in the Rinconada Valley for four summers. She produces the only organically grown apples and peaches in the area, and sells all of her fruit to 

 ill who, 
What, 
Where 

O N THE SOCIAL SCENE 

 people who ask to buy. She also raises horses. 
‘‘When I sold my fru it in th e 
F arm ers’ Market, I had people drive back for a second lug after they tasted the first one. I don’t use chemical sprays or chemical fertilizer, and it makes a real difference in the taste.” 
Irrigation water for the trees comes from the Rio Grande River. Some of her friends from the theater company have helped her irrigate and harvest the fruit in previous seasons. 
This summer, Eloise isn t expecting a fruit crop because the cold weather froze ail the buds. So, she plans to add onto her house . 

Swimming 

“ I live on the river, and the swim­ ming holes there make it like South­ west Paradise. I love it and plan to continue both my fruit farming and my theater work.” 
After the San Antonio performances of the pleasantly shocking m usical 
“ Jack and the Beanstalk," Eloise will take it to Austin for perform ances 
Friday and next Saturday. 
Before she returns lo her ranch, she w ill visit with her brothers and sisters. 
Taddy, who lives and works in Wa­ shington,, I). C. Walter III (Bo), and 
Keagin. 
Eloise also plans a visit at Port 
Aransas. “ I miss the Gulf of Mexico the most living in New Mexico.” 
Before moving out West, 
Eloise graduated from Alamo Heights High 
School and attended the University of 
Texas. 

ICW Grit‘ans 

STS 

 e l o is e M cA ll ist e r 
...visiting her h om e tow n 

Mr. and 
Mrs. 
Gordon 
George have recently returned from trips. Sin* was in New Orleans visiting her sister, 
Mrs. Gus Weber, while he was attend­ ing a meeting of representatives of major museums at Harvard. George represented the Witte M useum as trustee 

The group was feted at the Harvard 
Faculty Club and other showplaces. 
From one of the museum adm inistra­ tors in Washington, George learned that spectators waited in line one hour to get inside the Egyptian Exhibit of 
King Tut s Tomb. 
Triple treat awaits diners 

“ I ’m Italian, my wife is 
Cuban—and we were married in 
C uba—and I know som ething about Spanish foods,’’ explained 
Gian Carlo Pavesi about his restaurant specializing in three types of cuisine. 
Paella is the specialty of the house at 
Gian Carlo’s Restaurant, 18o8 Freder­ icksburg Rd. 
Since it is only offered for two 
($14.5o), my husband aud I decided to skip it so we could taste two different dishes 

We ordered instead V eal Scaloppine 
Marsala ($4 5o) and Steak a la Gian carlo ($o.25), learning later that those also are favorite entrees with Pavesi and his clientele 

The night we dined there, we noticed almost everyone was speaking Span­ ish. and the restaurateur says it is true that many of his custom ers are his 
Cuban and Spanish friends. 

Iii addition to the food, they no doubt enjoy the pleasant atmosphere of the restaurant with its black wrought iron tables and chairs, perky red and white table cloths and a sincere attempt at attentive s e n ice. 
Entertainment 
()n Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights, customers are entertained by 
Mike Navel and his “ one-man band” show. 

Gian Curio’s has the kind of menu that encourages making an evening of it. 

Antipasti ranges from Prosciutto and 
Meiotic at $1.5o to Clams Oreganate at 
$2 75 

Salads include a Ceasur salad for two at $2 25. Italian salad for 75 cents and asparagus salad for $1.25, 

Soups include minestrone for 7o cents and culdo de polio con fideos at 65 cents. 

The rest of the menu includes pizza, fish dishes, pasta, desserts, beverages and the two from which we ordered— 
Plutos Ltttinoamericunos and Primi 
Blatti. 

Where to go 
What to eat 

B> Jane I Ihrich 

The thing we enjoyed most about our dinner was a side dish of Arroz Blanco with Frijoles Negros that we ordered not because we needed more food but because we like Cuban black beans so much and wanted to taste their version. 

( I i i fact, we had tried to order this as an appetizer, but our Spanish waiter didn t understand and brought them with our dinner.) 

The veal dish was made with thin-cut and fork-tender slices of meat in a mushroom-wine sauce. 
Steak dish 

The steak dish included a generous portion of beef topped with a thick layering of green peppers, mushrooms, tomatoes and cheese—then slipped back under a broiler. 
Both dishes were served with a bowl of spaghetti 
What a delicious way to overeat! h or dessert. Gian Carlo’s offers three things that are homemade—rum cake 
(not always available), flan (plain as well a s flavored with coconut and guava) and bread pudding. 

The wine list is limited to IO labels, ranging from Mateus at $5.75 to Bar- ba resea ut $9 75. Beers include domes­ tic and imported varieties ranging from 65 cents to 85 cents a bottle. 
Pavesi came to San Antonio last July from Connecticut—for the weather and 
“ the nice people around here." 
He hail planned lo open a pizza parlor but looked around and decided that would be “ like trying lo compete with 
McDonald's!" 
Instead, he gathered up his cooking experiences in France, Tripoli and 
Libya (backed up with train in g in 
Italy) and opened his triple specialty restaurant. 
Hours are 11:31) a m. lo 2 p.m. and 5 to ll) p.m. Monday through Saturday’. 

Joyce Terrell picks up her application for Joske’s 
19 77-78 Teen Board from Teenas Cheryl Farris and Kathy Clark. Applications for the Teen Board are availab le in the junior departm ents of all 

Joske’s Stores. Preliminary tryouts will be at 
1o:3o a.m. April 2 in the downtown store. C on ­ testants must bring the completed application to their interviews. 

PHO TO BY R O N JO N E S 

Home tour will begin 
Saturday 

Five San Antonio homes will be open Saturday and Sunday for the 
4oth Annual Home and G arden 
Pilgrim age sponsored by Christ 
Episcopal Church. 

On view will be the gardens and residences of Et. Gen. and Mrs. 
Allen M. Burdett Jr.. 6 Staff Post 
Road (Ft. Sam Houston)) Mr. and 
Mrs. 
Jam es 
P. 
Robinson ll. 
3435 Twisted Oaks; Don Morris. 
245 Fox Hall; Mr. and Mrs. Walter 
F. Brown, 213 Sir Arthur; and Ro­ bert Daubert, 215 W. Kings High­ way 

Tickets for the tour (noon-6 p.m. each day) are priced at $2.5o and are available at Jo sk e’s, Handy 
Andy Supermarkets, HEB Food 
Stores, the Witte Museum. Muni­ cipal A uditorium , local flower shops and at garden gates during the Pilgrimage. 

Buses will leave Municipal Au­ ditorium each day. as loaded, between the hours of 11:3o a iii. and 2 p.m. Bus tickets are $2 for adults aud $1 for children.

LADY BIRD JOHNSON WITH FICUS COWLCS MEYER 
...renewing friendship over lunch in San Antonio 

Fleur reminisces about Look, Flair 

By DEBORAH WESER 

Painter - writer- 

 editor and one-time proper 
Bostonian 

 omanbSliop 

 n m J I am rn C 
Sn i a m # 
Half and large Size fashions 

SIZ ES 38 to 16 

2 5 
Float your separates 

 our Ila lid k e r e l i ie ! 

»t s h e e r | »«»I\ ( M e r . 

 iif * e k liiie a m i iii .i 

I M n p r in t u t i i i i i It i 

 it ll h im * o r b r o w n . 

It*?' ^ a l l i a b l e ! 

XII. OK PHOM 22.*..I Itll 
Ids ami I IMI fur lljinllm^ 

Fleur Cowles Meyer lunched Friday with her long-time Texas friend 
Lady Bird 

Johnson amidst a coterie of other San 
Antonio Texans. 

The river-edge noon stop provided an excuse for gossip, conversation and a spate of philoso­ phic comment about where the world they knew had gone and what’s in store for the future. 
Mrs. Johnson recently returned from a trip to 
Egypt that enchanted her with color, feel and tex­ ture of the ancient na­ tion 
She and her visitor were in town only briefly for a quick tour of th** ci­ ty and its missions. 
Mrs. 
Meyer 
— a former associate editor of Look Magazine (now only a memory to those who remember its pho­ to-factual reporting tech­ niques) — has put her hand to advertising. editing, reporting, even a little roving ambassa­ dorship for the late Pre­ sident Dwight Eisen­ hower. 
London 

Now she’s a painter living in an antique building in the heart of 
London and married to 
Tom Montague Meyer 
(pronounced Meer as the 
Dutch do), a timber ex­ pert 
“ I met him in Persia 

 when I was visiting the 
Shah and he was prospecting the forests,” 
Mrs Meyer says with a twinkle. 
On the verge of her 26th one-man show as a painter. Mrs. Meyer has profound memories of her major venture into avant-garde publishing: 
The incredible magazine called Flair that lived for about two years in the early 195os 

D e lig h t 
Texture, paper quali­ ty. illustration, die-cut detail, pullout material and story effort added up to visual and intellectual delight. The economics of that kind of publication is another story. 
And. in 1952-53 it seemed war was about to break out again As 

Mrs. Meyer recalls it was hardly the time to launch an elegant magazine 
‘‘We closed it in IO minutes and I wept but there’s no way to discuss that. It seemed wrong to be doing it,” she added. 
What does the world hold now for a woman w ith success on her credit sheet and homes in Lon­ don. Spain and Sussex? 
“ I want to do everyth­ ing I ’ve ever done hut better.” 
She’ll start with a trip to New York in the next few days to discuss four impending books with her publisher. Morrow. 
Lunch, by the way. was set in the top-floor river­ side apartment of Mrs. 
Nancy Negley, overlook­ ing the busiest part of the downtown San Antonio 
River.

Fashions from the Da­ vid Warren complex and the latest in beachwear will take to the Frost runway at I p.m. Satur­ day in the court of the 
North Star Mall. 
The David Warren fa­ shion complex encom­ passes six companies—David W ar­ ren. designs of sophisti­ cated. uncluttered dresses. Pedestal, maker of better up-dated dresses; DW3. creator of better and more sophisti­ cated misses dresses. 
Also. Shawn Originals, maker of distinctly young fashions; Hearsay O ri­ ginals. designer of super-young eontempo dresses; and Reggio, de­ signer of after-five and long dresses. 
Frost’s show will de­ monstrate the unique­ ness of each of the War­ ren companies. 
Before and after the show. David's Warren's em ny I rom New York. 
Matt Metger will he in the Spectator Shop where fashions will he infor­ mally modelled 
Swim fashions to he featured at the I p in show include designs from Gottex, Ralston, 

Christian Dior. Roxanne, 
De Weese, Catalina. Ser­ um, Sandcastle. Poppy, anil Cole of California 
Swimwear, for summer’77 moves toward with the unconstructed look Minimal weight fa­ brics in eye-catching co­ lors welcome the female figure. 

Beach accessories also will be shown including fashion sunglasses by 
Nina Ricci. Dior and Va­ lentino, terries by John 
Floss an.I gauze-t iesh cover-ups by Mel Mort* man.

Ella Shcaefer, chaplain, and L. H. Wingert, guard

Republicans set spring tea 

Alamo City Republican Women will have a 
Spring Tea and Fashion Fling at 4 p rn Friday 
Fashions from Clothes, Etc. and Courtney Scott and Friends will be modeled 
Tickets are $4 and will be sold at the door. 
Proceeds will be go to local Republican candi­ dates. 
Altar Society sets bus tour 

Our Lady of Grace Al­ tar Society will sponsor a bus tour to the Alamo and 
Missions followed by a lunch at the Bright Shawl 
Friday. 

The tour will begin at 
9 45 a m 

Mrs. William C. Cruze is chairperson assisted by Mrs. William Hauser. 

GLL offers writing class 

Registration is under­ way for an adult enrich­ ment course in creative writing sponsored by Our 
Lady of the Lake Univer­ sity. 

The class will meet at 
7:3o p m. on Mondays for 

 eight weeks in the Main 
Building at GLL 
Free lance author Mrs 
Fleur Tamon will teach the class. For inform a­ tion and registration call the university’s Continu­ ing E d u catio n D e p a rt­ ment

The

City 
Chapter of the American

3 to 5 p.m. Sunday in the 

 home of Leonora Robin­ son. 

The ABWA party will h ig h lig h t the 
ABWA spring enrollment event.

The State Association of Texas Pioneers will hold an informal dance at the Pioneer Hall at 8:3o p.m. 
Friday. The Toe 
Tappers O rchestra will plav for the dance 

* Past Lady Chairmen of the State Pioneers will honor the Lady Chairman 
Mrs. Farrell Moore with a luncheon at I p.m. April 
2 in the Ming Room at the 
Monger Hotel

Getting tired of door in face 

Do yon of vintage age remember when you were a girl and your e leg a n t aunt came to visit, wear­ ing a platinum brooch on the left shoulder of her dress? 

Of course, the pin was set with sparkling d ia­ monds, and you gasped in admiration. 

Such soigne ornaments have been m issing for some years, either stored in safe-deposit boxes or reset. 
But, now, platinum is being re in tro d u c e d by jewelers, its appeal and value having been disco­ vered anew 

Platinum has a singu­ lar resistance to corro­ sion In jewelry, it is the purest metal, with only 5 lier cent of either iridium or ruthenium 

Thus, a .jewelry item com posed of platinum holds gems with utmost security. 

It never tarn ish es or needs polishing. I ’sed bv the E g y p tia n s in the 
16oos, it adds its sheen to the gem s it holds. P la­ tinum started coming in­ to its own in the late ‘2os 

J u s t as the je w elers discovered its rem ark a­ ble properties, so did in­ d u s tr y , and valuable fsupplies were snapped nip. 

New deposits are now available and jewelry designers are competing to create pieces with the feeling of modern sim ­ plicity and tasteful qua­ lities. 

For ex a m p le , a p e n ­ dant with a flexible han­ dle and the wearer’s ini­ tials. Platinum seems a lovely bit of news for Lo­ velies. 

Do you have a hand problem ? Send for LO­ 
V ELIER 
HANDS, a booklet that covers every step in your quest for hand beauty. It tells how to keep the skin and nails groom ed; how to over­ come weak nails, polish chips, discolored knuck­ 

 les. pro m in en t veins. wrinkles, how to use the hands with poised grace 
For your copy, write to 
Mary Sue Miller in care of The Express, Box 2171, 
San Antonio, Tex 78297, enclosing a long, self-ad- dressed, stam ped enve­ lope and 2o cents in coin. 

MARY Silt MILLER 

D ear Ann: 
Y o u ’ve spoken out for w a i­ tre s s e s , te a c h e rs, bus drivers, mailmen, dogs, cats, n u rse s, m e te r readers and policemen, but I don’t think you have ever said anything in be­ half of doormen. Please, 
Ann, print this. We need help. 
Will you inform your readers that a doorman is expected to do a lot m ore than just open a door? For example, my duties include announc­ ing guests, hailing taxis, delivering messages and gifts to resid en ts, h an ­ dling keys for repairmen who are in and out con­ stantly, taking messages for people as they come and go, and h an d lin g n ew sp a p e r d eliv erie s, which m eans counting, recording and paying for p ap e rs — s o m e tim e s even selling them. 
In the building where I work there is no time set aside for a m eal or a coffee break. When we are seen drinking coffee on the job we sometimes get reported 
Don’t you think we are entitled to have a cup of coffee du rin g an eight- hour work period? You’d be s u rp ris e d at how many people resent it 

Ann 

Landers 

Dor union says we need only to open doors, a n ­ nounce gu ests and get taxis. 
Everything else we do is ex tra — because we w ant to give good s e r ­ vice. How about asking your readers to give us a break? — I Live In Chi­ cago 
Dear Doorman: So do I 
— and I’m happy to print your letter and add my plea for a little more un­ d e rsta n d in g . 
Have a h e a rt, folks. Give the doorman a break 
Punished 

Dear Ann: I'm writing about the student who was caught reading your column in class and was punished 
As one who is involved 

 with education and n ew sp a p e rs, I believe stu d en ts could benefit from re a d in g your co­ lumn — beyond the a d ­ vice that you give. All it takes is a teacher with a little im agination... 
For example, your co­ lumn could he used as a good exam ple of lucid writing, correct punctua­ tion, rules for capitaliza- ttion, prefixes, suffixes and so on. 
Students could be as­ signed to write a letter to 
Ann L a n d e rs about a p ro b lem . 
I t ’s an interesting subject (one’s self, th a t is) and the teac her would learn a lot about the student. 
The w ise teacher would use a student’s interest in your column as a spring­ board to create a positive learning experience. 
— 
E D R , Memphis Com­ mercial Appeal 
Dear ILI).: Thanks for accentuating the positive. 
I’m glad you said it — because I have thought it!

Dear Ann Landers: 
This letter is intended to inform doctors us to how their waiting rooms are run Many don’t have the foggiest notion 
I w as in a d o c to r's waiting room last week when a nurse came over to the young woman seat ed next to me and. in a voice that sounded like foghorn, asked some inti­ mate questions about ur m e sp e c im e n s, stool cultures and so on 
The woman, red-faced and e m b a rra s s e d , ans wered in hushed tones. 
E veryone around us heard the questions even if they didn't hear the answers A similar lnci dent happened at another doctor’s office yesterday. 
Neither of these offices is a free clinic. Both doc tors charge plenty. As physicians they are ex cellent but I would rate their staffs at zero minus 
IO — A Witness 
D ear W itness: 
Why don’t you do these doctors a favor and TELL them? 
Discover how to be date bait without falling hook line and sin k e r. Ann 
Landers's booklet, “ Dat­ ing Do’s and Don’t s . ’’ will help you be m ore poised and sure of your­ self on dates. 
Send 5(1 cents in coin along with a long, stamped, self-addressed envelope with your r e ­ quest to Ann Landers, care of The Express, Box 
2171, San Antonio, Tex., 
78297.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S — Saturday March 26 1977 

Wetter , climate today 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
A few Texans escaped dreary, wet weather 
Friday, but the spread­ ing pall was expected ti* catch everyone by Satur­ day. 
Fog, drizzle, light rain and thick clouds stretched from Childress to San Angelo to Del Kin 
Friday. Fog shrouded an area from North Central 
Texas through South 
Texas all tin* way to the 
Hio 
Grande 
River, 
Visibility al Alice and 
Austin was down lo one- fourth of a mile. 
Temperatures were mild, with most readings in the lids and 7os. 
Forecasts called for continued mild weather, w itll clouds increasing from the west and developing into showers and thundershowers across the state by Sa- tu rd a v.

Streets bill gets support 

City Councilman Bob 
Billa called Friday for wide support for a texas 
House bill that would re­ turn millions of dollars to 
San Antonio for street repairs. 

City Council Thursday passed a resolution of endorsement proposed by Billa in support of a btl! by State 
Frank 
Tejeda. It would return a portion of the vehicle use tax to cities. 
“ Everyone complains about bad streets lint funding is not available without a tax increase or bond issue," he said, ad­ ding the Tejeda bill would help solve the problem.

SPACIAL TO THI EXPRESS NEWS 

AUSTIN — Texas Air 
Control Board hearings 
Examiner John Turney announced 
Friday the postponement of a public hearing on San z\ntonio's request for authority to remove catalytic con­ verters from its police cars. 

The hearing, on a pe­ tition for a variance from 
TACH Regulation IV, which requires the main­ tenance of auto ('minis- sions controls systems in proper working order, had been scheduled for 
Monday in San Antonio. 

But, .Asst. C.ity Atty. 
Nelson Clare requested the delay on grounds San 
Antonio needed more 

 time to evaluate docu- scheduled or its variance mentary evidence sub- petition withdrawn, nutted in advance of thef hearings by the staff of J the TACB and the Envir­ onmental 
Protection 
Agency. 

Clare also said the additional time would be used to consider whether it was in the city's best interest to pursue the variance request. 

He said the city might instead ask the TACB to amend its regulation to exempt all police vehi­ cles from the catalytic convertor requirement. 

Clare agreed the city would report to the TACB within HO days indicating whether San Antonio wanted the hearing re- 

Com. .Jeff Wentworth will speak for Bexar 
County Monday in z\ustin when the Legislature argues over a bill that could give ordinance- making power to Texas counties. 
Commissioner’s Court 
Friday designated 
Wentworth the official representative. Com. Al­ bert Bustamante also hopes to he present to speak in favor of the hill. 
Counties in Texas, unlike cities, do not have ordin­ ance making powers. 
In other action. Com­ missioner’s Court’auth­ orized funds allowing 
Precinct 5 Constable I II. 
Garza Jr. to hire three deputies of his own choice for service in his area. 
The men will he paid 
$Koti a month and will he en i e to a $15o monthly car allowance under the arrangement approved by Judge Blair Reeves and commissioners. 

Also approved were new clerk and assistant clerk positions for the four new courts created for Bexar County. 

Garland boy killed 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 

GARLAND — Jimmy 
Gary Hind Jr. 9, of 38UB 
Larkin in Garland was killed Wednesday when the ear his mother was driving collided with an­ other vehicle. 
He is the son of Mr. and 
Mrs. G. J. Hind and the grandson of Mr. and Mrs. 
Jim Hind of San Antonio. 
Police Traffic Investi­ gator B ill Pease said charges of involuntary manslaughter are pend­ ing against the 
2o-year-old driver of the other car. 
Police said the case will he referred to the 
Dallas Grand Jury.

Some politicians are like ships Noisiest when lost in a fog 
There was no fan clouding the defense of today s excit­ ing part score deal, thanks lo the suit preference signal, the defenders were able to score all available tricks tor down 
3oo on a hand that might have made on another day 
This was the bidding re- portE*d when this hand was played at the Fall National 
Tournament in Pittsburgh 
East opened a weak two hid and after two passes. North 
Competed w ith a. don hied A risky bid, but the sort that is often made at tournament play South would have been belter off had he passed, however, he hid a normal three hearts and it was time to defend. 
The spade deuce went to 
East s ace and East was reasonably sure that the deuce was a singleton Had 
West held three spades, it seemed likely that West would have competed to three spades rather than de­ fend against three hearts 
So East gave the first signal by leading back the spade seven to alert West that East preferred the return of the higher ranking side suit after the ruff 
West ruffed and complied and a low diamond went to 
East s ace East led another spade - the lowest to show preference fur the lower ranking side suit West ruffed again and led the act* of clubs followed by the four of clubs fanother signah East ruffed gratefully and the requested diamond return went to 
West’s king for the defender s seventh trick

ST. LOUIS — Chevrolet's famed 
Corvette has marked another m i­ lestone iii its saga as America's only authentic sports car. 
The occasion was the production o| the 
•oil (MintIi Corvette at the (ieneral Motors 
Assembly Division plant here, which has been producing lite popular fiberglass bodied sp o rtster sin ce it entered the 
Chevrolet line iii 1955 
R o b e rt I) Lund. C h e vro le t general manager and a <ieneral Motors vice pre­ sident. said the Corvette m ystique has grown well beyond the actual number of vehicles built and has been a key to the automaker s overall product image. 
Im age ca r 
In nearly 25 years. Corvette has con­ tinued to he Chevrolet's image ear. parti­ cularly among young people and serious auto enthusiasts." Lund said. "Corvette s distinctive styling and its record for au­ tomotive innovation have led to its current success in the marketplace. 
"B u ild in g on our record I DTH sales of 
41.1127, Corvette dem and is again w ell ahead of our capacitv for 1977. 
"Current mode! year sales are running slightly ahead of the I97ti pave with hack

Milestone Unit 
Tile milestone unit — a classic white 
Stingray — came off the assem bly line at the (ieneral Motors Assem bly plant at 2 til 
P rn March 15 after a final inspection In 
Lund aud Plant Manager Ralph ilallquist. 
"T he men and women el this facility take great pride iii building Corvettes." 
Lund declared "In nearly a quarter of a century, this Si 
Louis product has be­ come one of the best known automobiles 

 iii the world and is a sym bol of Am erican automotive ingenuity 

The autom otive firs ts pioneered by 
Corvette, according to Lund. include 
• The first mass-produced fiberglass body 
• 
The lirst application of four-wheel disc brakes oil modern Am erican cars. 
• Independent rear suspension 
• Disappearing headlights 
• Tully concealed windshield wipers 
• Removable roof sections which make lls hardtop a semi-convertible 
Output largest 
W hile the Corvette's production is Ii nilled. Lund said its total output over the y e a r s surpasses the num ber of two-seat sports cars built under any other name­ plate iii world automotive history. 

"The Corvette’s impact on automotive trends and upon Chevrolet's image goes far beyond any production num bers. 
Lund declared "T h e half m illio n C or­ vettes are only a fraction of more than Ka m illion Chevrolet vehicles built, hut the prestige it has gained has added luster to every < hevrole! line

Auto dealer optimistic of future 

Hod E a s t is very o p tim istic about the economy; he is very optimistic about the future of San 
Antonio; he is very optimistic about new car sales this year. 
His optim ism is important because he lias inst been elected president of the San 
Antonin Automobile Dealers A ssn 
As far as Hic Carter adm inistration and the autom obile industry arc concerned. 
East expressed hope tile two could work together to solve the problems iii energy 
Ile would like lo see the two work hand iii hand in economy

Continued from Page I the patriarch of the Chevrolet car family. 
It is the oldest nameplate in the line ex­ cept for the regular Chevrolet. All the others have come along since the Cor­ vette. which joined the line in 1853. 
Chevrolet put the sports car into production after a preview of it as a 

Battery car fa r o ff 

SPICIAL TO THI tm tb S NfW S 

D ETRO IT — Electrically-powered cars conceivably could help make the federal target of 27.5 miles per gallon on the average U.S. car by 1885 easier to reach. 
But E. M. Estes, General Motors* presi­ dent. dispels such hopes when he says that mass output of cars running on battery power is at leas a decade away and maybe a little longer. 

Cycle tire m aker 

AKRON, Ohio — Firestone Tire & Rub­ ber is re-entering m otorcycle tire business after leaving the field in 19Ho. 
There are IO million motorcycles in the 
C S. and Firestone expects those tire 
Dili's to grow more than 5 per cent per vear in the next five years. 

 dream car in the 1953 General Motors 
Motorama, seen by about four million persons. 
The first 3oo were hand built at the 
Flint, Mich., assembly plant and then production was moved to St. Louis where all the rest of the Corvettes have been built. 
Principal milestones for the 98-inch wheelbase sportster have been the fol­ lowing. 
• Fuel injection models iii 1957 with impressive list of Sports Car Club of 
America championships. 
• Stingray model introduced in 59H3, along with four-wheel independent su­ spension. flip up headlights. 
• First American car with four-wheel disc brakes. 19H5. 
• Removable roof panels. 1988 
Among its many honors is the fact the 
Corvette is the daddy of Chevrolet’s ex­ perimental dream cars. It serves as a root for a long list of well-known experimental vehicles. 
The fam ily tree includes the Nomad, later a production wagon; Oorvair, Bis­ cayne and Impala cars shown in the Mo­ torama. that later became names of pro­ duction models; Stingray, Cerv I and ll. 
XP7oo, Grand Sport. Shark and Mako 
Shark. Manta Ray and Astro I and II. 
Astrovette and Muisanne.

ENGINE AND TRANSMISSION 

The new Lincoln Versailles — scheduled to go on sale April I 5 — will owe its exceptionally smooth and quiet ride to several engineering features drawn from the Lincoln Continental and Continental Mark V. In addition to the features pictured, the Versailles will incorporate several unique measures to assure a smooth ride, including new lower ball joints, shock absorbers doubly insolated, new forged aluminum wheels and a steering-shaft flex coupling designed to keep road shock from reaching the driver's hands. 

Continued from Page I 

 customer satisfaction 
“ I think I can speak for the dealers in 
San Antonio If they are aware of a prob­ lem. then they want to get it solved; in very few cases does it go beyond the dealer, lie usually gets the complaint from At T o r AP and gets it solv ed " 

•Judging from the load in the franchised service departments in San Antonio. East said a large number of customers con­ tinue to return to the franchised dealer tor service, even after the warranty on their car has expired. 

S o p h is tic a te d 

“ One thing you have to remember about today’s cars, they have become so sophisticated it takes a highly skilled mechanic, with the proper tools and equipment with updated repair manuals, to work on them.” he said 

The two factors of inflation and federal regulation have caused the prices of cars, and repairs to those cars, to rise in the past few years, East noted Ile said one of the results is that pimple are keeping their 

AUTOMOTIVI DISMAY 
AUTOMOTIVI DISMAY 
* ,rOMOTIVS DISMAY 
A U T O M O T IV I D IS M A Y 

 cars a year or two longer than they would have in the past. 

The cars that are being built right now arc extremely good cars,” East said, 
’ and ow ners can drive them an extra year or two 

“ The thing I can’t measure is the desire of pimple to trade ears ever two or three years People love a new automobile, and so their desire may be to continue to trade every two or three years. 

B u i l t to la s t 

‘‘As far as the cars are concerned, they are built to where they will certainly last. 
“ We still trade for a lot of late model cars We still trade with people who want a new car every year. It just really de­ pends upon what people really decide what they want to do. 

“ As far as the balanoe_of this year is concerned," East said, “ I look for it to be a tremendously successful year for San 
Antonio automobile dealers.” "The pt’O- ple here hame a very good attitude about the economy. 
‘ And with that attitude. I look for everyone to have a good year, not just the automobile dealers."

A ttention Scottish Rite Masons 

O n Saturday, March 2 6 at 7 :3 o P.M . a special dramatic program will be presented in the Scot­ tish Rite Auditorium, 

All Scottish Rite Masons who have attained the 
Twentieth Degree are cordia'ly invited to attend. 

This will be a Tiled Meeting and you must have your dues card to be admitted.

Dario Chapa, a can­ didate for City Council from District 5. Friday was hit by brick-bats from two opponents. 
Lu Betancourt, credit manager for a local ho­ tel, F rid a y charged 
Chapa, who lists his oc­ cupation as an educa­ tor. has a record of six arrests, none of which resulted''in conviction and were dismissed. 
She also produced a printout of the record she used as the basis of her allegations. 
Not reached 

Efforts to reach Cha­ pa for denial or verifi­ cation were unsuccess­ ful. 
In a public speech 
Friday. Ms. Betancourt questioned 
Chapa’s qualifications and cre­ dibility as a candidate for office. She also ac­ cused Chapa of conflict of interest, alleging he is maintaining full-time employment with the 
Mexican 
- American 
Neighborhood Civic Or­ ganization, an agency she said pays Chapa's salary using city funds 
Attacking 
Chapa from another direction was Bernardo Eureste, an assistant professor al Our Lady of the Lake 
University. 
A BC 
Eureste, also a can­ d id ate in D istrict 5, charged Chapa's cam­ paign “ is heavily fin­ anced by the ABC and j the developers.” ABC 
I stands for Alliance for a 
I Better City, a political 
I group organized after j the Good Government 
J League closed down. 
By soliciting and ob­ taining ABC's financial support, Eureste said. 
Chapa is selling out the 

 interest of the com­ m unities making up 
District 5. ABC and de­ velopers. through their support of Chapa. Eur­ este asserted, “ arc also interfering in the inter- j mil affairs of the coni-ii 
Triunity by using Mr. 
Chapa as a tool to des- j ? troy the viability and effectiveness of the San 
Antonio Communities 
Organized for Public 
Service (C O PS).’’ 
Threat 
The college teacher said it is an established fact ABC and the de­ velopers sec COPS as a threat to their develop­ ment strategies over the Edwards aquifer. 
He cited what he called Chapa’s “ disrup­ tive tactics” at a COPS 
Accountability Night as an example. 
Dupree nam es 3 issues 

City Council District 2 candidate 
Victor 
Dupree said Friday the three major problems facing his district are luck of jobs, high cost of energy and crime 
Dupree said his plans are to begin work with other council members to find solutions to these three problems. 
The candidate said lit­ is fam iliar with the problems alter working for more than IO years in community service programs 
Dupree told a group of District 2 residents bis platform also is based on seeking bu­ sinesses to locate within tile district.

Mayoral candidate Dr. Jose San Martin 
Friday told a group of Southwest San Antonio small businessmen City Hall should provide them with assistance. 
"America is based on the philosophy of free enterprise and the greatest number of busin­ esses are in the small category. 
“ But so many are going broke because so often they have no place to go." Dr. San Marlin said 
San Martin said the city should be in a position to refer small businessmen lo state and federal programs which are available to provide technical assistance. 
“ It is my opinion that the present city administration has totally left the small busin­ essmen out in the cold by ignoring them," he said. 
Ile said high utility bills alone are driving businesses to bankruptcy as no programs have been developed locally to assist. 
“ San Antonio’s economy is so dependent oil small business that the city should consider it at the top of its priority list,” Dr. San Martin said

A $3 a person fund­ raiser for Roberto G. 
Rodriguez, eandidate for City Council from 
District I. will start at ti p.m. .Saturday in Nueva 
Plaza. La Villita. 
Rodriguez said more than 5oo tickets have been sold 
Supporters will be entertained by a band and strolling m a ria ­ chis. and food and drink will be sold. 
Rodriguez Friday ac­ cused an opponent. 
Councilman Henry Cis­ neros. of using his council seat as a step­ ping stone for mayor two years from now

Com. Albert B u s ta ­ mante. Frank Sepulve­ da and other friends of 
.San Martin.
